—My question is directed to the Minister for Resources. Given some apparent confusion, can the minister advise the House of the benefits for the mining industry flowing from the government's proposed native title legislation?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Lee The Hon M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the honourable member for her question and her continuing interest in this area. Perhaps like a number of honourable members in the chamber, I have read with interest the comments by the mining industry lobby groups—in particular, the comments by the Australian Mining Industry Council and the Chamber of Mines of WA (Inc) in recent days—some of which have been critical of the government's Mabo proposal. I must say that I have found some of these comments puzzling when contrasted with some of the comments made by the chief executives of some of our mining companies. I will get back to that in a minute.

PARA.TAB: The key worry about the Mabo High Court decision, if we believe what the mining industry has put out in the past, has been its concern about uncertainty which we believe will be removed by our proposed legislation. There are many reasons why the mining industry should not only welcome the proposals that we have announced but also be working hard to convince the Liberal and National Party opposition at the federal level and the Liberal Party at the state level throughout the country to support the measures that we are putting forward.

The reason I am puzzled is that this morning I got out a copy of a pamphlet put out in June of this year by the Australian Mining Industry Council. In this pamphlet, AMIC listed eight points that it wanted satisfied by the government's legislation. Under the points, the mining industry put its position. I will quickly run through the eight points for the information of the House, given the interest in this matter. Under the first point, the mining industry said:

ANSWER.PARA: The mining industry recognises that native title exists where the conditions established by the High Court are satisfied.
Our bill is consistent with this view. So the first point gets a tick. The second point was:
Governments should move expeditiously and cooperatively to validate existing conventional titles to land.
The bill does that, so the second point gets a tick. The third point AMIC made in its pamphlet was:
Procedures should be put in place to register claims for native title with a `sunset' date being determined in order that uncertainty will not persist indefinitely.
The bill will do that without a sunset clause, so there is a qualified tick on the third point. The fourth point was:
Court processes should be employed to determine the validity of claims and the rights attaching to successful claims.
So on that point, again, our legislation satisfies that concern. The fifth point was:
States to continue to grant and validate mining and exploration leases while claims for native title are being processed.
Native title holders whose enjoyment of the title is disturbed would be entitled to compensation.

Our proposed legislation ensures that this will occur in some circumstances. While some additional protections are being afforded to registered native title claimants, grants of interest over land will continue to be able to be processed. So, there is a qualified tick on that point. On the next point AMIC said:
Apart from living areas and sites of special significance—the mining industry argued—there would be no right of veto by native title holders over mining or exploration.
Native title holders so affected would be entitled to compensation, as are other landowners in similar circumstances.
Our bill proposes for the right of negotiation as currently exists for other leaseholders under state procedures but no right of veto. So, again, we have satisfied that point. The seventh point was:
As determined by the High Court, native title cannot be revived after extinguishment.

This seems to be the only stumbling block—the only major difference—between us and the mining industry, if honourable members believe AMIC's pamphlet of June this year. The reason why there is a difference is that it is wrong. The High Court did not rule that mining leases or exploration licences extinguish native title. It was silent on this question. Under the general law, a mining lease or exploration licence can be issued over leasehold land—or even over your land, Mr Speaker. That exploration licence or mining lease is superior to the original leasehold or freehold title. The mining interest overrides the interest of the existing owner for the period of the mining operation. At the end of that mining operation, the interests of the original owner are restored. This bill proposes similar arrangements for native title holders. So, on this one major point of difference between the government and the mining industry, we believe that our position is eminently justifiable. On the eighth point AMIC argued:
Crown ownership of minerals must be retained for the benefit of all Australians.

The bill confirms this point. So, on the eight points which AMIC said was its position back in June, the government has given a tick to six, a qualified tick to the seventh, and AMIC was wrong on the eighth point—it was a furphy. It is rather difficult to understand some of the concerns that have been expressed.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the honourable member for his question. —When will the bill be introduced?
—Please, a separate question.

—I direct my question to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy. Would the minister please inform the House of the progress being made by Australian companies to increase food exports to Asia. What private sector commitment is there to the clean food export program?
—I can say at the outset that there has been significant progress in Australia's export penetration in high value added food produce, particularly into Asia.
—Backwards.

—It has not gone backwards—the Leader of the National Party should look at the figures. The fact of the matter is that we have now passed the $3 billion mark in the export of high value added food produce to the rest of the world. It has gone up $1 billion in the last two years.
—It has gone backwards in the last few years.
—Order! The Deputy Leader of the National Party!

—I reiterate: it has gone up $1 billion in the last two years. It took us the previous eight years to increase our food exports by the same amount. The progress has been very significant and should not be underestimated by the other side of the House. We are therefore well on the way to the target that the Minister for Industry, Technology and Regional Development and I have set, through the Agrifood Council, to treble food exports, in the main, to Asia by the year 2000—to take the figure of $3 billion to beyond $7 billion.

PARA.TAB: In essence, we have to be about convincing Asia of what we in this country take for granted, that is, our ability to produce the cleanest, the best quality and the most nutritional food produce that the world demands. An important part of the strategy that we have in place for this trebling of the export target is the clean food promotion campaign—a marketing strategy which, I am pleased to be able to say in response to the honourable member's question, industry has got solidly behind. So much so that, on the weekend, the Minister for Industry, Technology and Regional Development and I were able to launch the pilot program for the clean food strategy into Taiwan next month.

Industry is matching dollar for dollar the clean food campaign. The strategy itself is industry driven but government is assisting those industries that are prepared to get behind it. The significance of success is that it will enable us to rebuild our strength in agriculture but it will be a rebuilding of our strength on the basis of doing things in agriculture differently than we have in the past. Instead of just trading the commodity in the bulk, it means actually doing something with it before it leaves this country, and getting into the niche market opportunities overseas.

TALK.START.PARA: —We are doing less than we were doing five years ago.

—We are not doing less than we were doing before; we are increasing it significantly. If we are to require the conversion, the value adding, the linkages between the efficiency in production and manufacturing, that will require assistance to those companies that have not had experience in it before, in particular our agricultural producers who need to be assisted with marketing skills and the like. My department has a range of programs to assist in this regard. Last Friday, I am pleased to be able to announce, we indicated the first five of the programs which were beneficiaries, after the new one-shop-stop approach, whereby people can come to the Agrifood Council and not have to go through the red tape but be directed to the area of assistance that best suits their needs.

PARA.TAB: The potential is enormous in the food based products; it is also enormous, in my view, in the fibre based products. But, importantly, we have a strategy in place to get the food exports into Asia and, as the legislation currently going before the House will indicate, we will have it for the fibre based ones as well.
