DEBATE.TITLE: TAXATION LAWS AMENDMENT BILL (No. 3) 1993COGNATE BILL:INCOME TAX (FRANKING DEFICIT) AMENDMENT BILL 1993

PARA.TAB: Debate resumed from 29 September, on motion by Mr Gear:
That the bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Rocher Mr A.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 3) is an omnibus tax bill which amends the tax law in a number of respects. The principal amendments deal with the deferral of the initial payment of company tax, a tax exemption for non-profit tourist industry promoters, a sales tax exemption for the RSPCA, dividend imputation, income tax deductions for life insurance companies, capital gains tax treatment of life assurance policies, petroleum mining provisions, fringe benefits tax, resources rent tax and the superannuation guarantee charge. A number of minor technical amendments are also made. We will effectively be prevented from debating amendments which, I understand, are to be moved by the Assistant Treasurer (Mr Gear) at some later stage in these proceedings, and that is to be regretted. Those issues deal with deductions for the cost of establishing grapevines, sales tax application of penalties and sales tax exemption for child-care services.

PARA.TAB: Those three issues cannot be debated under standing orders because they are not before the chamber. With the guillotine on, we will not have the opportunity to discuss those matters. We are also debating cognately the Income Tax (Franking Deficit) Amendment Bill, which makes changes consequential to the amendments contained in Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 3).

Of all the measures contained in these bills, the coalition is most concerned with the proposed changes to the petroleum mining provisions. These changes are designed to close a loophole in the existing law which allows oil and gas companies to claim tax deductions on expenditure incurred in their tax exempt offshore mining, quarry and exploration activities. As a general principle, tax deductions cannot be claimed for expenditure in deriving tax exempt income.

The technical defect in the existing law, which Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 3) seeks to correct, allows mining companies to claim a deduction in Australia for expenditure incurred offshore, notwithstanding the fact that income from the offshore operations is not taxable in Australia. Every company in Australia involved in offshore oil and gas exploration is affected by these measures. The coalition's principal concern with this measure is that it is to be given retrospective effect from 7.30 p.m. on 21 August 1990—three years ago—the date on which the law was amended to give rise to this defect in the law. This is an outrageous proposal, not just because its retrospectivity is completely at odds with the principle of the rule of law but also because the proposed retrospective amendment is designed to cover up the downright incompetence of the Australian Taxation Office and the government.

The technical defect arose as a result of 1991 amendments to the tax law which deleted the words `in Australia' from the relevant provisions in the principal act. On two separate occasions, the effect of the 1991 amendments was raised with the Taxation Office by tax professionals through the regular consultative channels. The first occasion was at a meeting of the foreign income measures subcommittee of the National Taxation Liaison Group on 26 September 1991. At that meeting the Australian Taxation Office representatives gave an undertaking to tax practitioners that the issue would be examined. At a second meeting of the same committee held on 2 February 1992, representatives of the Taxation Office again advised that the issue was still under consideration.

The result of these two meetings was that tax professionals took the entirely reasonable view that the tax office had accepted that the law would operate according to the legislation as it then was and as it currently stands. Eighteen months later, on 4 August this year, the Assistant Treasurer issued a press release announcing the retrospective change to the tax law contained in this bill—a change that is completely at odds with the failure of the Taxation Office to correct the defect through the usual channels. The result is that taxpayers stand to be retrospectively disadvantaged as a result of their strict adherence with the law and despite their best efforts to clarify the law through the regular consultative processes with the Taxation Office.

The implications of this retrospective measure go beyond the disadvantage to be inflicted on these particular taxpayers. The implications extend to the integrity of the tax consultative process with the Australian Taxation Office. The government has used the goodwill and cooperation of taxpayers in this process to attack the rights of affected taxpayers through retrospective changes to the tax law. By acting retrospectively to the detriment of taxpayers, the ATO will effectively ensure that tax professionals will not in future raise matters of substance through consultative channels. When this happens the entire consultative process will break down to the detriment of the administration of tax law in this country.

According to tax practitioners, in a letter sent to the Assistant Treasurer, the Assistant Treasurer was not informed—perhaps through an oversight—that the tax office had not acted on representations by tax professionals when he made the decision to make this retrospective change to the tax law. They have, accordingly, called on the government to review and to reverse that particular decision. Unfortunately, the fact that we are debating this measure here today indicates that the Assistant Treasurer has ignored these appeals from tax practitioners. The result is that taxpayers will get the rough end of the stick to save the Taxation Office from embarrassment. The Taxation Office is prepared to wreck the consultative process with taxpayers and to undermine the operation of the rule of law in this country rather than admit that it has made a mistake in the drafting of the original law and to wear the consequences for the revenue which, we understand, amounts to $1 billion, although that is according to the government—and it generally overstates these figures.

Problems are compounded by the fact that the ATO has apparently issued several private rulings to individual taxpayers confirming that the expenses concerned are deductible. Either the government is proposing to overturn these private rulings through its retrospective legislation, which would be a disaster for tax administration, or it is proposing to treat taxpayers differently in identical circumstances, which means that the principle of equality before the law is to be thrown out the window. The government is walking all over the rights of taxpayers in this matter, with grave implications for the administration of tax law.
This situation was summed up by Mr Alf Capito, tax partner of Arthur Andersen, quoted in the Australian Financial Review of 6 August this year. He said:
The tax office has realised now there is a problem and is solving it by introducing retrospective legislation to cover its own incompetence . . .
Because they suspected a flaw in the legislation, many mining companies acting in good faith sought advice from tax experts, who advised their clients of the law as it stood at the time.

SPEECH.PARA: Now the law has been changed and companies which acted legally at the time have to suffer financially because of a fault which had been pointed out to the ATO two years ago. That is it in a nutshell, as related by Mr Capito. Accordingly, the coalition will move an amendment to this bill in the committee stage to remove its retrospective effect. The amendment will read:
Clause 18, page 5, omit the clause, substitute the following clause:

"18. The amendments made by this Division apply in relation to expenditure incurred after 7.30 p.m., by standard time in the Australian Capital Territory, on 21 August 1990 which has not been claimed as a deduction in a return furnished to the Commissioner prior to 5 August 1993.".
or—
. . . after—
and the time is to be inserted—
by standard time in the Australian Capital Territory, on 4 August 1993 . . .

The amendment will ensure that the government's changes to the tax law will have effect only from 4 August 1993, the date on which the government announced its decision to close the self-inflicted loophole. The actions of the government and the ATO in this matter are simply unconscionable and the amendment accordingly deserves the support of this House.

PARA.TAB: This is only one of several retrospective measures that the government has resorted to in recent years and the frequency seems to be on the increase. Only a few weeks ago we were asked to approve a retrospective customs tariff measure which sought to take away the rights of certain importers to a refund of customs duty to which they may have been entitled at law.

The government's actions in relation to the administration of taxation do much to prove the truth of Sir Harry Gibbs's assessment of the Australian taxation system in an address he gave to the 11th national convention of the Taxation Institute of Australia as recently as May of this year. Sir Harry is Chairman of the Australian Taxation Research Foundation and has an abiding interest in the subject of tax reform. His speech to the national convention of the Taxation Institute earlier this year is a 30-page indictment of Labor's tax system. Sir Harry refers to Professor Parsons's comparison of the tax law to a supernova as:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . a star which in its death throes undergoes a dramatic increase in size and intensity before finally collapsing.
After noting the massive uncertainty that currently prevails in the administration of the tax system, Sir Harry stated:
Legislation which has effects such as this is quite unacceptable in a democratic society.
He is talking about the Australian tax system. He went on to observe:

PARA.TAB: It is not an exaggeration to say that the Income Tax Assessment Act is obscure and uncertain in its operation, it is burdensome to comply with and to prevent avoidance it resorts to heavy penalties and to discretions so wide as to make it a gamble for a taxpayer to endeavour, quite legitimately, to reduce tax payable.
Such a law reflects no credit on the society which tolerates it.

SPEECH.PARA: Nor, might I add, does it reflect credit on the parliament that legislates that law in the first place. Sir Harry Gibbs's comments are supported by figures gathered by the tax office.

PARA.TAB: I refer in particular to a study by the Dandenong branch of the ATO into compliance levels among personal taxpayers selected for audit. This study found that 100 per cent of taxpayers audited filed incorrect returns in relation to lump sum payments, eligible termination payments and capital gains tax. The error rates for dry-cleaning expenses, uniforms, clothing, gifts, tools and superannuation were all between 91 and 99 per cent. The average additional tax payable on eligible termination payments after audits was $7,200.

That underlines the fact that the tax system is so complex, to the point of incomprehensibility, that ordinary people are unable to comply with it. Honourable members cannot tell me that 100 per cent of taxpayers in certain categories, or between 91 and 99 per cent of taxpayers in other categories, deliberately set out to avoid or evade tax. They cannot understand what they are required to do.

Honourable members will recall that similar results have been obtained with the fringe benefits tax, where the average adjustment as a result of an audit is in the vicinity of $52,000. We have also seen the ATO's large case audit program allegedly net massive amounts in unpaid tax from major Australian companies, reflecting the massive level of uncertainty about the payment of company tax under existing law. Significantly, a major proportion of these funds is subject to legal challenge by the companies concerned.

According to the Corporate Tax Association, 30 per cent of the $1.14 billion in additional company tax assessed by the tax office as a result of the large case audit program is being challenged in the courts. The ATO has collected only one-sixth of the $4.64 billion that was initially claimed by the ATO as having been netted by the large case audit program. These figures confirm a tax system which is out of all control and needs to be brought to heel. Mr Bob Bryant of the Corporate Tax Association is quoted as saying:

SPEECH.PARA: Australia's corporate tax system is beginning to crumble under the weight of its own complexity.

That is not an understatement. Legislation such as that we have before us today, and the proposed changes to the petroleum mining provisions in particular, do not give us any confidence that the deficiencies are being addressed by Labor. Its so-called tax simplification project has so far failed to materialise. If anything, the tax law has become even more complex since the simplification exercise was first announced. I move:

PARA.TAB: That all words after "That" be omitted with a view to substituting the following words: "whilst not declining to give the Bill a second reading, the House:
(1)condemns the Government for its inefficient handling of the changes relating to the taxation of offshore petroleum exploration activities; and

(2)calls on the Government to ensure that companies which have lodged returns in accord with the existing provisions relating to offshore petroleum exploration activities are not penalised retrospectively".

SPEECH.PARA: The remaining provisions of these two bills give the coalition no cause for great concern and we will not be opposing them accordingly. The deferral of the initial payment of company tax for the 1993-94 year of income for companies with a tax liability of less than $300,000, and which pay their tax in two instalments, is a welcome measure. It should be remembered, however, that the government has done much to bring forward the payment of company tax during its time in office, and so we should not look upon the measure as any great concession.

PARA.TAB: The grant of a sales tax exemption to the RSPCA is an appropriate measure, although it does point to the ongoing problems of anomalies with sales tax concessions. There are other organisations engaged in equally worthy activities which do not enjoy an exemption, and there is really no basis for their different tax treatment, other than that the government has made provision for one of these organisations but not for the others. We do not begrudge the RSPCA its tax exemption, but we would point out that the sales tax system by its very nature does not treat taxpayers equally and thereby violates what should be an important principle of tax law.

The two bills contain important changes to the imputation system as a result of the reduction in the company tax rate from 39 per cent to 33 per cent for 1993-94 and later years of income. The changes allow companies to pass on to shareholders the full value of any imputation credits for tax paid at the old 39 per cent rate by using dual franking accounts rather than the existing single franking account. Without these amendments, the value of the 39 per cent imputation credits would be reduced when passed on to individual shareholders.

The bill also deals with provisions relating to the income tax deductions allowable to life assurance companies. Currently, life assurance companies are disadvantaged by a requirement to include in their taxable income the tax liability of a superannuation fund, which is an unintended effect of the existing legislation. The bill amends the relevant formulae for the calculation of the tax liability of life assurance companies so that these amounts will no longer be included in their assessable income.

Amendments are also made to the capital gains tax treatment of life assurance policies. These particular amendments are designed to ensure that capital gains from life assurance policies realised by superannuation funds are treated in the same way as the general concessional treatment of these funds.

The capital gains tax provisions will no longer apply to capital gains—or losses—realised on the disposal of life assurance policies, or rights under such policies, by complying superannuation funds, ADFs, and PSTs, regardless of whether the fund or trust is the original beneficial owner of the policy. This exemption will apply to disposals after 1 July 1988, which also makes these amendments retrospective in their effect. However, since these amendments will serve to confer a small benefit, the coalition has no fundamental objection to them.

The bill makes changes that serve to retain the existing provisional tax uplift factor at eight per cent. The eight per cent uplift factor is applied to income for 1992-93 for the purposes of calculating provisional tax for 1993-94. The provisional tax system, however, is a particularly contentious imposition on taxpayers, and it is made more so by the uplift element. This is despite the fact that it has been reduced from 10 per cent to eight per cent in recent years.

Surely, the existing rate for the provisional tax uplift factor needs to be reconsidered. Interest rates and inflationary expectations have fallen considerably since the eight per cent figure was set, and there is no sign yet that interest rates have bottomed. The uplift factor is applied in a completely indiscriminate way, which assumes that the provisional taxpayer's income will increase by the percentage stipulated, when in fact that income could rise or fall by an amount well outside the eight per cent range.

The only way to mitigate the effect of the uplift factor is by applying for a provisional tax variation from the ATO. But this does not really help the situation, since it greatly increases the exposure of taxpayers to penalties and back taxes if they should misjudge their likely non-exertion income for the financial year ahead. Such penalties can easily wipe out the benefits of a possible provisional tax variation, so many people are trapped into paying provisional tax, and will have to recoup any overpaid tax at the end of the financial year. Any provisional tax uplift factor will inevitably be an arbitrary imposition. The only way in which the arbitrariness can be reduced is if it is kept at the lowest possible rate, and if taxpayers are given a fair margin of error in calculating a provisional tax variation.

The bill also makes some changes to the petroleum resources rent tax law, to ease compliance with the law and to prevent the distortion of commercial decision making where there is a change of interests in a project. These amendments will treat the transfer of part of a taxpayer's interest in a petroleum project in the same way as transfers of a taxpayer's whole interest.

Exploration expenditure incurred in one project will become offsettable against assessable receipts from other projects, or against assessable receipts derived by another company in the same wholly owned company group. Exploration expenditure incurred in the financial year in which a person abandons a petroleum project can be offset against receipts from other projects. The amendments also increase the time available for the lodgment of expenditure transfer notices and for the lodgment of the annual petroleum resource rent tax returns.

The bill makes some minor changes to fringe benefits tax provisions to reflect the effects of the deregulation of domestic aviation in Australia over the last few years. Under the existing arrangements, a fringe benefit for airline transport arises when an airline operator, or travel agent, provides transport to an employee.The taxable value of this benefit is the stand-by value of the transport provided, less any contribution made by an employee.

Currently, the stand-by value is calculated with reference to the economy air fare of either the provider of the service or Australian Airlines. The amendments mean that no particular airline will now be referred to for FBT valuation purposes. References to Australian Airlines are no longer appropriate for a number of reasons, but particularly given the changes that have taken place in recent years to the domestic passenger market in Australia. Where an airline has a published economy air fare different in value from a non-published economy air fare, only the published fare will be used for valuation purposes. The bill also removes the requirement for certain employers to disclose the sources of information used in the compilation of their fringe benefit tax return.

As I have said, the bill essentially has the support of the coalition. Many of the measures contained in the bill are concessional in nature, with the one exception that I have already mentioned concerning the retrospective element of the proposed changes to the petroleum mining provisions. As I said, amendments in my name have been distributed, one of which will be moved in the committee stage, and one which is relevant to the second reading debate. I conclude by saying that the coalition does not support the retrospective change proposed, and I enjoin honourable members to support the coalition amendment when it is brought before the committee.
Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Hon. N.B. Reid)—Is the amendment seconded?

TALK.START.PARA: —I second the amendment.

—This is a debate on a very large number of amendments to the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 3) and the Income Tax (Franking Deficit) Amendment Bill but, rather than canvass any number of those topics, I would like to concentrate on chapter four, the deductions allowable to life assurance companies. This has been the cause of some correspondence and debate between the Life Insurance Federation of Australia, representing the life insurance industry, and the government over a number of months. We resolved one thing in particular that was sought by LIFA in a sense, in its favour. We also resolved a second matter, not necessarily in its favour—it may not agree—so I would like to explain how we reached our particular decision on that matter.

PARA.TAB: We need to explain the various and different rates at which life assurance companies are taxed. This is really a debate about which streams of money will be taxed at what level and whether we can adjust the contributions in each tax stream so that life assurance companies, unlike most other taxpayers, have separate classes of assessable income arising from the various types of business in which they are engaged. There are four classes of income, each taxed at a different rate. The relevant classes and rates of tax are: first, the non-complying superannuation class, which is assessable at 47 per cent; second, the complying superannuation and rollover annuity class, which is assessable at 15 per cent; third, the accident disability residual life assurance class, which is assessable at 39 per cent; and, fourth, a non-fund class, where non-mutual company taxes are assessable at 33 per cent and mutual company taxes are assessable at 39 per cent. These unique factors make it necessary to allocate or apportion deductions to the particular class of assessable income so that the overall tax liability of the company may be determined. This calculation and apportionment of some deductions are achieved through formulas in the tax law. There is discussion of these formulas as part of the bill.

The two amendments in particular, which the Treasurer (Mr Dawkins) announced as at 31 May, intend to make certain changes to the formulas. These are that transferred superannuation contributions, what are known as section 275 amounts, no longer be treated as assessable income for the purposes of the formulas and, second, that the apportionment formula would include as assessable income superannuation premiums and the investment component of ordinary life insurance premiums. These are the two amendments which are included in the bill, and they were introduced on 29 September this year.

The first of those amendments was requested by the Life Insurance Federation of Australia. We agree that that is a reasonable request, and we have produced the amendment. LIFA is not keen on the second one, however, and it thinks that our amendment will be detrimental to life insurance companies. In essence, it considers that the amendment unfairly directs a larger proportion of deductions to the lower taxed superannuation class of business. I want to respond to this because it is our view that LIFA is seeking to inject a degree of complexity here that will only make things more difficult all round. We have sought an amendment which maintains the simplicity of the system which, after all, is what industry is continually seeking us to do.

Our second amendment is designed so that the deductions allocated to each class of business of a life insurance company better reflect the expenses actually incurred in connection with that class of business. In other words, given that superannuation premiums and the investment component of life insurance premiums increase the overall deductions available to life insurance companies, the second amendment will ensure that these premiums will also be included in the formula which determines, on a proportional basis, how allowable deductions relate to the various classes of income of the life insurance company.

The particular concerns LIFA raised with us in relation to the second amendment are complex. Its main concern is that a group of expenses will be apportioned to differently taxed classes of income by the amended formula, even though these deductions are not necessarily boosted by the inclusion of premiums in the formula which determines allowable deductions, and that this will work to the disadvantage of the life offices. The formulas used to apportion the income and expenses of life insurance companies were included in the act in 1988 with the agreement of the life insurance industry, mainly to ease the compliance burden for life insurance companies. It is the case, however, that, as with any formula approach, this will not necessarily provide the most appropriate outcome for each individual expense when it is looked at in isolation. For some expenses a formula approach may result in a less valuable deduction for the life insurance companies and, equally, for other expenses the outcome may be more generous.

The aim of the formula approach is to provide an outcome which overall provides an appropriate determination of deductions when applied to a variety of different expenses. One of the options to address LIFA's concerns would have been to resort to a greater number of formulas to determine and apportion separate classes of deductions but, as I have mentioned before, this would have added considerable complexity to the law but with no guarantees that a more appropriate outcome would be obtained. Our approach—I think it is the desirable approach—to resolve issues relating to the appropriateness or otherwise of the determination and apportionment of deductions is to move away from a formula approach to an approach whereby income deductions are determined and apportioned to the maximum extent possible in a manner which is consistent with the actual income and expenses of each class of business, which we call a factual basis.

Within the government we have been exploring the possibility of moving to a factual approach, and we have informed LIFA that we are currently in the process of developing a paper outlining the issues raised in moving to a factual basis for discussion with that industry. I note that in LIFA's discussions with us it too was keen to move to a factual basis.A move to a more factually based approach involves consideration of some complex issues, and we will take some time, therefore, to work this out. Certainly in the interim the formula approach will be maintained. The apportionment formula contained in the amendment provides a fairer and more consistent basis for the treatment of deductions overall than does the current law.

The intention of that second amendment is to provide a formula which results in an appropriate apportionment of deductions between classes of income when applied to all the relevant deductions as a whole. It is our view that, if we had taken on LIFA's suggestion and let only the first amendment go through, the overall income would have erred significantly on the generous side for life insurance companies. So it was not possible to go down its route.

I will reiterate that we have been in close contact with LIFA on this issue. We have certainly held good discussions with it and have treated its concerns well. We are to remain in contact with LIFA over these complex matters. Nevertheless, we have chosen to introduce both of these amendments.

The Treasurer has indicated our approach to LIFA and has noted that in LIFA's correspondence with us it has a preference to move away from the formula approach to a factual basis for the tax of life companies. We have already informed LIFA of the work that we are doing on that, and we agree that that approach offers good prospects in moving to a means of taxing life insurance companies in a more acceptable manner to the industry.

We note in the attachment to some correspondence we have from LIFA that it canvasses the possibility of providing a separate formula for the apportionment of certain deductions, but it was our feeling, after considerable work on this, that there would be too great a complexity introduced without providing for a better overall outcome for either party—government or life insurance. We reiterate that the way forward on these issues would be best achieved by focusing on establishing an agreed approach to implementing a factual basis.

I wish to speak on only those matters relating to that section of the bill. I want to thank those in the government who have worked on these very complex matters and also reiterate that we have a good working relationship with the Life Insurance Federation of Australia and the insurance industry, and we will continue to keep up those good relations.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Braithwaite Mr R.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak on the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 3) and the Income Tax (Franking Deficit) Amendment Bill and to endorse the amendments of the honourable member for Curtin (Mr Rocher). I draw attention to the fact that once again we are debating taxation bills—and some of them are rather pernicious. I came into this parliament about 18 years ago, and in looking at the volume of legislation that has been passed since then—I give the example of the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 3), which is some 60-odd pages long—I think the size of tax bills has probably increased 10 times in that period.

PARA.TAB: But that is not the only problem. The complexity of the taxation laws has increased so much that it is now impossible for John Citizen to do his own income tax return, for two reasons: first, the fear that he may have missed out on a deduction he might have claimed; and, secondly, the fear that he might have overstated a deduction and understated income unintentionally and be subject to a fine. As a result, it is now the norm for consultants, QCs, specialists and everybody else in the taxation field to involve themselves in the tax affairs of John Citizen and the companies around Australia, substantially increasing the costs to business and to individuals.

I suppose the Parliamentary Secretary to the Treasurer (Mr Johns), who is at the table, would say, `So what?' because they get a taxation deduction for it in the long term. But I bring to the attention of the House the fact that, particularly in the taxation area, we need clear English and clear expression so that people can understand what is required. This will enable them to go about their business of tax lodgment and recording without the current fears of recriminations. In those 18 years a great cost has been imposed on businesses on a pro rata basis—businesses which are already suffering from increased taxation, let alone the cost of keeping accounts.

It is rather interesting that while we talk about complexity, the tax office was affected by the public servants strike yesterday which closed some offices and shortened the business hours of many others. This followed a work to rule procedure of a month ago when John Citizen could access taxation offices only within certain hours. It was suggested here within the last 12 months or so that, under an enterprise bargaining agreement, a proficiency bonus would be allocated to taxation staff who were able to collect more taxes. But that is the degree of their proficiency; people who are prepared to leave the affairs of the Commonwealth in disarray through stoppages such as these should not receive proficiency bonuses.

This smells a little of a book I am reading entitled Wild Swans: Three Daughters of China. It goes back to the China of the 1950s and 1960s where everybody was peering over everyone else's shoulder to make sure that they were not expressing any revolutionary slogans and were being faithful to the state. Sometimes I feel that our government departments—particularly the Taxation Office in offering incentives for the collection of taxation that is unintentionally avoided—are almost going back to those times.

In the context of this strike by public servants, I have also received a complaint about the Taxation Office, under its guidelines, continuing to put great pressure on tax agents over the lodgment of returns. For the individual, the complexity of the system has increased tenfold over the last 18 years. I am suggesting that the tax agents face a similar situation and similar stress. To be now pressured further by limiting their extension of time for the lodgment of returns I think goes beyond the pale.

The second bill, the Income Tax (Franking Deficit) Amendment Bill, takes into account the reduction of the company tax rate to 33c. I know that the main bill also separates the profits not distributed in a company prior to the reduction to 33c at the 39c level and then again at the 33c level. I think this measure is equitable and I hope it is given a lot of prominence because some company accountants could well be able to distribute profits from those pre-33c in the dollar days, and they should be encouraged to do so.

We are looking at a reduction from 39c to 33c. I believe the main explanations in the bill put the saving to the companies and in Commonwealth expenditure at $440 million in 1993-94, $1.83 billion in 1994-95 and $1.62 billion in 1995-96. I do not believe there is included in that calculation the contrary situation that will apply to shareholders above the marginal rate of 33c whereby, on imputation, they will be called upon to make up the difference between the 33c in their marginal rate and the current 39c marginal rate.

A company that distributes all of its profits—I cannot think of too many that do—will be caught in a situation where there has been simply a transfer of the taxation liability from the company to the shareholders. This will mean that a shareholder in receipt of a dividend will only need to have income of over $20,701, after which the tax rate is 35.33c in the dollar for 1993-94. The government might herald the reduction of 39c to 33c, but this was done not for any economic reason, but to counter the tax regime that the opposition proposed in the last election whereby personal rates of taxes were going to fall substantially. This, in addition to the budget itself, is not good news for the shareholder and personal taxpayer in any way whatsoever.

We well remember the promised tax cuts that were l-a-w but which turned out to be no more than an l-i-e. A lot of Australians will be remembering that at the moment. I have said it before: if the misrepresentation that has been perpetrated by the Labor Party on the people of Australia was in fact rendered by a company secretary, such misrepresentation would be subject to the Trade Practices Act and the companies and securities legislation and be subject to severe fines. Yet in the case of this most blatant misrepresentation, which has the greatest cost for the Australian people, the Labor Party and the Labor government escape any penalty whatsoever. It is a matter of do what I say, not do what I do.

I have spoken in this House on many occasions since the introduction of the fringe benefits tax. I am one of the few members who was here when that tax was introduced. I remember it very well. The tax shows the desperation of this Labor government to pick up income from any source whatsoever, but I think it is morally wrong for a tax on somebody's income or benefit to be imposed on the employer. I remember when it was first introduced. The fringe benefits tax was, in the first 24 hours of its notification, going to be a tax on the employee who received the benefit.

I can quite well remember the ACTU President at the time coming to the realisation that his car, his telephone and a lot of the other fringe benefits in his ACTU salary were going to be subject to the fringe benefits tax. The original contention lasted 24 hours, when the ACTU muscled in on the government to bring that liability back against the employer. I still believe it is a pernicious tax; it is morally wrong, and this bill does cover some further exemptions and some amendments in this regard. As I have said, fringe benefits tax really scrapes the bottom of tax morality; it scrapes the absolute depths.

As we look at the budget for this year, we see that there will be $1,430 million collected in fringe benefits taxation and $90,443 million collected in overall taxation. The budget is still bereft of $16 billion, and that has put us further into the red. I read the other day that, of all the nations in the world, Australia, with its small population of almost 17 million people, has the largest per capita debt. That is nothing to write home to anyone about and, again, in spite of the measures that are being taken, this is where Australia finds itself.

What concerns me in this bill, as it has in previous bills, is that the government is hitting the only economically performing sector of the community: business and individuals. In some cases, it is taxing them out of existence as they try to bear the costs of these taxes and increases. I mention just a few: the fringe benefits tax, the training levy, the superannuation guarantee charge, the increase in excise and fuel charges, the sales tax increase, health and safety regulations—and they are just a few. I remember that just 12 months ago I was looking at a report from a company. The secretary had put together nine foolscap pages, which were in fairly fine print, of regulations, interventions and intrusions of taxation by government departments that a normal company trading in Australia today, whether it is a private or public company, has to deal with. Most of them require a return to be lodged under penalty of having fines imposed if they are not.

Another thing that has happened in the years that I have been a member of the House of Representatives is the gradual intrusion by the government into the field of advanced payment of taxes—the prescribed payment system, the advanced payment of provisional tax, and the advanced payment of company tax itself. While I would be the first to say that in years past many people were able to take advantage of, and probably abuse, the system by paying tax so far in arrears, it is not an undesirable thing. But, at the moment, I suggest that Australians are taxed right up to the minute and are being taxed, in many cases, on what is going to happen next year. The company rate of tax is probably the greatest example of that. The payment of taxation 28 days in advance, as at the end of the year, is, I think, a major penalty on those companies that are out there trying to keep liquid despite increasing debts, increasing stocks, and trying to expand. Yet they are asked to pay, within 28 days, 85 per cent of next year's tax.

But I must say that there is some relief in this bill for those companies with tax liabilities of $1,000 or more, but less than $300,000; they can pay their tax in two instalments. Those companies get the benefit. The due date for the initial payment will be deferred by nine weeks from the 28th day of the month following the balance date, to the 28th day of the third month following the balance date. But it is still a major penalty for a company that is trying to survive in these difficult circumstances.

I remark about the criminality of the tax uplift factor for 1993-94, which has been set at eight per cent. Some might say, `Alleluia, it has dropped from 10 per cent'. But how can a taxation regime that is looking at an inflation rate of two or three per cent in this coming year, and the unofficial growth rate of 2.5 per cent, suggest that an eight per cent uplift factor should be applicable as far as the provisional tax is concerned? Again, it has been the case in previous years where that factor has always been higher than the inflation rate, and has always been higher than the combined inflation and growth rates. It is a miserable and desperate measure by a government to drain the last dollar out of the Australian taxpayer.

It is obvious that Australia is not a saving nation. It is obvious why we are not a saving nation. The reason is that, in many cases, before individuals get their hands on the income they have worked for and derived, the money is taken out of their hands. If the government wants a reason why there has been so much foreign investment in Australia in the past in normal facilities that should have remained in Australian hands, the answer is quite simple: Australians were not able to afford those investments because they did not have any savings of their own, and that is when foreign investment became very much the lifeblood of the Australian economy.

In the last election I was speaking with a particular small businessman—I spoke with many—and this small businessman was just letting me know the effect that all these regulations and taxes were having on his business. He had started with six employees; within six months, he had dropped that number to two employees. He and his wife had had one meal together in six months. They had worked the whole seven days a week continually since that time; that was the only way they could make ends meet. Of course, we were talking about the fringe benefits tax at that stage. As far as that small business is concerned, it recognised that, on expenditure, tax should be paid by the final consumer, whereas, as far as income is concerned, it is all pre-dedicated to the Taxation Office. Goodness only knows what the small businesses in Australia do to survive.

I want to talk about family taxation because I believe that is very important. Many of our companies and businesses are family based. The families associated with those businesses are the very fabric of our society, morally and economically. It is interesting to note what has happened to that sector. When I started accounting, back in the 1950s, the personal tax rate at the highest marginal rate was 11 times greater than the average weekly earnings. Fair enough, the taxation rate at that amount was equivalent to about 68c to 70c in the dollar. One only struck the highest marginal rate of tax when one was earning 11 times the average weekly earnings. In 1993, the highest rate of tax paid is applied at just under two times average weekly earnings. I think that is absolutely scandalous and, again, bears out the fact that there is no-one saving money these days because the tax office is getting the major proportion of it.

I was recently able to have the benefit of hearing a lecture by Mr Barry Maley to a group in Parliament House. He is a senior fellow at the Centre of Independent Studies. I want to read part of his speech because I think it is very important that we recognise who is bearing the burden of taxation in this country. He said:

SPEECH.PARA: In 1950, a single income, two-child family on average weekly earnings, after subtracting taxation and then adding in child and family allowances, received a net income six per cent higher than the original earnings. By 1990, that same family was receiving a net income 14 per cent lower than the original income. In 1950, singles paid twice as much tax as a married couple, two-child family with one income. By 1990 the effective tax rate was only 6 per cent more for singles.
He went on to say:
Generous treatment—
for those in the welfare industry—
is coming in large part from the pockets of families with dependent children; families which now need to send mothers out to work in order to maintain living standards.

I think that is a reflection on where our society has gone in the last 40-odd years. It is certainly not forwards, it is backwards. There are quite a few other things within this bill that I could comment on. One is the non-profit tourism industry bodies which are going to be given an exemption under section 23(h) as being non-profit bodies.

PARA.TAB: The greatest anomaly within the tax act at the moment is the manner in which unions—I mentioned the Public Sector Union and its one-day block-out—enjoy an exempt status under the taxation act. I think it is section 27 which says that the funds accumulated by employers and employees in unions are treated as non-profit, yet a tremendous amount of income is generated from those groups. I am not just talking about individual subscriptions, but interest from investments and the types of investments they go into. If this government was fair dinkum about trying to get the tax cheats, that would be one place to start. In doing so, perhaps it might look at the accountability to society that trade unions do not allow for their members. Yet we as a society—particularly companies—are asked by the government to do so many other things. There is a 10 times increase in volume as a result of a government that says it wants to stop tax evasion, but the only way to do that is with a goods and services tax. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —The discussion this afternoon on the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 3) and the Income Tax (Franking Deficit) Amendment Bill has been wide ranging and at times has moved somewhat from the detail of the bills before the House. Nevertheless, if we are to have a general debate about tax issues, it is worth while, first, to look at the provisions of the bill before the House and, secondly, to conduct some sort of overview of taxation arrangements in Australia generally. That is what the honourable member for Dawson (Mr Braithwaite) invited others to do.

PARA.TAB: Despite the comments that have come from opposition speakers, the bills are overwhelmingly positive for taxpayers. They recognise a number of criticisms that have been made recently, especially in relation to small business and in payment timing for company tax. There has been a call from the tourist industry in the past for exemption from taxation provisions for some non-governmental bodies and associations in the tourism industry. There are sales tax exemptions for the RSPCA and there are very important measures relating to dividend imputation and changes because of the previously legislated reductions in the company tax rate from 39 per cent to 33 per cent.

All these measures, and the ones the Parliamentary Secretary to the Treasurer (Mr Johns) referred to relating to the life insurance industry, are designed to give benefits to various sectors of the community in the provision of tax arrangements. Also—and very importantly—they ensure that the fairness and equity provisions applied to dividend imputation arrangements are maintained. Already in this debate we have heard about the level of taxation. It is worth noting that the cuts in the company tax rate from 39 per cent to 33 per cent were primarily designed to ensure that our company tax regime was competitive with that of our trading partners.

There were substantial outlays to introduce that change. It meant we were able to cut the company tax rate without the savage impost of a GST such as the one the opposition used to advocate before it was beaten in the 1993 election. Fundamentally, the cut in company tax was designed so that, as the economy improved, economic activity increased and, as we had further investment occurring, companies could be competitive and business could invest competitively in Australia compared with our trading partners. We know that we need a tax regime that is competitive, particularly with countries in our region; otherwise we will not get the level of investment we need to get economic activity accelerating at the proper pace. That is precisely what that change was designed to bring about. It was an important change. Despite all the toing-and-froing over the budget, the change has not had the attention it deserved. There has been a significant cut in the company tax rate.

We are now competitive. We have a tax regime which, as a whole series of studies has shown, is certainly competitive with our trading partners. It has not been mentioned today, but the suggestion has been made that the income tax changes were part of the budget process and have not been delivered. But the fact is that on 15 November we will get the cuts in personal income tax. The first stage of the income tax cuts comes in seven months early—not delayed, deferred or axed, as was suggested. The cuts will be introduced seven months earlier than intended and will have the direct effect of assisting people on average weekly earnings. They relate to incomes between $20,700 and $50,000—precisely the people in the middle-income bracket who have not been the beneficiaries of previous cuts in personal income tax.

It is worth noting that this government cut the personal income tax rate from the 60 per cent level under the previous Liberal government down to 47.5 per cent. It also brought in the lower tax scale rates. The rates of low income earners were also reduced as part of the government's tax reform arrangements. So income tax for the lower income end and the higher end of the spectrum have been reduced. The cuts that are part of this year's budget proposals have been delivered for the middle-income sector.

These bills will add substantially to the real impact the government has had in trying to encourage a competitive financial arrangement in Australia. One of the inequities that used to apply under tax arrangements was the double taxation arrangement. The landmark in dividend imputation removed that anomaly. When people talk today about levels of savings and so on, it is worth pointing to the fact that there is substantial interest in our share market today partly because of the very positive arrangements relating to share treatment and the dividend imputation arrangements which have really encouraged people to be investors in a productive share business.

The amendments contained in this legislation add a degree of certainty to some of the arrangements as a result of the cut in the company tax rate. The provisions outlined here set up a dual franking system in relation to dividend imputation. They adjust the required franking account provisions to take account of the two franking accounts and to ensure the available class A franking credits are used to frank dividends first. Further, they adjust the franking process and the franking rebate calculation to take account of the two franking accounts. They ensure the franking deficit tax can be properly calculated for the two franking accounts and the initial payment of tax can be offset against any aggregate franking deficit tax liability.

Further, they adjust the machinery provisions of the imputation system, including self-assessment, to take account of the two franking accounts and install a transitional provision to apply to dividends paid early by balancing of companies. Those arrangements clearly spell out the value of, first, the changes in the company tax arrangements and, secondly, the real benefit that will flow from dividend imputation being applied with this dual and flexible arrangement as outlined here.

They give the best possible outcome, given the transitional arrangements required with the cuts in company tax. All these measures are important in ensuring that the full value of dividend imputation is retained and that the benefits to the community are retained. Rather than have the sort of negative comment that we have had about the bills and about the tax arrangements generally, one would have thought the dividend imputation arrangements and the logical progression in these bills would have been welcomed by the opposition. People are demonstrating, by their attitude to investment, just how valuable those arrangements are.

I am very pleased to see that these arrangements that were part and parcel of Investing in the Nation in February are being implemented. We are giving positive effect to the change and maintaining the value of that change to companies and to investors to try to ensure the best possible outcome for the competitive tax environment and the dividend imputation rules.

I will briefly refer to the discussion that has been going on about sales tax exemptions for child-care services. I particularly welcome the initiative by the government to ensure exemption from sales tax, particularly for occasional child care. Many of us have had representations about that issue. I am very pleased to see the government has taken up the cause of those in the industry for sales tax exemption across the range of child-care services. It is certainly a valuable benefit. We all recognise the importance of child-care services—public or private—and the value they provide to many people in the community.

The measures in these bills, and the budget measures that have already been enacted, give strong effect to the government's pledges that were given on child care before the election. I certainly welcome the initiatives to extend the measures to occasional child care and to the range of family day care that are outlined, because I think they will be tremendously helpful to many of the centres that often struggle with limited budget arrangements and limited financial resources to make ends meet. I am grateful that the government has been able to take positive steps to deal effectively with the particular requirements and requests that have been raised by centres in my electorate.

I want to refer to the company tax changes that are contained in this bill. The bill gives effect to the announcement in the 1993-94 budget for relief for small business by deferring initial payments of company tax in respect of the 1993-94 income year. The companies affected are those with a tax liability of $1,000 or more but less than $300,000 and which pay their tax in two instalments. The due date for the initial payment will be deferred by nine weeks from the 28th day of the month following the balance date to the 28th day of the third month following the balance date. As for previous deferrals in the 1990-91 and 1991-92 income years, the amendments will ensure that franking deficit tax and franking credit tax and debits will be determined as if there had been no deferral in the initial tax payment.

This measure, which has an impact of about $10 million on the 1993-94 budget, is nevertheless one that will be of significant assistance to many smaller companies in the community. We recognise the importance of those smaller companies to Australia's economic recovery and the importance of their cash flow arrangements. The changes announced in the bill go a significant way towards meeting the requests and the representations that have come to us from the small business sector.

In relation to the provisions in the bill concerning the tourism industry, I think they are an important recognition that tourism—and its diversity—is one of the most important developing industries in Australia. In these measures we have said that we recognise that there will be a variety of groups that will develop skills, particularly in regional tourism promotion. As those bodies are developing markets for their particular parts of Australia, they should be given an opportunity to expand their promotional efforts. The exemption that is contained in this bill for income tax purposes will give them an additional incentive to develop those types of coordinating mechanisms and to use them effectively. Increasingly, from a variety of regions around Australia, we notice that there is a determination to see tourism more in a composite form—not, for instance, one local government authority doing its thing and another local government authority down the road trying to do its thing—and there is a need for them to marry their goals and their range of policies to try to promote and harness interest in their regions. This particular change is one element in which the government is showing its commitment to that industry and its diverse nature, and the need to have tax policies that do not run out of kilter with that broader growth industry that has developed so magnificently in Australia over the last decade.

It is important that we continue to keep an active interest in tax arrangements relating to an industry such as tourism. The government has used a variety of measures in recent times that have been beneficial to the industry—depreciation and investment allowance arrangements, and other things. It is a dynamic industry and there needs to be a continuing process of monitoring to ensure that the tax arrangements for the tourism industry are very competitive. We know that the tourism market around the world is extremely competitive. If we want to get the optimum value out of our tourism industry, at all times we need to see that its tax treatment matches the competitive environment. I am pleased to see that this bill is lending weight to that occurring.

I have already touched upon the very important changes relating to child care exemptions for sales tax purposes. The sales tax exemption for the RSPCA—which has already been touched on by previous speakers—is an important recognition of the organisation and its work throughout Australia. Like most honourable members, I have had representations on this issue over a significant period of time. It is pleasing to see that all of our collective representations have brought forth the fruit that everyone was desiring, and have ensured that the exemption is granted. The RSPCA is an organisation which has the highest regard of the community, and I would hope of the parliament. As such, I welcome the sales tax exemption that is contained in the bill.

Reference has been made already to the fact that other groups come along to us with strong cases in relation to sales tax exemption, and many of those groups are in schedules that currently have sales tax exemption. No doubt members of parliament on both sides will have cause to make representations in the future about other groups that have deserving cases. All that we can hope for is that we can produce the same sort of cogent case that has been produced here in respect of the RSPCA, and that it will meet the same positive recognition from the government and the then Treasurer. I feel confident that similar organisations will get appropriate treatment.

I turn to the issues relating to the life assurance industry. There has been quite an active campaign by the industry in relation to what it regards as some inequitable treatment of specific deductions for tax purposes, and the apportionment of deduction arrangements as far as some companies are concerned. These bills, as the parliamentary secretary has pointed out, go a long way towards meeting those concerns and establishing a fair regime for the treatment of superannuation funds. It is important that we continue to monitor the changes in that area, maintain a dialogue with the industry, and continue to ensure that the treatment of these different developing areas of tax reform is equitable. The amendments before the parliament help ensure that occurs.

The fringe benefits tax has been raised in the debate. It is important to note that the fringe benefits tax tried to ensure a return to equity as far as the treatment of taxpayers was concerned. Fundamentally, the fringe benefits tax recognises that people who are PAYE taxpayers, and have most of their tax liability calculated through that system, should not be treated any differently or in a more adverse way from someone who gets non-cash benefits, non-direct income benefits, in the form of fringe benefits. To suggest that we go back to the old days—I did not think it was opposition policy to go back to the old days of saying that the fringe benefits tax should not exist anymore, if that were the inference contained in the earlier remarks—would be a retrograde step. We need to ensure fair treatment of all taxpayers. Whether they derive their income as PAYE taxpayers or have other forms of income, as far as possible they should receive equal treatment.

We have removed things such as the double tax arrangements which used to apply in the pre-dividend imputation days, and that is a positive benefit. We have cut the company tax rate and we have cut income tax rates as well. Part of the strategy for dealing with that has been to ensure that people pay the level of tax that is commensurate with their income. That is what the fringe benefits tax has been about. Fundamentally, it is what the discussion over the years about capital tax has been about—ensuring that there has been fair and equitable treatment.

I suggest that the bills before the House in Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 3) are an important part of maintaining that equity. I would argue that our very positive changes as far as dividend imputation is concerned have been some of the most substantial tax reforms that this country has seen in decades. The fact that we are ensuring the consistency and coherence of those measures with the cuts in the company tax rates in this bill reflects our continuing commitment to dividend imputation and the value it brings to the Australian community and to Australian business.

I would have thought it could be well supported by the opposition rather than the negative comments we have had from it about tax arrangements in Australia. The pity of it was that it was not the opposition's initiative to bring in the dividend imputation arrangement. It came from this side and was a very positive thing. It should be welcomed by all of us. I have pleasure in supporting the bills before the House.

TALK.START.PARA: —As the previous speaker, the honourable member for Parramatta (Mr Elliott) has made very clear, there is a huge number of issues canvassed and presented to the parliament in the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 3). The Assistant Treasurer (Mr Gear) has added to his second reading speech by bringing forward some other amendments which, I gather, primarily relate to the wine industry. I am saying that with the presumption that they are included. Sometimes it is somewhat difficult to discover, but there certainly are further amendments to the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 3). I wish to address a few of these, particularly in the light of my responsibility as shadow minister for small business.

PARA.TAB: There are some words that have often been said about taxation and they are that it should abide by the rules of simplicity, certainty and equity. I am not yet convinced that the government is anywhere near achieving that. I frequently add another couple of words to that. One is visibility. I hold totally to the view that taxes should be seen. We are having a continuing drift to taxes that cannot be seen.

TALK.START.PARA: —Seen and not heard.

—That is the problem. The Minister for Social Security reminds me that they should be seen and not heard. It is when they are not heard that we also have difficulty. People should be constantly reminded of their taxes. For instance, we should be buying fuel, as we would in America, at so much plus tax. Where that is impractical in America, at places such as Disneyworld and other places, the authorities oblige the people by putting a very clear statement of the break-up of the $US35 or whatever the entry fee is. We see what is the actual fee and we see what state, provincial and federal government gets from that amount of money. There is a legal obligation on resellers to tell the consumer who is getting the money.

PARA.TAB: It is also very obvious when we go into small consumer stores. When we wish to purchase an article which is clearly marked on the shelf at $10 we find when we go to pay for it that the person at the cash register says it is $US11. We say, `Hang on a minute. It is marked at $10'. They say, `Yes, but the dollar is tax'. I have had people complain to me about that procedure. They get annoyed by it. I said, `Well, I hope you continue to be annoyed by it. I believe that it is by your annoyance that governments will be less avaricious in how much of your income they might receive'.

It is an interesting point that at a conference I attended recently a leading Australian businessman gave an example of the circumstances and the effect of taxation and all the other things that are applied, particularly today. We have a reference in this debate to fringe benefits tax. We have this new regime of benefits provided to a third party—the employee—being taxed in the hands of the employer. We have fringe benefits tax, the superannuation guarantee charge and of course other penalties such as payroll tax, et cetera.

This fellow got up and cited the case of an employee within his organisation who earned $40,000 a year. He then identified these numerous add-ons and pointed out that after the add-ons that employee's total cost to his organisation was $57,000 a year. Then came the tragedy of his advice when he told the meeting that that person would take home $28,000 a year. Here was a person on a salary of $40,000 a year—at a cost to the business, and therefore to the people who consumed these various assets or the items that he produces, of $57,000—but whose take-home pay was $28,000.

What we are talking about here in all these so-called amendments and changes is what is left for the worker. If we were to follow that worker around after he went home with his measly $28,000—when he was employed on $40,000 and at a cost to the employer of $57,000; $28,000 is less than half of that $57,000, and that is borne out by all the other statistics that show that the government takes 40-odd per cent of the national economy—we would find him taxed on just about everything that moved. He would pay tax on his new car, he would pay tax on his fuel and, what is more, he would pay tax on registering his mortgage. It is a real worry.

There seems to be a need for more visibility. The way petrol pricing fluctuates today by 10c or 15c a week makes that notification more important simply because the people have no idea who is getting the dollar or the cent this week. I think they are entitled to know.

Looking at some of the other aspects of the provisions that we have within this legislation, I note certainly with approval that the RSPCA is to have more certainty put into its circumstances and it is to be exempt from sales tax. One could think of no organisation that is more entitled to be exempt, and I would have thought that it had had it for a lot longer than this.

That draws my attention to the fact that, whilst this is going on and whilst this matter tightens up or changes in some way the fringe benefits tax regime, we find that another group, well established throughout Australia but particularly in New South Wales, called the business enterprise centres, has been told that it is going to lose its exempt status. BECs must be one of the more effective ways of assisting small business that I can think of. For a start, the business enterprise centres cost the federal government nothing. They get funding—50 per cent of their operating costs—from state governments on a dollar for dollar basis. The other 50 per cent is contributed by the community; that is the cash component.

Such service clubs as Rotary have taken a serious interest in this area and provided funding. But the greatest resource that the centres provide to small business is provided absolutely free. I am talking here about active and retired businessmen who voluntarily provide their services to these BECs for the purpose of advising prospective and established business people in the small business area to assist them to survive in what is a very difficult situation. One particular executive officer, informs me that he passes about half his clients—people coming to him to seek that initial advice—on to people who are experienced in the business and who work for nothing, about half of whom are unemployed people.

There is a huge new development in terms of the small business sector. These are people who have found themselves redundant from government enterprise, government services or large business enterprises, who have been paid quite substantial redundancy fees in many cases, and who seriously do not want to be unemployed and so take the small business option. They go and risk everything they have accumulated during their life of employment—their redundancy money and any superannuation payment, and they probably remortgage the house, which they had probably paid off—to get into a business. Hundreds, if not thousands of them are making very bad decisions because the advice is not available or it is available from people who, in my view, lack the experience that these business enterprise councils provide. They are not necessarily advised by successful businessmen.

Whether the Public Service likes it or not, it is a simple fact that if people go broke in business one of the places they go to get a job is to the small business section of some government department, where they are more than likely to be given a job. I guess someone who has gone broke at least can explain to people how it happened.

The simple fact is that the BECs are, in many cases, providing active businessmen or those who have retired in comfort and are willing to give of their time, and that is wonderful because it is good for them. These people are out there helping out. We have the Minister for Science and Small Business (Senator Schacht) running around presenting small business awards and getting his photograph in the paper. Yesterday, we had the Minister for Industry, Technology and Regional Development (Mr Griffiths) telling the MTIA that he is determined to find more capital for small business. I worked out that, if he found $25,000 for every small business—which, I can tell him, does not go very far in a small business—that would be $19 billion. But, while he is doing that, will he find capital for people who do not know how to run a business?

We have all these spectacular schemes but, more importantly, the amount of tax revenue the government will recover by removing the small tax advantage from BECs, which primarily allows a centre to buy a car for its executive officer free of sales tax, would not equal what the Minister for Science and Small Business is probably spending by flying around Australia at the moment handing out these small enterprise awards. I do not want to be seen as being critical of small enterprise awards, because I am not; we should use the opportunity to encourage those who succeed.

Another group wants to get into small business and there are those who are experiencing difficulty in small business. We have this very cost-effective scheme and the government is turning around and saying that they are not entitled to those sorts of tax benefits. The only people who receive remuneration are the executive officers and they clearly have to feed their families. Everybody else donates his or her time, and a large group of Australians are donating their money. Having decided that the RSPCA, a worthy organisation, is to be exempt, the government is going to impose the tax on previously exempt BECs. That is totally silly. It is not cost effective.

At the same time, the government is running around telling us what it is doing in the NEIS sector; in other words, giving financial support to the unemployed while they establish themselves in small business. What do those people need next? Good advice, and one could not get better advice than these groups give. I hope the government stops and thinks how foolish it is, particularly with regard to the cost to revenue.

TALK.START.PARA: —What is that?

—The business enterprise centres, the BECs, of which New South Wales has about 47. In fact, about 2,500 to 3,000 volunteers give this advice. These councils are well established. It is of considerable concern to them that they are losing this benefit, which I do not believe they would have been abusing in any way. However, they do need some help, and it is value for money. It is not a novel situation to Australia. Years ago, the Americans established a similar arrangement—I have forgotten the name they gave it—and it is very positive. And, of course, it is needed.

PARA.TAB: I note, with approval, that the government has again extended the time for small companies with a tax liability of between $1,000 and $300,000 to pay company tax. On behalf of small business, I thank the government for that consideration. There are some aspects of dividend imputation that are also mentioned in this particular area. Whilst what the government has done is to be recommended, to break it up so that the 39c rate can be passed on until the 33c rate applies is a matter of complexity, but I doubt whether there is a solution to it, so we just have to accept that.

I am interested—I will come back to this matter if I have time—in some of the references to life assurance companies. I note that we are still applying certain special rules to those companies through capital gains which are not available to the small business sector. Again, I would like the minister to give serious consideration to one of the best things that could be done for small business; that is, simply to pick up the opposition's policy on the rollover of capital gains. A top limit can be put on it—a lot of things can be done.

Today an energetic business family can, literally, buy a business, improve its value by 50 per cent, decide to sell it for the purpose of investing in a larger business and then go through that process again. By the time that family has paid capital gains tax, commission on the sale and stamp duty on the new business, it has less money than it started with. I just cannot believe that is the intention of a capital gains tax.

The simple fact is, even if the rollover is taken into account in the appropriate way, that family is got at in the end—presuming it sells for the last time to go into retirement. Why not give such a family a chance, while it is progressing through business development, of reinvesting its assets? If that family does not reinvest its assets and takes a holiday, then it is charged capital gains tax. But, if it reinvests in another business of a reasonably similar type, why should it be discouraged from doing that? Why should that family be locked into the original business because it actually shows a loss by selling out? All these things are involved.

There is more to selling out than just capital gains tax. There is the commission which is generally paid to an estate agent on selling the business. The state government is waiting with its hand out because it is tradition, again, that the purchaser always pays the stamp duty on a new purchase. I have done the sums and it is evident that such a family can be worse off than when it started, having put a lot of time, effort and long hours into building up a business and creating an asset. It just cannot get on.

The other area I want to refer to on behalf of small business is the decision to retain the current provisional tax uplift at eight per cent. The original idea of having an uplift factor on provisional tax was for the government or the Australian Taxation Office to deem that, if someone made $100 this year, he or she was likely, through the processes of inflation, to make $110 or $105 in the following year. We know that inflation is not eight per cent. We know that business generally has huge pressures on its profits and is not growing at anywhere near eight per cent. I do not know why, in the present environment, the uplift factor is retained at all but, more importantly, why it is retained at such a high level.

I know that eight per cent does not sound much but it is well beyond what most businesses would anticipate by way of increased profits unless there has been some investment in the business that is, undoubtedly, at a cost anyway. The simple fact is that the government should look to that. It was applied for a purpose. I do not think it was intended as a straight money grab. I do not think the government should go on deeming at these rates.

For years the government was stuck on the principle that an investment returned 10 per cent—we had this mythical 10 per cent and the government deemed 10 per cent for pensioners and it deemed 10 per cent for other people. Yet any businessman will tell you, Mr Deputy Speaker, that a return of 10 per cent on assets is dreamtime, in good times, not bad. It just does not happen; it is a myth generated amongst people who have never had the experience.

Although the government is saying that one could expect people with a tax liability to have a tax liability for the forthcoming year that is eight per cent higher, that is very unlikely. What does a person have to do to escape it? He has to go in and object to that assessment and then make a statement that there is no way in the world that the tax liability will increase by that amount. Such a person is then confronted with some aberration in business turning up; we do not know what that might be. If such a person does achieve those results, notwithstanding that he was totally honest in predicting it could not be done, he is suddenly a tax cheat and could be subject to substantial penalties and interest rates which are much higher than people can borrow money for today.

I again make the point that interest rates were lifted to 20 per cent. The old law had them at about five per cent when interest rates got up to 16 per cent. It was clearly quite silly. It did not pay people to pay their tax, and I do not support that. We have not seen interest rates withdrawn at sensible rates to reflect the contemporary situation. I believe it is time that they were. Of course, this particular piece of legislation does nothing for that—it entrenches the eight per cent uplift—and both the provisional tax and the uplift factor are very debilitating for small businesses which are having such difficulty. They go to borrow money. The reason they are not able to get it is not that the banks do not like them but that their bottom line does not in fact support a claim. (Time expired)
