PARA.TAB: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Mr Newell)—I suggest to the honourable member for Wide Bay that he bring his remarks straight to the bill and not waste his time.

TALK.START.PARA: —This bill deals with a wide range of tax issues, most of them unrelated. They demonstrate the vast extension of tax measures under Labor in government. In the 10 years of ALP government a huge range of new taxes has been invented. In fact, most of the taxes to be amended in these bills tonight did not even exist before Labor came to office. If Labor were half as creative in doing positive things to get our country moving again as it is in inventing new taxes, I am sure we would be a whole lot better off.

PARA.TAB: These taxes have placed an enormous burden on Australian industry: much of the administration associated with these measures is in fact borne by business. It is business that has to fill out all the new forms and employ extra people to administer the new tax regimes that have been introduced by Labor. Is it any wonder that, under Labor, bankruptcies have trebled? I noticed some new figures released by the minister this last month. For the September quarter, Queensland bankruptcies are up by 17.9 per cent. I guess we will start to break those records now in Queensland as we are the only state left—after Labor is defeated in South Australia—with a government that believes the best thing it can do for business is to invent new taxes. The Goss government has certainly not been left behind by other Labor governments around Australia in the way in which it has increasingly raised tax revenue.

Indeed, Labor seems to try to make a virtue out of the new taxes that it has invented. It frequently talks about broadening the tax base as though that is something good—providing new taxes for business to administer and providing new complexities and new difficulties for the Australian economy. When government members talk about tax cuts—they do that from time to time—it seems that, inevitably, following the tax cuts, they still raise more money. Despite all the tax cuts that Labor has given us over its decade in office, total tax revenue has increased by over 150 per cent—individual taxes are up 250 per cent; company tax is up over 300 per cent; sales tax is up over 300 per cent; and petrol excise is up 600 per cent. Of course, every other tax that it has invented has added to its tax revenue. So, instead of tax cuts, we have massive tax increases. Indeed, Labor has been the great taxer. The only economic commentators left who believe that higher taxes make a successful country are Labor members in government.

TALK.START.PARA: —A great tax on the economy in Australia.

—Indeed. They tax everyone, and everyone's patience as well. Many of the new taxes invented by Labor are amended by this bill: the fringe benefits tax, a tax paid by employers on the iniquitous principle that one person is expected to pay another person's tax; the capital gains tax, the tax that Labor promised us we would never have. Of course, everyone knows how empty Labor's taxation promises are these days, and hopefully people will never be allowed to forget the deceit and dishonesty in the 1993-94 budget when we got all the taxes Labor said we would never have. Sales tax has been simplified by this government but in a way that again has increased horrendously the burden on industry and resulted in major increases in revenue for the government; the revenue from the super funds tax has increased from $25 million to over $1.2 billion under this government; and the superannuation guarantee charge is a conceptual failure which is destroying people's confidence in superannuation and has done more damage than good in encouraging people to be self-reliant and to put aside for their retirement.

PARA.TAB: It is not just those taxes alone. Other taxes invented by Labor include the training guarantee levy, the prescribed payments system, the Medicare levy, the tertiary tax and now the wine tax. Is there to be no end? No, I do not think there is to be an end. We now have a Labor committee talking about a new jobs levy. Others in Labor are keen on death duties, wealth taxes and the like. So more and more taxes seem to be Labor's only solution to our nation's economic problems.

I want to refer specifically to a couple of items that are mentioned in this bill. As one or two previous speakers have said, some elements in a number of these measures are to be commended. I want to make some comments about the proposal in this legislation to provide sales tax exemption for the RSPCA. As other people have said, it is indeed commendable that the RSPCA is at last to be granted sales tax exemption.

TALK.START.PARA: —It would be better if there were no such tax at all.

—Obviously, as the honourable member for Dawson interjects, it would be better if there were no such thing as sales tax so that these measures would not be necessary. But Labor is determined to increase the burden of sales tax as a major revenue source. It is commendable that the RSPCA is to be exempted from this particular tax and, what is more, that it is to be backdated to 13 March 1993. This measure arises, I understand, from a High Court decision of the 1930s. The High Court, in its wisdom, decided that the RSPCA was a charity and should be free from paying income tax but, as it was not a benevolent society because it did not help human beings, it was necessary for it to pay sales tax. The RSPCA has been pressing the various governments that have come and gone for relief from sales tax since that time. At last, that measure is to be brought to fruition. So I welcome the measure.

PARA.TAB: I have had something to do with the RSPCA in my electorate. I was closely associated with the development of a RSPCA facility in Kingaroy in my electorate. Indeed, I am proud to say it is built in Warren Truss Drive—a very wise selection of a venue. The RSPCA in Kingaroy certainly provides an outstanding service to the community. So this particular measure is welcome.

However, there is also an enormous degree of unfairness about this provision. The tax exemption is available to the RSPCA but not to the scores of other organisations which perform the same kinds of services. In many parts of Australia, animal care—looking after animals which are lost or need to be cared for or destroyed—is not undertaken by the RSPCA but by similar organisations with similar aims, objectives and structures. They will be excluded from this new benefit being provided. That should not come as a shock to the government. In fact, soon after the announcement was made, the Minister for Finance (Mr Willis) received a letter, which drew attention to these inequities, from the Lost Dogs Home in his electorate. I quote briefly from that letter. Mr Graeme Smith, the General Manager of the Lost Dogs Home, stated that the exemption to the RSPCA:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . is certainly a long overdue recognition of the community service aspect of animal welfare work. As such, it is very commendable.

Unfortunately the proposed measure is also inequitable and unfair. As the largest companion animal shelter in Victoria, The Lost Dogs' Home is doing exactly the same sort of rescue and shelter work as the RSPCA. Yet we must continue to pay Sales Tax. Moreover, this compounds an already unjust situation wherein public donations to the Home are not tax deductible, whilst donations to the RSPCA are.

Let me give you a dramatic illustration of this unfairness. Since 1991 The RSPCA Victoria and The Lost Dogs' Home have co-operated in animal rescue work. The RSPCA covers areas south of the Yarra, The Lost Dogs' Home covers areas north. However the RSPCA will pay approximately $4000 less for its ambulance in future because of the sales tax exemption.

A similar position exists in my own electorate. I have already referred to the Kingaroy RSPCA animal refuge. It will get the benefit of this sales tax exemption, and that is welcome. But the Maryborough animal refuge at the other end of my electorate, which is operated by a community committee, will not get that benefit. If a dog is collected in Kingaroy it will be collected in a tax free vehicle; if it is collected in Maryborough sales tax will have been paid on the vehicle.

PARA.TAB: The food for cats in the RSPCA in Kingaroy will be exempt from the 21 per cent sales tax, which was increased in the last budget. The cats fed in Maryborough will be fed on fully taxed food. The soap used for washing animals in the Kingaroy RSPCA will be sales tax free, but the Maryborough animal refuge will have to pay the full 21 per cent tax on those requisites.

Veterinary supplies bought in Kingaroy will be sales tax free, but in Maryborough those goods will be taxed. I have not examined it in a great deal of detail, but presumably when euthanasia is performed in Kingaroy it will be with a tax free drug, but in Maryborough taxes will have to be paid on these veterinary supplies. So here is Labor's death tax again; this time a death tax on animals—so long as they are not euthanised by the RSPCA. In Melbourne the situation is even more starkly obvious. Animals collected on one side of the river will be fed on food subject to sales tax; those collected on the other side of the river will not.

I listened to the honourable member for Parramatta (Mr Elliott) and some others who referred to the obvious inequities in this case. The honourable member for Parramatta expressed the hope that other organisations would also be considered for this exemption in the future. He is a member of the government; this is his opportunity. The government, instead of just exempting the RSPCA, should exempt all of those organisations that are providing this very worthwhile service in the community.

I hope that when this bill gets to the Senate, when it is subjected to detailed scrutiny, that there will be some amendments or some requests to this House to ensure that there is justice and equity, that all animals are treated the same and that all organisations providing this kind of service are given the same kind of tax exemption. Perhaps government members opposite will do more than hope that the government will take this matter on board; I hope that they will act to ensure that appropriate amendments are made so that this very worthwhile concession is extended to all organisations providing care and relief for animals in our community.

Whilst dealing with the question of sales tax, I would like to refer to another sales tax anomaly that the government has promised to address on a number of occasions, but which again it has failed to take up in this bill. I refer to the sales tax anomaly that exists in relation to second-hand farm machinery.

TALK.START.PARA: —An absurd anomaly.

—An absurd anomaly, and indeed the Assistant Treasurer (Mr Gear) has acknowledged that it is an anomaly. Currently farm machinery dealers have to pay sales tax on spare parts used to recondition second-hand equipment for future sales to primary producers, despite the fact they are exempt from sales tax. This sales tax, which amounts to about $10 million per year, is not refunded and as a result is recovered from farmers when they buy second-hand machinery from dealers. This has been raised with the Assistant Treasurer on a number of occasions, and he has written to a number of members of parliament acknowledging that the anomaly exists and—what is more important—promising to review this matter when sales tax matters are next under consideration.

PARA.TAB: Sales tax matters are under consideration tonight, but this amendment has not been made. There were sales tax amendments considered earlier in this budget session, and again the government failed to act. I call on the Assistant Treasurer to be true to his word, to review this acknowledged anomaly and to make the necessary amendments to ensure that second-hand machinery is indeed exempt from sales tax.

I suspect the reality is that the government wants the money. Because it is the farm sector—the sector mercilessly persecuted by this government over such a long period of time—the government thinks it does not matter if another $10 million is being unjustly collected from the rural sector. Surely one day there has to be some honesty, some honour from this government. If ever there is a time when the rural sector needs this kind of consideration, it is surely now. Farmers are simply unable to afford to buy new machinery; they are forced to buy second-hand, reconditioned equipment. This government has so increased the tax burden on the rural sector, so reduced farmers' incomes, so destroyed farmers' capacity to survive the recession and the international economic situation, that farmers cannot afford to pay these additional tax burdens.

The 1993-94 budget further increased the tax burden on the rural sector. There have been several sales tax increases which farmers have had to pay, including the sales tax increase on second-hand farm machinery. The Assistant Treasurer should be honest and true to his word and review this iniquitous measure. I welcome the arrival of the Assistant Treasurer into the House. I hope in time he will announce that he will honour his written promise to so many people and review this iniquitous tax. Not only has he failed in that promise, but in the last budget he actually increased the amount of sales tax to be paid and is promising future increases in sales tax as the years go by.

We also have the iniquitous fuel tax increases which farmers will have to bear as a result of this budget. We are told that all of this is to fund income tax cuts which very few, if any, farmers will actually receive because they have to be earning a positive income, and a reasonably high income, before they will qualify for those tax cuts. So there will be a massive increase in farm costs as a result of the tax measures being introduced by this government, and farmers will not benefit from the compensation measures that are proposed.

There is this famous $150 tax rebate, but that is useless unless someone is actually paying tax. We do not get a tax rebate if we are not paying income tax. As the government ought to know, and as the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Mr Crean) ought to have told the Assistant Treasurer and others with economic portfolios in the government when they were drafting the budget, according to ABARE figures—the government's own figures—most farmers will be earning negative incomes this year for the second year in a row and, for many people, for several years in a row. Because they have negative incomes they will not qualify for this miserable $150 tax rebate. I might add that a $150 tax rebate would not in any way cover the increases in fuel tax and sales taxes which have been imposed in the same budget.

TALK.START.PARA: —They couldn't afford to drink wine.

—They certainly could not afford to drink wine. Indeed, those poor winegrowers in our community are to be slugged with additional taxes. I understand that some of the measures associated with that tax are also to be introduced as late amendments to this bill. This is typical of the way in which the government has mercilessly exercised the guillotine during the budget debates. Bills are brought in and it is found, even before they reach the debating stage, that the government has to make a score of amendments. Is it any wonder that the poor taxpayers have been confused?

PARA.TAB: Census statistics have revealed something that really ought to drive home a very stern message to all Australians. The poorest federal electorates in Australia are all in regional and provincial areas. The electorates with the largest number of people earning below $16,000 and the least number of people earning above $60,000, are all located in rural and provincial areas. For a Labor government that talks about equity and social justice, what measures is it putting in place to help the most disadvantaged sector in the community—those living in rural and regional areas?

Let us look at what measures the government is proposing. There are increased fuel taxes, which are borne more harshly by those people in rural areas than in other parts of Australia. The government is proposing increased sales taxes and they will be borne by many people in business and industry to further restrict their capacity to survive Labor's recession. The government is imposing a wide range of new, harsh tests to ensure that many people in rural areas will not qualify for family payments and the like that have been available in the past. So these tax measures proposed tonight make some very small concessions. What benefits are there are welcome, but they make no real contribution to cutting back Labor's enormous taxation regime and doing something worthwhile to help Australians genuinely in need.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank all honourable members for their contribution to this debate on the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 3) and the Income Tax (Franking Deficit) Amendment Bill. In this case, it is totally unreasonable for people to think that they could get deductions for investment where the product of that investment means that the income is not assessable in Australia. For that reason we will not accept an amendment that confers on some taxpayers an advantage which it does not confer on others.

SPEECH.PARA: The government proposes to amend the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 3) to provide deductions for the capital cost of establishing grapevines. Under existing income tax law, winegrowers are able to depreciate certain costs of establishing a vineyard. For instance, plant depreciation deductions are available for the cost of trellising and irrigation. However, the cost of acquiring and planting the grapevines themselves is not deductible or depreciable.

PARA.TAB: The government has decided to allow expenditure incurred on or after 1 July 1993 on establishing grapevines in Australia to be evenly written off over four years. The deductions will be available from the time the vines are planted. Costs currently eligible for depreciation deductions will continue to be deductible under those provisions. The cost of the amendments is estimated to be $1.5 million in 1994-95, $3 million in 1995-96 and $4.5 million in 1996-97. This measure will provide a significant benefit to grape growers and will facilitate the planting of new vines able to produce higher quality wine. It provides a considerably more generous deduction regime than that applying in other countries, such as New Zealand and the United States of America.

Another amendment of the bill will make a minor technical change to the Sales Tax Assessment Act 1992 to clarify the extent to which penalties can apply to acts or omissions that happen after the introduction of amendments of the sales tax law but before they receive royal assent. The need for the amendment arises from suggestions that taxpayers are under no obligation to pay any sales tax until 28 days after the government's budget sales tax bills receive royal assent. The government is concerned that taxpayers might be confused by these suggestions and fail to make payments of tax that are legally due for payment. The sales tax law imposes penalties for late payment of tax.

The amendment will insert a clearer expression of the effect of the existing law, so that taxpayers will be in no doubt that the passage of amending laws will not relieve a person from a continuing liability under the law. Press reports which suggested that as much as $1 billion may have been at risk if the government had not made this amendment were greatly exaggerated. The purported weakness in the law raises only a question of the timing of certain payments, so that the cost to the government even of the claimed interpretation would have been small. As it is, the amendment preserves what the government believes to be the existing law. Accordingly, there is no impact on the revenue from this amendment.

The Prime Minister (Mr Keating) announced in the Investing in the Nation statement changes to the sales tax laws to give exemption to certain child-care services. This is one of a number of measures designed to make the cost of child care less of a burden, particularly to working mothers. These amendments to the bill will give effect to that announcement. Broadly speaking, an exemption from sales tax will be given to goods for a range of child-care services. These services comprise long day care, outside school hours care, vacation care, occasional care and family day care coordination. Employer sponsored child-care services located on premises owned or leased by the employer will not be entitled to exemption. The exemption applies from the date of royal assent.

Exemption will apply to services which are eligible for Commonwealth, state or territory child-care funding or services which are approved by the Minister for Family Services. The cost of the amendments is estimated to be $10 million per year. I present the supplementary explanatory memorandum which contains more detailed explanations of the amendments, and commend the amendments to the chamber.

TALK.START.PARA: —There are some 10 minutes before the House will break for dinner, and I have some comments to make. I am sorry, in a sense, that they will be truncated but, given that we are under the guillotine, I cannot afford to let any moment lapse through inconvenience. We have only one hour to discuss this important bill—the Migration Laws Amendment Bill 1993.

PARA.TAB: I want to make some points that are very germane to the guillotine and this bill. This bill is to defer the commencement of certain provisions in the Migration Reform Act 1992. I do not recall whether there was a guillotine when the relevant bill was dealt with in this House on 11 November 1992, but I suspect that, given the time of year—even though it was Remembrance Day—it was undoubtedly under duress that we were pressing on with the matter. The bill received ready cooperation from Her Majesty's loyal opposition to ensure its passage.

I did not offer my comments without some criticism of the government. I refresh my memory by looking at the speech I gave on that occasion. It was against a background of crisis that the then Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs, Mr Hand, introduced a bill which was seen as being of enormous importance to the government of the day. The bill was to put in place provisions to enable us to address that crisis. Nothing that has happened in the meantime has convinced me that those comments were misplaced then or that the situation is substantially different now.

If the bill to address that crisis was urgent then, in my view, the act and its implementation are urgent now. I will deal with the crisis now and after the dinner suspension I will deal with the bill. The crisis that was of concern to me, and I think very much in the minister's mind, related to the government's failure over time to address the problem of asylum. We are now facing the problem of a large number of asylum seekers in Australia. I pointed out at that time that 21,700 asylum seekers were seeking sanctuary and pressing claims. Some 500 people at that time had arrived in small boats and were seeking asylum. Many of them were in detention at Port Hedland and some were in Sydney. A number of people arrived by aircraft and were similarly detained.

I mentioned that around 20,000 Chinese students, and additional spouses and dependants who had been allowed to come to Australia since that time, were here at the time of the Tiananmen Square massacre. They had been granted a special status which was going to have to be resolved at a future date. A great number of people were seeking to press refugee claims or, in other circumstances, seeking special status. Our previous experience had been of much smaller numbers. They were straining our capacity to handle properly the claims for refugee status. Before this crisis we had dealt with some 500 applications a year. Considering that, the enormity of the problem becomes apparent.

At the time this legislation was introduced, the crisis had been with us for almost three years. People have complained about detention. A large number of people have been held in detention and many remain there today. That situation had been with us for three years when we discussed this matter in November last year. Australia is in a unique position to deal with refugee status. We have water boundaries which have protected us from the sorts of claims often made in North America generally. We have not had the same problems as Europe where people have land boundaries. They do not have our insulation. We have a system of universal visa entry which, we have been told, provides us with an enormous capacity to test people's bona fides before they come here. That has given Australia a capacity to test people's eligibility in a way few other countries can.

Why is it, when we have these innate advantages, that we are faced with the same sorts of dilemmas as elsewhere in the world? The reasons are very simple. They turn upon the capacity of this government to make decisions in this area. Some of the most senior ministers of the government are culpable in this matter. First and foremost, the reason we are facing difficulties is the large number of Chinese students who were allowed into Australia before the Tiananmen Square massacre. Decisions were taken by the Treasurer (Mr Dawkins), who was then the Minister for Employment, Education and Training. We knew that the relaxed basis upon which people were permitted to enter Australia had given us a large number of people already overstaying their student entry visas.

About 40 per cent, according to Senator Robert Ray—this was confirmed to the Joint Standing Committee on Migration Regulations—of the PRC students in Australia in May 1989 were already overstaying visas. The then Minister for Employment, Education and Training had given us a significant problem by allowing a large number of people here who were not going to honour their conditions of visa entry. Former Prime Minister Hawke compounded that problem—notwithstanding advice from his colleagues, particularly the honourable member for Melbourne Ports (Mr Holding), who had drawn attention to this matter—when he allowed all the Chinese students here in Australia at the time of the Tiananmen Square massacre to remain on a basis on which no entrants from any other part of the world would be allowed.

Is it any wonder that we then faced an avalanche of students seeking to enter Australia and wanting to make the same claims? The only basis upon which they thought they could make claims was refugee status. This was a problem of the government's making and remains so. After the dinner suspension, I will take honourable members through this bill and what the government is seeking to do in delaying the implementation of the Migration Reform Act that was intended to address this crisis. We will look at why legislation designed to cope with this problem is being postponed for another 11 months and ask some very simple questions about the competence of those who are dealing with this matter.

This legislation introduced into this parliament was so seriously flawed, in the government's view, that it cannot be implemented immediately and the program that was outlined as urgent and pressing cannot be implemented. I will go through the arguments in relation to that because it is important to understand that, while we are giving the government the utmost cooperation in addressing this very pressing problem, the government is on notice that, if it is going to continue to handle these matters as inadequately as it has, it cannot expect cooperation in further legislative changes. I will also press strongly for the administration of immigration arrangements to be the subject of wider review. We ought to get to the bottom of why legislation as important as the Migration Reform Bill, as it was—now the Migration Reform Act—could not be implemented as was originally planned. There is some culpability on the government for why that has not been possible.

TALK.START.PARA: —Before the dinner break we were discussing the Migration Laws Amendment Bill 1993, and I was alluding to the crisis that we have in relation to the issue of refugee determination. The point I was making—and I would emphasise again—is that it was all the government's own work, and it was the work of those who are at the most senior level. It was at the level of the former Prime Minister, and the former education minister, but now Treasurer, that these errors of judgment were made. The piece de resistance is that those who were not bona fide were admitted under what Senator Ray euphemistically referred to as `pipeline processing measures, less stringent than the global measures that applied to other PRC applicants'.

PARA.TAB: Every time governments in this country have departed from non-discriminatory criteria to advantage any one particular group, enormous problems have arisen. At that time I moved an amendment, and I would like to remind the House of its nature because it put at issue a number of factors. The amendment was to this effect:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . the House:

(1) deplores the Government's failure to control the refugee determination process, commencing with former Prime Minister Hawke's decision on the People's Republic of China Nationals in Australia at the time of the Tiananmen Square massacre;
(2) notes the lamentable time delays in moving to reform the refugee determination system; and

(3) regrets that the further proposals put by the Coalition to limit judicial appeals, to require leave to access review procedures and to redeploy staff to the refugee screening process have been ignored".

That amendment was moved deliberately because the situation was one of crisis. The government's response was to introduce a bill to reform the Migration Act—re-called the Migration Reform Bill 1992. It is perhaps timely to refresh our memories about this bill, and we can do so from the explanatory memorandum. It states that the bill will:
. . . effect major changes to the Migration Act.
It was further said:
The reform Bill continues the process of modernising Australia's immigration law.

The explanatory memorandum mentioned the major amendments of 1989, following on what was called the Cape report, to allow the government to more effectively control the composition of overall numbers in Australia's immigration program. It went on to talk about subsequent amendments and streamlining that occurred under the former minister. It said:
The major themes behind the changes to be made by the Reform Bill are simplicity, clarity, certainty and fairness.
It went on to say:

The changes will replace the legislative framework which currently underpins the regulation of entry to and stay in Australia as well as detention and removal of non-citizens here unlawfully. It will provide a new and greatly extended basis for merits review of. . . decisions and, for the first time, provide independent determinative merits review of refugee-related decisions.

Then we go through and look at a framework of law designed to implement new arrangements to ensure that our immigration control was effective. It had provisions dealing with entering and remaining lawfully in Australia, and to simplify travel and entry arrangements. It was to provide a single form of authority to be called a visa, to travel, enter, and remain in Australia.

PARA.TAB: It took a series of decisions, and each of them was important. It required all persons to undergo immigration clearance on arrival. It included requirements that Australian citizens present an Australian passport or pay an administrative fee to use another passport on arrival from overseas. It put the onus on all non-citizens to prove that they were lawfully in Australia. It created a special category of visa to accommodate those from whom it was impractical to require a conventional visa prior to travel. It put limitations on further applications from non-citizens, apart from a small number of prescribed visa classes.

There was a visa tax on illegal entrants who had been in Australia unlawfully for over 12 months. It provided arrangements for pre-cleared flights to cater for immigration checks prior to boarding direct flights to Australia. It had major changes to detention arrangements, and the removal of non-citizens including the requirement to detain unlawful non-citizens; the creation of a bridging visa to ensure that any release from immigration detention was controlled by certain conditions; a uniform detention regime for all unlawful non-citizens; and a liability for non-citizens unlawfully in Australia for costs of detention, removal and deportation.

It further had restrictions on availability of judicial review by narrowing the scope for migration decisions to be appealed under the Administrative Decisions (Judicial Review) Act 1977. It had codification of procedures to be followed by primary and review decision-makers. There was the introduction of an objects clause to state that the object of the act was to regulate entry to Australia and set out the conditions under which stay was permitted. It had the validation of certain third party opinions, and a new criminal justice visitors scheme to ensure that people who committed crimes in Australia were brought to justice. It was seen as a major reform measure by this government, putting in place procedures to deal with the proper detention of unlawful non-citizens. It was seen as being the very fundamental reform that this government could have achieved, and was pressed urgently for implementation last November. It was the subject of a guillotine so that there could be limited debate, as we experience tonight.

So here we are, faced with a bill that defers the commencement of the provisions contained in this major reform act. Interestingly, when we go through the second reading speech which justifies this deferral—and I will come to some issues of detail in relation to the deferral in a little while—we find that the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Mr Crean) had this to say:

SPEECH.PARA: It is clear that the reform act requires finetuning, and this is to be expected in legislation of this nature. At this stage, a number of minor amendments have been identified, predominantly of a technical nature, which still need to be made to legislation to ensure that it operates smoothly.

The minister tells us that what is involved is finetuning. This House deals with finetuning of legislation every day. Normally it is slipped into some amendment bill which is passed through with a whole lot of other, very often unrelated legislation, without objection.

PARA.TAB: I do not know what the government has in mind here in terms of what it sees as being the defects that require the legislation to be put off for something of the order of eight to nine months—defects that are of such an order that, except for the implementation of the provisions dealing with the establishment of the refugee tribunal and some amendments to ensure that it is able to operate, do not pick up any of the other major reforms. What does that say about the nature of the legislation?

I and my colleagues do try to help the government in relation to its legislative program. We have been very cooperative, and we wanted to be cooperative in relation to this legislation. We agreed to the government's original reform measures. We saw them as being important. We thought they were worthy of support last year. We would like to see the government implement as much as possible of that legislation. We would like to see implemented forthwith, for instance, the provisions dealing with restricting the availability of a judicial review by narrowing the scope of migration decisions to be appealed under the AD(JR) Act. Why? Because we know that one of the major problems that the government has is in relation to the extent to which the courts—and more matters are litigated in relation to immigration than to almost anything else—are involved in redefining and expanding the

SPEECH.PARA: basis upon which people might be able to remain here in Australia.

PARA.TAB: What we want to do is ensure in relation to refugee determination that the international agreements that we have signed are complied with and that we have in place an administrative regime for determining refugee status—not one of these broad schemes where people are given the right, first, to an administrative decision; then to an appeal from an administrative decision; then, if they do not like the administrative decision, to go off under the AD(JR) Act to get a judge to have a look at it; then, if they do not like that decision, to move off and have the full court look at it; and then, if they are unhappy about that decision, to trot off to the High Court for it to have a look at it.

What we said is, `Look, we think you, the government, ought to remove the possibility of appeal under the AD(JR) Act and put in place the sort of regime that we had for determining refugee status, which was efficient, was fast and was never the subject of any complaint by the UNHCR. You would have a far better, more efficacious system and the delays that you are experiencing and the detention that some people are experiencing of an unconscionable nature could be avoided'. That is what we put very strongly.

But what did the government say to us? `Look, we have left this all too late: 1 November is the operative date. These provisions would operate by 1 November and we really could not even implement our scheme'—that is, the government's scheme, which we, the opposition, think is second best—`that is, simply restricting the availability of judicial review by narrowing the scope of some of the more technical issues that might be raised by parties for a judicial decision'.

I must say I find it extraordinary that legislation as fundamental as this legislation was, that needed our urgent cooperation to ensure its passage, can be the subject of a bill in which it is argued that there are only matters of finetuning outstanding but which require the implementation of the legislation to be put off for another eight to nine months.

I want to pick up this judicial review argument. I noticed in a recent reported case of Roser v Immigration Review Tribunal of 28 September 1992 that Mr Roser was a gentleman who had exhausted all of the remedies available to him through the department and through the Immigration Review Tribunal. He trotted off to get his decision examined by the court. I found what the court had to say very interesting because I think it highlights the problem that we experience in the immigration area. The court said:

SPEECH.PARA: It is apparent that Mr Roser is using the entry permit system of applications and the review and appellate hierarchical structure of the Tribunal and the court to prolong his stay in Australia; that is his predominant purpose and that is an abuse of the process of this court.
The court went on to say that what he was involved in:
. . . was no more than a regurgitation of the material that had been placed before the Tribunal on the first application and found to be wanting.

I would not want to pick up particular cases other than that one in which a court has commented, but I just suspect that when we do get involved in litigation in this area, where the outcome that people are often seeking is merely to prolong their stay in Australia, the situation in which there can be abuse of process is perhaps very much more often the case than we would like to believe. It is a matter of some trouble to me that the government sees fit with this new tribunal to leave in place this attenuated appeal process.

PARA.TAB: In conclusion, I want to make a number of other points. I think that the way in which this matter has been handled has involved very considerable legislative and administrative incompetence on the government's part. I do not want to get too involved again in canvassing matters that I did in the estimates debates but I did draw attention to the matter that my colleague Senator Short and his representative in relation to this debate have foreshadowed in the other place, that is, the possibility of setting up a Senate committee of inquiry into the government's handling of immigration into this country, particularly the departmental arrangements and all of the internal difficulties that have arisen.

It is certainly clear to me that some of the people who have been involved in projecting legislative reform, and have certainly highlighted the urgency in the past for changes in this area, are no longer involved in the pursuit of the legislative program on behalf of the government. Changes at very senior levels took place after the election. It is not clear from the estimates debates what was the rationale for all of those decisions or the reasons why people were dealt with as they were.

I mentioned previously the situation of one officer about whom certain allegations were made, who was cleared as a result of the investigations that were undertaken in relation to the complaints, and who has not been reinstated into the position that he previously occupied. Those matters have given my colleagues reason for concern and they give me reason for concern.

TALK.START.PARA: —It has nothing to do with the bill.

—It has a lot to do with the bill; the Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Housing, Local Government and Community Services and Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Health would know that the very basis upon which we are being asked to postpone legislation, which was seen as a major reform, is that we are told the bill now requires some finetuning. It just belies comprehension to imagine that something that merely requires finetuning has to be put off for eight months when the major reform proposal, which goes to the very issue of detaining people in custody—and that was one of the matters that was raised—is at risk.

PARA.TAB: When there is the potential as there is in this area, for judicial challenge, I am astounded that the government sees the preferable course as being to postpone the implementation entirely while, in the words of the minister, merely finetuning is to be expected and that a number of minor amendments have been identified, predominantly of a technical nature. The only other matter that was advanced in relation to this matter was that the implementation of these complex and important changes needs to be smooth and trouble free. The government said, `We need to train our officers in relation to these matters'. My experience in relation to training of officers is that we do not need eight months to do it and I would be very surprised if, in relation to the Migration Reform Act, that is being done now for what is going to be implemented next September. We will not oppose this legislation but it is seriously questioned. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —The honourable member for Dundas (Mr Ruddock) in his speech said that this country had a great advantage because of the fact that it is an island. I want to refer to a few quotes to put this line of argument in context.

PARA.TAB: Australia might be an island but the reality is that a significant part of the problem the honourable member spoke about has nothing to do with the proportion of people coming here by boat. Australia is not separate from an international phenomenon. I refer to an article entitled `Refugees and Displaced Persons' in JAMA magazine of 4 August 1993. The authors, Michael Toole and Ronald Waldman, said:

In 1990, we described the high mortality associated with mass population displacements in developing countries and proposed preventive strategies. Since then, the number of refugees and internally displaced persons has grown by 40% from approximately 30 million to 43 million.

SPEECH.PARA: Does the United States have the ready solutions that we have so apparently missed? I do not really think so. In the Clinton budget, $172.5 million has been allocated to America's refugee and asylum problems. Dirk Kirschten, in an article in the National Journal of 7 August 1993, made the following point:
Of an estimated 200,000-300,000 migrants who enter the country illegally each year—
that is the illegals, let alone the huge numbers of legal entrants—
only 13,000-15,000 claim asylum after being intercepted at international airports or rounded up . . .
He spoke of:
. . . a massive backlog of nearly 300,000 unadjudicated asylum claims filed by immigrants who have managed to enter the country—both legally and illegally . . .

So, once again, we might say that we do not have the phenomenon of a border with Mexico or close proximity to Central America but the problem still has to be seen in the international context of population movement, the availability of transportation and the international problems that people are seeking to escape. Hans-Georg Betz, in an article entitled `The New Politics of Resentment' in the Comparative Politics magazine of July 1993, looked at the situation in Europe and he said:

. . . there is growing concern about the dramatic increase in the number of refugees and illegal immigrants looking for a better life in western Europe. During the 1980s, the number of political refugees in western Europe grew from some 75,000 in 1983 to almost 320,000 in 1989. Since 1989, these numbers have dramatically increased. Switzerland alone counted 41,000 refugees in 1991, and Germany more than 250,000.

It belies international reality to come here this evening and say that all is hunky-dory and that, if it were not for an incompetent government, Australia would not really have any problems. It is worth saying that, whilst there is some truth in the comments by the honourable member for Dundas about the introduction of the sale of education overseas, we need to be more realistic about the present position. We no longer have 21,000 claimants. Despite the issue of 35,000 student visas last year, there has been a considerable drop in the number of student overstayers. It is no longer the case that that proportion of visa entrants who are overstaying is abnormally high.

PARA.TAB: The honourable member for Dundas repeated a lot of the comments he made in a speech on 11 November 1992. He referred to the Tiananmen Square entrants and the problems of the overstayers amongst students. The clear change of policy, the clear emphasis on a greater degree of pre-visa testing and the greater controls indicated in this field have accomplished a lot of what this government sought.

The honourable member for Dundas spoke about all the warnings members of the opposition gave us and said that they were really on top of the whole policy area. However, I was interested to read comments by the honourable member for Goldstein (Dr Kemp). Admittedly, those comments were not strictly on the migration aspect of this education policy but on the policing of the industry. He described the legislation as `catastrophic and appallingly drafted'. He stated:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . the bill restricts institutions from marketing courses overseas.
He further stated:

I have had countless recommendations about the damage that the trust account mechanism will create for the education export industry, particularly for the private providers. It will create severe cash flow problems for these institutions.
Written notice must be given to overseas students as to what amounts will be considered non-refundable.

In general, in a series of speeches on 15 November 1990 and 20 June 1991, he was at pains to deplore any action by this government to put restrictions on the players in this industry to require a degree of policing by these institutions.

PARA.TAB: The honourable member was very concerned that anything would be done to undermine the saleability of education in Asia. He referred to the lengthy statement of the Industry Commission, which he said, `fully vindicated criticism made by the opposition'. The Industry Commission urged `further deregulation in the freeing-up of this market in order to provide these institutions with a maximum capacity to take advantage of what is a very large international market in this area for education services'. In other words, the whole emphasis of the opposition was not on the fact that our migration situation might be imperilled, but more on its grave concerns that we might restrict a few people from getting a buck.

Last week we saw legislation introduced to further tighten up in this field. Despite the fact that the opposition was so expert, it knew everything, it was interesting to note last week that, despite measures that the opposition deplored back in 1990-91, such as the introduction of trust accounts and a variety of other measures, there was not this same kind of vigorous opposition and intensity of concern. So, for a group of people who know everything and who have all the answers, perhaps it should be said that the matters are not as simple as they have stated them to be.

This deferral tonight relates to the Migration Laws Amendment Bill which had a number of intentions in relation to unauthorised entry, and which has led to very long sojourns in this country through the use of our legal system by a group of people who, to some degree, the honourable member for Dundas defended very strongly on 11 November 1992, when he said:

SPEECH.PARA: I do not find it in the least surprising that those in the legal profession—given their duties and responsibilities . . . and given the employment difficulties that so many of them have in this recession, also a Government creation—use their creative endeavours to find their way through the system that the Government puts in place.

So it is all right for the honourable member to come here tonight and say that he is very concerned that we are deferring these matters, that they are very urgent and that we cannot afford any delays. He knows, as does everyone else in this House, that this area has been subject to a large degree of litigation in the expectation by some practitioners that there would be significant compensation payments down the track.

PARA.TAB: It is a bit hypocritical for the honourable member to say tonight that everything must go ahead full speed and that we should not defer or reconsider. A few months ago he said that there is a reality in this industry, that is, because of employment in the law field, people are using very inventive activities to try to subvert these laws.

If the new Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs (Senator Bolkus) had a view that a number of issues in this area should be reconsidered and there was a need to review these matters, then that is pretty understandable, given the history of litigation in this field. Those opposite will appreciate that some of the measures to which the ALP party caucus and the opposition have loaned their support in the last few years and which have been put through this House without objection from those opposite, with a very large degree of complementary support, have been subjected to those kinds of legal challenges and, I am afraid to say, on a significant number of occasions those challenges have been successful.

Despite what the honourable member has just said, the government has put forward a number of reasons for deferring these very important measures. A significant parliamentary inquiry is looking at the policies of detention for a number of people who are crucially affected by this bill. A large number of client groups need to be provided with information in the industry.

There is the added situation, as the honourable member opposite mentioned, of the training of staff and the drafting of regulations. In addition, it has been found, I understand, that there is a need through this process for extensive and complex alterations to the computer systems and databases. A variety of reasons have been given for deferral, but fundamental to them is the reality that this particular area, as I said earlier, has been subject to significant litigation.

We are talking, as the honourable member says, about a series of very important measures to ensure a more effective control of entry and detention and removal for those who fail to establish their genuine refugee credentials. We are talking about the enhancement of merit review by the Migration Internal Review Office and the Immigration Review Tribunal and, fundamentally, review by the Refugee Review Tribunal. So we are talking about things that do matter. We are talking about a subject that has been a very serious problem for this country. To say that there should be no reconsideration, that there should be no deferral, is not considering the realities.

More importantly, this legislation does not impact upon and undermine the operation of the Refugee Review Tribunal. It is operating; it is going ahead. Previous decisions by delegates representing the minister have been given increased authority by this bill. The most crucial aspects of the legislation are in no way affected. I support deferral.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pyne Mr C.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The government has run a curious migration system since 1989. It has two main steps: grand designs followed by rapid reform. Migration has been vital to the development of Australia. All non-Aboriginal Australians are either descendants of immigrants or are immigrants themselves. Our economy has been boosted by overseas migration, overseas investment and profits from overseas. There are equally important humanitarian reasons to make sure our migration system is fair and functions well. But these economic arguments clearly demonstrate how important it is for national development for Australia to have a sound migration policy.

PARA.TAB: The Migration Laws Amendment Bill defers introduction of all the major provisions of the Migration Reform Act 1992. It also introduces some technical arrangements dealing with transitional amendments which arise from the delay. The coalition does not oppose these aspects. However, we want to know why we need this bill. For those of us on this side of the House, the Migration Laws Amendment Bill only highlights the government's legislative and administrative incompetence. The government appears to have been unable to provide an achievable timetable for implementation of the Migration Reform Act when it was considered by parliament in December 1992. Nothing of great significance has occurred in the immigration portfolio in the ensuing months that could not have been anticipated last year. Instead, it appears that the government has simply not taken the appropriate measures to ensure a reasonable timetable to set the workings of the act into motion.

When the Migration Reform Act was debated last year, the coalition reminded the government of the crisis in immigration that this country faced. We spoke of the urgent need for reform. That crisis has not diminished, yet the government has been unable to put a coherent solution before this parliament. When, under the operations of this bill, the provisions of the 1992 act finally come into operation in September next year, 20 months will have passed. Last year, the Migration Reform Bill was drafted, debated and passed by the parliament with bipartisan support, ready to come into operation on a start-up date almost 12 months away. Now it has been found to be so badly flawed and in need of such reworking that, with the development of necessary new procedures and preparation of documentation, the start-up date must be delayed. During that delay, the urgency in immigration will not have diminished.

I believe it is important to remind ourselves about the depth of the immigration crisis this country faces. We now have over 20,000 asylum seekers in Australia applying for refugee status. Around 500 boat people are being held in detention while their claims for asylum are being determined. We have the problem of the 20,000 Chinese students who were in Australia at the time of the Tiananmen Square massacre, as well as their 7,000 dependants who have come to Australia since 1989 and may seek asylum after June 1994.

When I practised as a lawyer I worked extensively in immigration. A number of the cases on which I worked involved People's Republic of China nationals concerned about what status they had, and might be able to gain, to remain in Australia after the Tiananmen Square massacre and the comments of the then Prime Minister.

TALK.START.PARA: —Were you aware of the comments of the honourable member for Berowra?

—In my practice and as the member for Sturt, I have always relied on the comments of the honourable member for Berowra (Mr Ruddock). The government built up the hopes of these people. When faced with applications to remain in Australia, the road to success is a rocky one indeed. Often the initial application is refused, and is almost always followed with an appeal to the Migration Internal Review Office. If that is unsuccessful, another appeal to the Immigration Review Tribunal remains. This process is both costly and emotionally draining. Failure is a personal tragedy for those concerned and their dependents.

PARA.TAB: When the former Prime Minister granted the special conditions to the People's Republic of China nationals who were here prior to the Tiananmen Square massacre but were due to return to China, he did much to add to the confusion which surrounds immigration policy in this country. On the one hand, he built up their hopes of starting a new life in a country of liberty and equality; on the other hand, he condemned them to years of ambiguity and potentially shattered hopes.

In the world today, millions of people are on the move. Australia is fortunate to have a geographical position that protects it from many of the worse aspects of this mass population movement, as my colleague the honourable member for Berowra explained. Western Europe faces a serious problem with a growing tide of illegal immigrants and refugees now entering from the former communist states of the east. Thousands of Latin Americans steal across the border into the United States each year by whatever means they can. In Australia, however, we are relatively lucky in numerical terms. Only about two per cent of all the overseas born people in Australia are here illegally. Unlike those floods of people moving from the Balkans or Mexico, most immigrants to Australia are educated and skilled. However, we have problems and many of these can be tied directly to government policy.

The hopeless confusion surrounding the eventual fate of the 20,000 Chinese students seeking refugee status is a spectacular example of the failure of government policy. In the 1980s, the government encouraged Australian educational institutions, some offering courses of extremely dubious quality, to tap into the Chinese market. The demand for these services has collapsed, but we—and many thousands of PRC nationals in Australia—are still living with the consequences of this. Many Australians are anxious about the prospect of mass refugee arrivals, despite the relatively low levels of refugee and humanitarian intakes we actually have. These people are concerned about the effects such a massive influx of refugees, plus family members allowed into Australia on humanitarian grounds, could have on this country. Our current economic situation does nothing to assuage their fears. Instead, it opens up opportunities for all sorts of fringe groups to turn innocent concerns into racial tension, which is something none of us want.

The government or the department has done little to assist the situation. Instead, they are suffering from a hopeless administrative confusion brought about by a virtual state of sclerosis in their refugee policy. There is a clear need for a firm lead from the government on this issue. Tonight's legislation shows just how extensive the government's failure has been. Our processing system for determining refugee status has been put under enormous stress ever since 1989. As I mentioned, many of those seeking refugee status are in detention. Some of these have been held for a matter of years. This matter itself raises questions of human rights. Detention can have a most deleterious effect on these people and adds a whole range of new issues to the question of how we determine refugee status.

It could be argued that this bill is yet another continuation of the reworking of the government's 1989 migration regulations. There is a lack of coherence in the government's handling of these matters. The 1989 regulations needed major amendments and reworking. For honourable members who have been here longer than me, there must have been quite a sense of deja vu about this legislation. We need an immigration policy that is fair, sound and well managed. Tonight's debate clearly seems to suggest that that is lacking.

Last week the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs (Senator Bolkus) announced the establishment of a new special assistance category for Cambodians. It provided yet another example of the ad hoc nature of the government's immigration planning. Senator Bolkus's announcement pre-empted the outcome of the current inquiry into detention practices by the Joint Standing Committee on Migration Regulations that is due to report in December, to which my colleague the honourable member for Reid (Mr Ferguson) referred in his speech. It suggested to potential asylum seekers that if they could reach Australia, legally or illegally, they could well be allowed to stay if they spent enough time in this country.

The new category offers no fresh options that would allow refugee applicants to be processed speedily on a fair case by case basis. Most importantly, it fails to limit the wide access migration applicants have for judicial review of government decisions that have caused so many of the immigration problems that we now face. In short, it seems to be a typical bandaid measure that will treat the visible symptoms while we wait for major legislation, like the Migration Reform Act, to be implemented.

The Migration Reform Act introduced restrictions on the availability of judicial reviews by narrowing the scope for migration decisions to be appealed. A delay in its implementation will cause further log jams in our immigration system and continue to clog the Federal Court. When the legislation was originally debated last year, the coalition moved an amendment to reinforce the importance of this point. The amendment is worth repeating because it was excellent. It was moved by my colleague the honourable member for Berowra, I would imagine. It read:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . "whilst not declining to give the Bill a second reading, the House:

(1)deplores the Government's failure to control the refugee determination process, commencing with former Prime Minister Hawke's decision on the People's Republic of China Nationals in Australia at the time of the Tiananmen Square massacre;
(2)notes the lamentable time delays in moving to reform the refugee determination system; and

(3)regrets that the further proposals put by the Coalition to limit judicial appeals, to require leave to access review procedures and to redeploy staff to the refugee screening process have been ignored".

The Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Housing, Local Government and Community Services and Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Health (Dr Theophanous) did not care to take up these amendments at the time. He has now lost his chance, unfortunately. In 1992 the legislation was belated; in 1993 we are now facing greater delays before it can come into operation.

PARA.TAB: In Australia, no-one ties immigration purely to economic issues. We do not see immigrants only as factors of production that will add value to the national product. However, the area of immigration is tied very closely to the sort of society we all want Australia to be. How governments deal with immigration is watched closely by Australians of non-English speaking and cultural backgrounds. Immigration policy affects each ethnic community in Australia very acutely. We are fortunate that in this country we have developed a tradition of tolerance and multiculturalism.

TALK.START.PARA: —Hear, hear!
—Hear, hear!

—`Hear, hear', my colleagues say. Peaceful multiculturalism is one of Australia's greatest achievements. Its critics contribute little of any value to our national debates. It is not surprising that there is such a great deal of bipartisan support for the concept, as the parliamentary secretary has demonstrated by his support for my speech tonight.

PARA.TAB: I would like to take the opportunity tonight to put on the record my own unequivocal commitment to a multicultural Australia. The benefits of diversity and tolerance, and the richness of the contribution that non-English speaking background Australians have made to our society, and now their society, is hard to quantify. Suffice to say, we are a more sophisticated and lucky country as a result of being open to people of all backgrounds in our immigration policy.

In my electorate of Sturt I am fortunate to have a high concentration of Italian background Australians. In fact, it has been estimated that as many as 15,000 of the 82,000 adults in Sturt are of Italian background. I have been welcomed wholeheartedly into their community. I look forward to my continued association with that community, as well as the many other groups that represent non-English speaking background Australians in my electorate.

Too many commentators have sought to link support for multiculturalism with backing for mass immigration. Some of this has stuck in the public imagination. It does nothing to advance the multicultural ideal, as making high immigration a prerequisite for multiculturalism weakens public support. It also prevents the wider community from thinking about the hard facts of immigration policy, as opposed to ideas of national identity, close though they may be.

The work done so far on codifying our national immigration policies has created a legislative and administrative maze that is incomprehensible to ordinary people. We learn this every day from the number of calls on immigration matters we all receive in our offices. We are now even hearing suggestions from immigration specialists that the government has set itself the impossible task of drafting immigration rules that are trying to cover all eventualities and has become totally lost in the process.

Migration is important. We cannot afford to have a system that constantly fails to serve the needs of our community. For some time now, the coalition has been calling for a full inquiry into the administration and operation of the Department of Immigration and Ethnic Affairs. The incompetence of the department as shown in its handling of the Migration Reform Act only adds to that call.

So far the government has resisted taking any action. I understand, however, that this week we will be taking action in the Senate to establish a select committee that will inquire into the efficiency and management of the department. Debates like tonight's remind us of the department's record. We should not have to tolerate continual revision or continual failure to meet aims in such an important area.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Theophanous The Hon A.C.

TALKER.NAME: Dr THEOPHANOUS
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Housing, Local Government and Community Services and Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Health)

TALK.START.PARA: —I am glad the honourable member for Sturt (Mr Pyne) is a great supporter of multiculturalism. We welcome those people into the parliament. It is a pity that about half of his party do not support it.
—Don't be so ungracious!

—I am being very gracious in saying only about half. I remind honourable members of the on-the-record comments of the honourable member for Bennelong (Mr Howard), in particular, and others in relation to this matter.

PARA.TAB: We have had a wide ranging debate. Unfortunately, because the Migration Laws Amendment Bill is under guillotine we have not been able to have more discussion; nevertheless, it has been very good discussion. We have heard from the honourable member for Berowra (Mr Ruddock), the honourable member for Reid (Mr Ferguson) and the honourable member for Sturt, and I thank them for their contributions.

The honourable member for Berowra brought up a number of issues. I want to reply to some of them in the few minutes available to me. I begin by saying that I thought his somewhat angry performance here today about what has happened was quite unconvincing. The basic reality is that the government has been very responsible in deferring certain provisions of the Migration Reform Act 1992. In fact, in so doing it has given itself the opportunity to look again at a number of these issues.

It is interesting that in the contributions of both the honourable member for Berowra and the honourable member for Sturt we had criticism of the government in relation to certain key issues concerning refugees, in particular the Chinese and the Cambodian questions. Yet when the government says, `Look, we are actually going to resolve some of these issues and, in the context of that resolution, we will be in a much clearer position to look at the act again in September 1994', we get criticism from the opposition. It is an inconsistent position. But it is not just that. Every speech the honourable member for Berowra has given in this parliament in the last few years seems to have come back to the Chinese students issue.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is right.
—It is as if the Chinese students issue has got to him. In fact, it has got to him because—
—It's a fundamental issue.

—It is a fundamental issue; but, as he knows, it is an issue about which there are disagreements in this parliament as to how it ought to be dealt with. He knows that because he and I served on the Joint Standing Committee on Migration Regulations which brought down a report on refugees and humanitarian categories.
—And more of your colleagues agreed with me than they did with you.

—That is not correct; only one of my colleagues agreed with the honourable member. But I do not want to go into the ins and outs of that. The government has said that it is going to respond to this issue and to the report. The new Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs (Senator Bolkus) has been pressed on a number of occasions to comment on this issue. He has said that the government will remain faithful to the commitments made by the former Prime Minister and by the current Prime Minister (Mr Keating). Nevertheless, a number of options remain for dealing with the problem.

PARA.TAB: The minister has also said that he is hopeful of having the matter resolved before the end of the year. I am confident of the likelihood of that occurring. By the end of the year we should have from the government a statement about which of the various options it will adopt in relation to this very difficult question.

The honourable member for Berowra does himself a disservice when he gets up here and repeats over and over his view on how the problem arose, as though that will somehow make the problem go away. I do not agree with his one-sided view of how the problem arose, and even those who do agree that the problem should not have been allowed to arise say that we need to give serious consideration to the options for resolution of the matter. Surely, the honourable member for Sturt—who, as a lawyer, has dealt with immigration cases—has some sympathy for the plight of the Chinese students.

TALK.START.PARA: —Enormous sympathy.
—Unfortunately, the honourable member for Berowra, by his comments, does not show much at all.
—That is not a correct interpretation of my compassion. My concern is to maintain the education system.

—The honourable member is on the record in relation to this matter, and so am I. Obviously, the government will respond to these issues. There is no crisis; the government is not out of control. The visas for the pre-Tiananmen Square people do not expire until June of this year. There is no crisis. It is not as though people have been put into some situation about which they know nothing. There will be a resolution in time to meet the deadline—that is certain—and, hopefully, it will be this year.

PARA.TAB: For those people whose applications came after the Tiananmen Square incident, obviously, there is a difficulty. The government will have to look at their situation and the situation of all the other people who have been granted four-year temporary visas. It will have to decide what will happen when those four years are up. Those are important issues.

To say that there are important issues confronting the immigration minister in what is always a difficult task is not to say that there is a crisis. The government must deliberate on these matters and sort them out—and it will be sorting them out. The honourable member for Sturt referred to the resolution of the Cambodian issue as an `ad hoc' solution. I do not know where he gets that idea.

TALK.START.PARA: —Where else has it been used?
—The honourable member for Berowra keeps interrupting, but to answer his—
—It is a one-off solution.
—No, it is not a one-off solution.

PARA.TAB: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Mr Jenkins)—The honourable member for Berowra should cease interjecting, and the parliamentary secretary should ignore the interjections.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is rather difficult to ignore the interjections from the vociferous honourable member for Berowra.
—One must try.

—The establishment of a special category is something that has occurred in different immigration contexts over the years. One special category deals with people in one way; another special category deals with people in another way. For example, there was a special category for Lebanese people; that problem was dealt with in a certain way. A special assistance category applies primarily to people from eastern Europe.
—More ad hoc decisions.

—With respect, that was not ad hoc; it is another example of a special category. To refer to the creation of special categories to deal with special circumstances as ad hoc decision making is nonsense. Special situations require special categories. In the present case we will be applying a special formula because it is a special situation. I do not see any problem with that.
—In other circumstances it would be called discriminatory. If it had been proposed by us, it would have been.

—I do not recall the opposition calling the Lebanese category or the special assistance category discriminatory. In fact, when these categories were introduced, the opposition supported them. The opposition is simply being argumentative. The reality is that the government is dealing with a number of serious measures. The honourable member for Sturt referred to the situation as a crisis. It is not a crisis. The government is dealing with the issues in a sensitive and constructive way. Certainly, one of the most important steps has been the announcement of the Cambodian category, but there will be other measures taken in respect of the Chinese situation, where both the pre-Tiananmen Square and post-Tiananmen Square issues will be dealt with.

PARA.TAB: The Cambodian issue was a very difficult issue to deal with. The opposition came up with no constructive suggestions. Its approach was to keep these people in detention until such time as they were processed under the very narrow refugee category, and then send them out with no opportunities, irrespective of whatever links they might have had to Australia. The minister has taken a much more compassionate approach—much more compassionate than anything suggested by the honourable member for Berowra.

The honourable member is very good at pontificating but when he was the shadow immigration minister—certainly in the second half of the last three-year regime—he took an extremely tough stand on the Cambodian people, the Chinese question and on many other issues. Here the minister has come up with a compassionate and considerate approach to the Cambodian problem and what do we hear from the honourable member for Berowra? We hear him say that it is all ad hoc. That was the response from the honourable member for Berowra to the minister's humanitarian and compassionate approach to what has been an intransigent and difficult problem. That sort of response is not good enough. The opposition should start thinking about its whole approach to immigration.

The honourable member for Sturt talked about the way in which ethnic communities follow events in immigration. He is absolutely right about that. One of the reasons the conservative parties lost so many votes in the ethnic communities in the last election was precisely because they took positions on immigration that were unsustainable from a humanitarian point of view.

The honourable member for Berowra made some comments about why the government is delaying implementation of these measures. The Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Mr Crean) in his second reading speech said:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . a number of minor amendments have been identified, predominantly of a technical nature, which still need to be made to the legislation to ensure that it operates smoothly.
The honourable member for Berowra said that that was not a good enough reason. He obviously did not read the next paragraph, which said:
Substantial drafting of subordinate legislation and consequential amendments to related legislation is necessary.

That is certainly a very important reason, because we do not want to get into a position where this subordinate legislation and regulations will be mistaken. We want to get it correct and we want to be in a situation in which it works.
