DEBATE.TITLE: FOREST INDUSTRIES RESEARCH LEVY BILL 1993COGNATE BILLS:FOREST INDUSTRIES RESEARCH EXPORT CHARGE BILL 1993FOREST INDUSTRIES RESEARCH IMPORT CHARGE BILL 1993

PARA.TAB: Debate resumed from 7 September, on motion by Mr Lee:
That the bill be now read a second time.

TALKER.NAME: Mr ANDERSON
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —The coalition supports the Forest Industries Research Levy Bill and cognate bills. The bills before us provide for the establishment and funding of a forest and wood products research and development corporation, which the forest industry has been very sensibly, I think, seeking for some considerable time. To finance the corporation and its activities, there will be a levy on wood produced in and exported from Australia as unprocessed wood and on unprocessed wood and certain classes of primary processed forest products imported into Australia.

PARA.TAB: Whilst at the present time Commonwealth and state governments do contribute to some extent to research through the various departments and the CSIRO, the Australian Forestry Council, which consists of state and federal ministers responsible for forestry, believes that there is much more that can be done. All major reports on the forest industry, including the Resource Assessment Commission's 1992 forest and timber inquiry, the National Plantations Advisory Committee and the ESD working group on forest use have echoed the urgent need for an enhanced, better coordinated and better focused research program. All believe more research is essential if Australia is to increase productivity and value adding in processing in forests and wood product industries and to manage our forests in an ecologically sustainable way.

The new research corporation will identify national research priorities and assess research gaps. It will commission, administer and subsequently evaluate research into a broad range of areas relating to wood production, extraction, processing, economics and marketing. Its charter will also include the ecological and environmental impacts of disturbance resulting from wood production, silviculture and management of native forests and plantations. It will not actually undertake research itself but will call for tenders from those organisations which can and do undertake research.

As with other rural research and development corporations, it will have a higher degree of industry involvement and accountability, and the industry, through the National Association of Forest Industries—NAFI, as it is known—will be closely involved in the selection of a board of directors for the corporation. The corporation must prepare a five-year plan in consultation with the industry. It must also prepare annual operating plans for each financial year which are consistent with its five-year plan. The corporation's annual reports will be tabled in parliament and they will be made available to industry. It will be up to the industry to decide the amount of levy payable to provide the corporation with the resources to increase the research effort to an appropriate level.

The application of the levy will commence as from 1 January 1994. There will be provision for different levy rates to apply to different classes of wood and levies will be payable by the operators of mills taking delivery of wood. The industry has requested essentially four different rates for different classes of wood in relation to the level of the levy. The different classes of wood are hardwood sawlogs, softwood sawlogs, hardwood pulp logs and softwood pulp logs. The levy is payable on not only domestic wood but also imported unprocessed wood. A separate account will ensure that the money collected from imports is spent on research and development relevant to the timber importing industry.

The Commonwealth will provide $1 for every $2 collected from the domestic industry to a maximum of 0.25 per cent of the gross value of production of the industry. The reason for the Commonwealth contribution being set at $1 to $2 and not dollar for dollar, as is the case with other primary industries, is given as being because only half the industry has a primary industry focus—in particular, of course, that refers to tree production and to small rural sawmills—while the other half has an essentially manufacturing basis. I note that this seems to be an application of a slightly different principle to that which applies to the dairy industry. The Commonwealth will not match import levy funds, and it is expected that contributions in a full year from the domestic industry will be of the order of $700,000. The effectiveness of the corporation—I think this is quite appropriate and advisable—will be reviewed in 1995-96.

It seems important to underline that the timber industry has enormous potential for growth in all of its facets in this country. Until now it has largely concentrated on the domestic market and currently provides some two-thirds of Australia's needs. However, Australia still imports more than $2.4 billion worth of timber product, much of it high value pulp and paper products. We export only $775 million worth of product, leaving a very substantial trading deficit getting on for $1.75 billion.

Given resource security, the forest industry can, and in my view will, expand. It will increasingly become a prominent value adding industry. It has the capacity to create thousands of additional jobs and it has the capacity to very substantially reduce not just Australia's trade deficit in timber products, but address our urgent need to boost exports and move towards the righting of our trade imbalance. I note that even the ACTU estimates that nearly $7 billion in job creating investment is currently being held up in this country by what is euphemistically known as green tape. Much of that is in the development of forest products from forests and plantations which are, unquestionably, a renewable and sustainable resource. It is a pity that the government seems little short of paralysed when it comes to making decisions about the future of the forest industries.

We have seen arguments between ministers about whether exports of woodchips will be phased out altogether after the year 2000. We have seen a failure to obtain resource security for the 1,200 timber mills scattered throughout Australia, many of them small but quite important to the people who work in them, to their local communities and, in the end, particularly in a cumulative sense, to the nation's economic performance. We have seen a minister in charge of forests have the ground cut out from beneath his feet when he tried to reach an agreement that could have helped those smaller companies that were proposing to set up projects worth less than $100 million.

We can only draw the conclusion that the truth is that the government never wanted resource security legislation. It wanted only to make it look as though it was being friendly to the timber industry—to the forest industries. By contrast, the coalition's policy was to legislate for resource security without any reference to the size of the project. Small can be beautiful and small can grow. Henry Ford started out with a very small business indeed, but it did not stay that way.

We believe the sawmill that wants to spend money on a veneer plant or a drying process, or anything that adds value to timber, has just as much right to be guaranteed supply as does a pulp mill. There have been something like 18 reports by committees of inquiry into the forest industry and I cannot think of any that the industry lost, or that found in some essential way against the industry and its continued opportunity for expansion.

The mother of all inquiries was the one done by the Resource Assessment Commission. It took years to complete, used almost an entire forest to produce its report and was favourable to the forest industry. The industry might have expected, quite reasonably, that that was going to be the end of it and that it would be allowed to get on with the job of expanding and developing a strong and vibrant timber industry in this country. Unfortunately, it seems that the only way that the government was able to respond was by having yet another inquiry. This time it was by the Industry Commission and it was also favourable. Will the industry now get the legislation that the IC says is necessary, the RAC says is required, the opposition has proposed, and which is unquestionably vital to the future of the industry?

The coalition recognises that the most efficient, cost-effective and environmentally sound method of forest management is an integrated harvest system. If a tree is to be cut down for sawlogs, it is important to use every bit of it. This means that there is material that can only be chipped. Apart from pulp mills and the few places in Australia which value add by turning the chips into board which can then be veneered and turned into furniture, the rest is currently exported or far too often—shamefully, in my view—burnt on the forest floor.

Unfortunately, there are still people who really believe that the industry logs native forests just for woodchips. In fact, it is difficult to get rid of chippable material at the moment. The lack of market for forest thinnings and sawlog residue is costing jobs and making sawlogs, and therefore timber, dearer. We have seen whole forests like the Victorian pine forests at Myrtleford ruined because the former Labor state government would not allow them to be thinned in case it upset what might be loosely described as the `deep greens'. That particular government went down owing billions of dollars, to the great cost—as is now being experienced so vividly in that state—of its residents, at the same time as it wasted tens of millions of dollars by refusing to thin the forest which guaranteed that much of its resource became virtually useless.

On top of this, there was a time when, unbelievably, it was paying to have the sawlog residue burnt on the forest floor. This was costing the state $10 million a year in lost revenue at the same time as Australia lost $100 million in export earnings from woodchips. It is an absurd situation. It is reflective of the way in which emotion has been allowed to cloud and supplant logical debate where the future of the forest industries in this country is concerned.

One of the other things that I think is important to recognise is that, because of the long time between planting and harvesting, it is difficult to get people to invest in plantations in Australia. In terms of building a bigger and expanding industry in this country, it needs to be understood that we have to get the incentives right so that people will invest in farming trees and developing plantations. Taxpayers who plant trees in Australia are often subjected to inconsistent rulings by the Taxation Office, particularly in regard to the definitions of `capital' and `revenue'.

If the plantation is deemed to be capital, deductions may be allowed only over a 10-year period or even disallowed as coming under capital gains rather than income provisions. Currently, the establisher of a plantation can obtain deductions for the cost of trees and must pay full tax on the value of the trees if he moves to sell the plantation before harvest. However, the buyer of an immature plantation who wants to resell before maturity does not obtain any deduction for the value of the trees. It is important that the government look to getting rid of these tax impediments because we believe that the timber industry is a potential growth industry with a capacity to reduce our trading deficit, provide jobs, prosperity and opportunities, particularly in rural and regional areas of this country. As one who comes from and represents one of those areas, I am very conscious indeed of the urgent need for just such development. We want to see more money put into research and development. This is why we support these bills.

While we are on the subject of forests, let me take up a matter which I think has been seriously wrongly reported in recent days. It relates to the Hampshire satellite mill in Tasmania. This mill is not being established to chip old growth forest as appears to have been implied very strongly in media reports in recent days. Nobody in their right mind would chip a log that is suitable for milling because the return from a sawlog is so much greater than the return from chips. About 85 per cent of the wood used in the Hampshire mill will in fact come from the company's own wood farms where trees are grown specifically for the pulp market. The other 15 per cent will come from farm forestry and native forests.

When sawlogs are harvested, there is always a residue—logs that are bent; logs that are rotten; logs that, for whatever reason, are not useable for other purposes. This can be turned into chips or, alternatively, is left to rot or is burnt on the forest floor so that the regrowth trees can be given every opportunity and encouragement to grow. The prime purpose of this mill is to supply world-class product for the Burnie and Wesley Vale pulp and paper mills. While many of us would like to see more pulp mills in Australia so that more of these chips could be used in this country, in the meantime, it is certainly better to export chips and earn export income than to burn the residue on the forest floor.

North Forest Products owns 125,000 hectares of land in northern Tasmania and 82,000 of those hectares are suitable for eucalyptus production. Currently, the company is planting about 3,600 hectares a year at the rate of 1,000 trees a hectare, or 3.6 million trees a year. This ensures a sustainable yield of more than one million tonnes a year on the current genetic stock and, in the future, double that from improved genetic material. That is just one area where research and development can bring extraordinary results.

The company has been planting eucalypts since 1956. It increased the size of the plantings in the 1970s and again in the 1980s. It has further developed another 2,000 hectares of eucalypt with private owners. The company plans to expand its tree nursery to about five million trees and plant 5,000 hectares every year. On a recent visit to the tree nursery and plantations, I can honestly say that I was very impressed with the work that the company is doing with the cloning of Tasmanian blue gum and shining gum—or nitens, as they are so widely known down there. We are leading the world in this work. I was also impressed that 20 per cent of the company's freehold land is kept in reserve for environmental, historical and recreational purposes. The company believes this is part of good management.

Whilst in many ways the debate in the past has been healthy in terms of focusing the minds of both the community and the industry on the need to be environmentally responsible and work towards developing a sustainable industry for the future, there comes a time when we have to say that, to a large extent, those desirable objectives have been achieved. We now need to look to the future and ensure that the facts rule and emotion does not cloud judgment. In my view, as a farmer who understands only too well the nature of rotation, growing things in cycles, harvesting and replanting, this industry is well on the way towards developing a sustainable future. We need to support it in that, not just for the sake of the industry, but for the nation as a whole. I believe that can be done in a way that is entirely sympathetic to, and consistent with, the legitimate environmental concerns of the broader community.

I commend the industry on the progress that it has made, albeit at times under some pressure. I urge it to continue to maintain a sensible and balanced approach. I urge the government to give this great industry an environment in which it can reach its potential. Having said that, I acknowledge the value of the bills and their objectives which are before the House and I encourage their support.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to support the Forest Industries Research Levy Bill and cognate bills tonight, and it gives me great pleasure to be part of the debate. The forest industry of course is a major industry in my area of Victoria—in both the electorate of McMillan and the electorate of Gippsland, which are side by side in that great part of Australia. The major company Amcor is in my electorate, and it produces much of Australia's paper.

PARA.TAB: These bills form part of a package of legislation to establish and fund a Forest and Wood Products Research and Development Corporation in partnership with industry. The purpose of these bills is to provide for the imposition of a levy and charges on unprocessed wood produced in Australia and a charge on wood and certain classes of primary processed forest products imported into Australia. So it impacts on both the local industry and those who are importing timber into Australia.

In addition to these bills, the Primary Industries and Energy Legislation Bill includes consequential amendments to the Primary Industries Levies and Charges Collection Act 1991 and the Primary Industries and Energy Research and Development Act 1989. The levy and charge on domestic production will be collected at the time that the unprocessed wood is delivered to a mill for processing or when it is exported. The charge on imports of wood and forest products will be collected from the importer at the time of importation. So, once again, I stress that the legislation is treating both the industry within Australia and those importing into Australia on a similar basis.

All major inquiries and reports concerning the forest industries conducted over recent years have identified the critical need for an enhanced, better coordinated and better focused research effort in the forest sector. These have included the Resource Assessment Commission 1992 forest and timber inquiry—which the previous speaker, the honourable member for Gwydir (Mr Anderson), alluded to—the National Plantations Advisory Committee and the ESD Working Group on Forest Use.

Following lengthy discussions and negotiations with the forest and wood products industries, the government agreed to the establishment of the corporation as a key initiative of the national forest policy statement. Commonwealth funds for the corporation, totalling $4.25 million up to 1995-96, were approved under the national forest policy statement. The corporation is to be established under the Primary Industries and Energy Research and Development Act 1989. Regulations establishing the corporation from 1 January 1994 were made on 27 July 1993 and gazetted on 3 August. Separate legislation is required to impose the levy on the domestic industry and on imports such as those we are dealing with tonight.

The charter for the corporation will be to identify national research priorities and assess what research is being done. It will commission, administer and subsequently evaluate research into a broad range of issues relating to wood production, the extraction of those products, processing, economics and marketing. Its charter will also include the ecological and environmental impacts of disturbance resulting from wood production, silviculture and management of native forests and plantations. These are very important issues, and they will certainly further develop the industry—an industry which has, at times over many years, been the target of demonstrations by, and the subject of concern of, many people in the community. This sort of approach can certainly do only good for the industry and will further its development in the future.

The corporation will not actually undertake any research. Organisations currently conducting forest industry research will be eligible to tender to carry out research on behalf of the corporation. As with other R&D corporations, the Forest and Wood Products Research and Development Corporation will have autonomy and flexibility and, at the same time, be fully accountable to both government and industry. The corporation will also be required to facilitate the dissemination, adoption and commercialisation of the results of research and development activities undertaken. Establishment of the corporation is intended to supplement the existing research effort rather than replace it. This is a very important item. Much of the research effort that is being carried out today will stay in place. It is not intended that this corporation will replace it. However, it is expected that existing research efforts by the industry—both by private companies and public forest management agencies—will be maintained and enhanced.

The National Association of Forest Industries fully supports the establishment of the corporation and has been declared a representative organisation for this corporation under the act. The National Association of Forest Industries has been very active in the whole gambit of the forest industries and is a very active organisation. Only two weeks ago I sat in a committee hearing here in Canberra when the executive officer of the National Association of Forest Industries addressed that committee and expressed NAFI's concerns in relation to many issues, including the security of tenure over resources. It is a concern that is an ongoing discussion point between the industry and government.

Unlike other rural R&D corporations, the Forest and Wood Products Research and Development Corporation is to be funded on the basis of $1 dollar from the Commonwealth for every $2 from industry. This amounts to dollar for dollar matching for the small sawmill operators who, together, account for about half of wood production. But there will be no Commonwealth matching funds for the pulp and paper manufacturers since they are large manufacturing companies and have access to other government assistance through cooperative research centres, the national pulp mill research program and R&D tax concessions. Proposed amendments to the PIERD Act provide that the Commonwealth will match industry contributions on a $1 for $2 basis up to a maximum of 0.25 per cent of the gross value of production of the industry. However, the Commonwealth will not match funds raised from the import charge.

The levy and charges, and any future changes to these, will be set by regulation following advice from NAFI. Industry has requested that different rates of levy apply to four classes of wood: hardwood sawlogs, softwood sawlogs, hardwood pulp logs and softwood pulp logs. The levies will be based on the average value for each class of wood. In the case of unprocessed wood exported from Australia, an equivalent charge will be imposed by the Forest Industries Research Export Charge Bill 1993. Industry is still consulting on the operative rate at which the levy and charges are to be introduced. While the legislation sets a maximum rate for a class of wood of 0.5 per cent of its average value, it is understood that the National Association of Forest Industries expects to recommend a rate considerably lower than this initially—possibly in the order of 0.1 per cent, or between 4c and 6c per cubic metre of unprocessed wood.

I have a few comments on the import charge. The Australian Timber Importers Federation—an affiliate of NAFI—has agreed to a charge on imports of unprocessed wood and certain classes of primary processed forest products, including sawn timber, wood based panels, medium density fibreboard and hardboard. In fact, continued industry support for the corporation has been dependent on the introduction of the import charge, which will ensure that importers do not gain a competitive advantage over the local industry.

The legislation provides that the import charge on unprocessed wood will be the same as the rate of levy applying to domestically produced wood. An appropriate conversion factor will be applied to imports of processed forest products to ensure equivalence with the domestic rate. Based on an initial levy rate of 0.1 per cent of the value of a class of wood, the rate of import charged would be in the order of 16c per cubic metre for sawn timber. New Zealand and US officials have raised concerns about the introduction of the charge. However, it recognises that importers who stand to benefit from the research should also contribute. I do not think anybody would challenge that those involved in the industry, both in the import and local sectors, should also contribute.

Of direct relevance to importers will be economics and marketing research and development, specifically identified in the charter of the FWPRDC. Importers should benefit directly from research and development in fields such as expanding the demand for wood products in Australia; new market and product developments; fire-related codes and standards; and the use of timber in multiple storey construction.

In addition to the benefits from research to be undertaken by the FWPRDC, New Zealand should also benefit through opportunities for New Zealand forest research organisations to tender for research projects commissioned by the corporation. It is understood that New Zealand is already involved in research and development with some Australian forestry agencies.

To ensure that importers benefit from the research activities undertaken by the corporation, an amendment to the PIERD act will provide explicitly that funds raised from this charge on imports must be directed to research and development which will be of relevance to their timber importing industry. The Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade has advised that introduction of the levy is fully consistent with Australia's obligations, the general agreement on tariffs and trade, and the closer economic agreement with New Zealand.

As I commented earlier in my remarks, the industry is extremely important to my electorate, to the total region of Gippsland and to Australia as a major industry. The Amcor operation, which announced in the last six to eight weeks that it has taken over APPM, is one of the major companies in Australia in relation to the forest and wood products industry—one that I am sure will be part of any research and development in an ongoing way.

I do not think any other company in Australia has a better record for research and development than the Amcor company. I would like to put on record not only its achievements in research and development, but the record relationship it has with its work force. It is one of the first industries within the timber industry to have settled an enterprise agreement with the CFMEU union.

Anybody who would like to visit the Amcor plant in Maryvale, Morwell, in my electorate—I am sure they would be most welcome—would see a model for Australia. The workers, through an organisation known as the A-team—made up of members of the CFMEU who work with management from Amcor—now virtually operate and run the mill. Management is so confident of the capabilities in the work force that the mill operates virtually with the workers running it. It is a unique situation, one of which they can be proud. The company is very proud of its achievements and I know that members of the CFMEU are extremely proud of their achievements in achieving an enterprise agreement where the union is not just the work force but now a fully-fledged partner in how the mill operates.

The work practices and improvements in productivity are such that if any companies in Australia wish to see what can be achieved by enterprise agreements and good cooperation with the work force, they need go no further than the Amcor mill at Maryvale. I am very pleased that Amcor has been able to take over APPM in Tasmania. That company has had the opposite experience in relation to its work force. We are looking to the stage in Amcor's development when the same level of cooperation between the work force and the company will be standard at the sites that previously were in great difficulty with APPM. What has been learnt—and the developments that have been put in place—will be very beneficial to the future development of this industry.

There is always the argument about resource security. It has been raised with me on many occasions and is one of the issues which I am sure those sitting around boardrooms take into consideration very carefully before they make the sorts of investment decisions required for new mills to be put in place. The Maryvale mill is a large producer of white paper. I am sure that in the near future, with the right conditions, the company will announce some very large investment decisions for a further white paper processing plant in that area. We have the resource. We are working towards resource security. Once all those things are in place, the company will make those decisions which will benefit Australia.

I spoke in this House last week in relation to the special country preferences. Indonesia has a country preference with Australia, one that needs to be reconsidered. Indonesia and Brazil in particular are the real competitors with Amcor for this sort of production of paper. Their mills are very much larger than the ones we have in Australia. Investments those nations have made for the future production of paper are such that they intend to be the world leaders by the turn of the century.

Australia, through the United Nations, has assisted developing countries. Once again—two weeks after my last speech—I put it on the record that it is time we started to negotiate very seriously with Indonesia, on the basis that whilst Indonesia and Brazil need to develop, when the big capitalist money is moved into their nation and very large sums of money are spent on very modern technology, we need to consider very carefully whether we need to provide special preferences for their products in the Australian market. I raise that matter again tonight because it is crucial.

The measures in the Forest Industry Research Levy Bill, the Forest Industry Research Export Bill and the Forest Industry Research Import Bill are good for the industry. But we need the level playing field. I appeal to the Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Defence (Mr Punch), who is at the table, to convey to the executive government that there comes a time when Australia may wish to continue to assist such countries as Indonesia and Brazil with their overall development, but we should reconsider whether the special benefits afforded to them in the paper industry have run their course. We are now onto level playing field conditions and we need to compete with those countries, not only on the Australian market but on the world market. We need to negotiate with those countries for a fair and level opportunity.

If we do not get that, the people sitting around the boardrooms of large companies, such as Amcor, will always have a doubt as to whether resource security is there and whether the playing field is level, before they make final decisions. I am confident that in my electorate we will see, in the very near future, those decisions being made for the benefit of Australia. Before they are made I am sure that the company—and the workers in that company—will be urging the government to move towards a real level playing field so the industry in Australia can prosper and we can further develop our industry—maybe even to the point where they need our products, the quality products, in Indonesia and Brazil. We may be able to export to them without having to face up to 45 per cent tariff barriers plus other measures which restrict our exports to those nations. I fully support the legislation and recommend that the government keep on its path. It is a positive path, and I am sure that in the long term it will certainly benefit Australia.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gallus Mrs C.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —Following on from the comments of the honourable member for Gwydir (Mr Anderson), I want to refer to the value added aspects of the Forest Industries Research Levy Bill. That bill and the other two bills before us put a levy on logs produced and delivered in Australia, on those produced and exported and on forest products imported. The levy is to fund the Forest and Wood Products Research Development Corporation. The charter of this corporation is to identify priorities, administer and evaluate research into wood production, extraction, processing, economics and marketing—and this is sorely needed in Australia.

PARA.TAB: Trees and forests have become quite an issue in Australia on a number of levels. One thing that happened last year that was disturbing to everyone was this government's licence to send large, uncut sawlogs straight to Korea—if my memory serves me correctly, about 7,000 tonnes. This has to be an example of what not to do. Here we have an Australian resource which we send away to another country. We either import it back with a value added by another country or that country makes a profit by sending it somewhere else. We have to look much more to our resources and say, `How can we do that value adding?'. It is certainly not to send those saw logs, without the value added, to Korea.

TALK.START.PARA: —Hear, hear!

—The honourable member for Gwydir certainly agrees with that. It is value added. If this research trust comes forward with ways in which we can do this, it will be for the benefit of not only the forest industry but Australia as a whole. I mentioned saw logs. Recently I was in Tasmania talking to the forest industry. I was quite amazed to find the limited number of saw logs that the industry can actually get out of an area. The industry there said it expected to get 10 per cent of the original straight trees that it was looking for. If the industry logs an area for the sawlogs, there is a lot left that goes into woodchipping and what follows from the woodchipping. Part of the problem is that the market for woodchips has fallen—Brazil has taken over a lot of that market—and we are getting virtually nothing for our woodchips. Here we have a fabulous natural resource that is not bringing any return to Australia. This is why some of the green groups are saying, `Why do it? We are losing the resource and we are not getting anything back for it'. When we do log, whether it is plantations or some of the forests that perhaps are not of the highest conservation value, we have to look to the value adding through pulp mills and paper mills so that, as the honourable member for Gwydir said, we are not importing $2.4 billion worth of product from overseas. I think we are exporting $775 million worth of product. The figures should be the other way around. We should be exporting so much more than we are importing. We have the land and we hope to have the product to go into it.

PARA.TAB: There is disagreement between the greens and the forest industry, which will be an ongoing argument for a long time. I do not think there is any disagreement at the outside. Both the forest industry and the greens will agree that there has to be a national reserve system where forests are conserved. But when we get to the edges there will always be an overlap where the forest industry says, `This forest is suitable for logging; it is not an old growth forest; it is not part of the wilderness and it should be logged', and the conservation groups say, `No, this is part of the old growth forest. It should be part of the reserve system and we have to keep it here'. I do not think we can hope that these issues will be easily resolved. They must be resolved, and I condemn the government for the way that it runs some of these issues, which is government by press release and grandstanding.

There are genuine disagreements on the forest policy. The way to solve them is not by making political capital out of them but by sitting down—as did the forest industry and many of the conservatives groups in the ESD process—discussing the problems with give and take on all sides and coming to an agreed line on where they can agree and where perhaps they disagree. I think it was of great disappointment to both groups when the ESD process on forests, as with other processes, went into the bureaucracy and simply got lost.

I have mentioned that most of the forest is not used for sawlogs. I recently read a quite fascinating article called `Our Timber Cringe', written by Peter Collenette, in which he refers to the possibilities that we have for our timber industry. He talks about the neglected hardwoods in Australia and that for so long we have looked to the exotic timbers for furniture—rosewood, teak and the Brazilian woods. These have been referred to as the special woods we should have. He points out that in Australia we have more than 70 commercial species of eucalyptus, plus scores of other trees that grow to millable size and produce delightfully varied timber, yet—rather regrettably—the journal of the forestry industry was:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . hyping up wood from the rainforests of Brazil . . . and west Africa.
He points out:

PARA.TAB: It's not as if our native timbers have never been used for fine work such as furniture and interior trim.

SPEECH.PARA: That used to happen. We can remember the days when huon pine and Australian cedar were used for furniture to the point where they are now hardly available and we have run out of supply. But other hardwoods are available to us. In fact, Peter Collenette sets out quite a list of the neglected hardwoods we could be growing in plantations in Victoria to supply the sawlogs. These include messmate, yellow stringybark, red ironbark, candlebark, mountain gum, manna gum, narrow-leaved peppermint, southern blue gum, southern mahogany, grey gum, silvertop ash, red gum, and silver wattle.

PARA.TAB: Forests are a major issue for conservation groups. The reason for that is not hard to understand. Forests, like everything else, grow on the best and most fertile land. When the settlers came to Australia it was naturally that arable, fertile land that was cleared first for farming. So some of our best forests were removed early on. As farming increased, so more of the forest went. We were left in many cases with not the best we started with but with remaining forests. The conservation groups are now working very hard to save examples of those forests throughout Australia. In those forests we have an enormous biodiversity which we have not yet fully realised. Just as we have not done the value adding in the sawlogs, we have not looked at our forests to see what they can offer to Australia's economy.

If I can take a step backwards, I think everybody in Australia now realises the contribution that trees make. Clearing farming land and removing trees has had a disastrous effect on Australia inasmuch as it has caused the raising of the water tables. In the electorate of the honourable member for Gwydir, I have seen areas where the water table is within about one metre of the surface. It has had disastrous effects on the whole area. In my own state of South Australia, we have a massive problem with dry-land salinity. Much of this comes from the fact that we have cleared the forests and the long-rooted grasses. That we need to regenerate has long been accepted. During the last election not enough attention was paid to the coalition's policy on the concept of a permanent revegetation trust. That would have meant the taxpayer would have paid farmers for the planting and fencing of land that went back to revegetation to save the land.

Taking a step on from that, I do not think the biodiversity of forests has been appreciated fully in the community. Certainly the conservation groups are very much aware of this and it is one of the reasons that they are so very keen to save what forests we have left and to put more effort into plantations, so that we can hopefully get into fully sustainable logging by the end of the century or, if not, very soon after.

Australia, more than any other country, has a wide range of species in its forests that is simply not available anywhere else in the world. We have not realised what those species offer. I think we are all aware of what was happening recently in Western Australia. I think it was in the smoke bush—although I might be corrected on that—that a possible cure for AIDS has been found. This is one very dramatic example, but I am aware that there are many less dramatic examples. One that I know of is the discovery of a plant that excretes a certain chemical that the aphid cannot tolerate. It so happens that we do not have that aphid in Australia but Singapore does. So products from that plant can be manufactured and sold to another country.

This is just one very small example. There are numerous such examples but we have not yet looked at all those plants and at what possible medical, industrial, chemical and biological uses we could put them to. Part of the reason for the biodiversity convention is to have a look at the genetic ownership of plants, because scientists all over the world are guilty—and Australian scientists are as guilty as anyone else—of taking plants from other countries, using them to produce products and not giving a return to the other country. Australia stands to lose more than most countries because of our unique biodiversity.So this is one of the reasons why we have to maintain an example of all the ecosystems that we have left, to see what biodiversity is there and what use we could make of it. I also believe we need to maintain some wilderness, but that is another question.

Taking that a bit further, there is the belief in forests as such—that because trees are good forests are good—but there is a tendency to ignore the necessity of keeping the understorey. But it is in the understorey that we have that wide diversity of species. I was reading another article in today's paper which indicates what effect there is when the understorey is removed. It was referring to the scarab Christmas beetle and how that has recently been causing dieback to the eucalyptus. The scarab beetle is being blamed for killing off the eucalyptus but the article points out that before white settlement the scarab beetle was actually no problem in Australia. So what has happened that the scarab beetle is now causing dieback to the eucalyptus?

What happens with farming practices, with fertilisation and the removal of some of the understorey, is that we lose the predators and we get an extremely high feeding ground for those beetles, so we get an explosion of the population. Again we have to realise that, unless we keep things in balance, it is not only our forests that are going to be affected but our very farming land. It comes back to a story similar to when we removed the trees and we got this rise in dry land salinity. If we remove the understorey we break up the ecological balances, we get a loss of predators and one or other species becomes out of balance and attacks our productive capacity.

The need to maintain a representative system of forests has been recognised by the national forests policy which has been signed by all states except Tasmania. In conclusion, I would like to look at the agreed national goals. The first goal, which was the focus of this bill, was to increase Australia's national forest research and development effort. One of the high priorities of the coalition is to see value added for our national resources. A second goal was the maintenance of an extensive and permanent native forest estate and the management of that estate in an ecologically sustainable manner. The third one, which I am sure the honourable member for Gwydir (Mr Anderson) will fully endorse, was the development of an internationally competitive and ecologically sustainable wood production and wood products industry.

We support the expansion of Australia's commercial plantations of softwoods and hardwoods so as to provide an additional, economically viable, reliable and high quality wood resource industry. We need three things in our forest industry. We need value added. We need to direct more attention in the future to plantations because we cannot keep logging forests without plantations. I think everybody realises that. We have to replace them with new plantations and we have got to be sensible in the way that we look at those plantations. We perhaps have to look at multiculture rather than monoculture and be sensitive to the effect on the rest of the environment with those plantations. Finally, we have to combine it with a system of national reserves, including all the representative forests in Australia.

TALK.START.PARA: —It certainly is nice to be here this evening to find that the opposition is supporting the Forest Industries Research Levy Bill and cognate bills and supporting the thrust of this government in trying to get value added to our timber products. The forests of Australia have been a major resource to this nation for thousands of years. They were a resource to the indigenous people of this country long before Europeans came here, and let us hope that legislation such as that before us this evening is going to ensure that they are a resource here in this country for the rest of the history of the earth.

PARA.TAB: One has only to look around this building to appreciate the beauty, the durability and the versatility of Australian hardwoods. But, unfortunately, this resource is currently being exploited at unsustainable levels in some areas. Our forests have a history of being exploited and being undervalued. Their traditional uses have not taken advantage of their unique qualities.

In the early colonial days of course timber was felled, it was burnt to make charcoal and it was shipped off to Europe in enormous quantities. The roads of London were actually paved with blocks of Australian hardwood. Some of them are still there today. So it was easy to get, and by removing it we were creating cleared farm land. So it went on. We continued to exploit this magnificent resource. This is a tragedy because our native hardwood forests are a unique resource—they are unique to this nation, to the world of forests.

The Forest Industries Research Levy Bill is an attempt by the government to return capital to the forest industry for research and development so that value adding can be carried out. That way, not only can we generate greater income but also we obviously create jobs. The beauty of it is we will create jobs in those parts of Australia that need them the most, and that is the rural areas.

In my own electorate timber harvesting and processing has been a traditional industry for approaching two centuries. We have had logging and milling. At present there is a glulam mill where selected hardwoods are taken, kiln dried, glued together and dressed—a tremendous value adding industry. CSR has a hardboard mill there where wood pulp is produced from the offcuts, the timber waste. I have been advised only in the last week that after Christmas this particular mill will be expanding to three shifts a day, seven days a week. That again is indicative of how Australian hardwoods are coming back into their own; how research and development is creating new uses for our hardwoods. That is certainly to be complimented.

Let me give an example of what value adding can do to Australian hardwoods. We sell a cubic metre of sawn hardwood for framing, which the United States has taken a liking to over the past decade, for about $300 to $400. If it is kiln dried and stress tested, its value is increased to about $1,200 a cubic metre. A young craftsman who lives in Gloucester is participating in an international furniture exhibition in Japan next month. He uses only Australian hardwood; he does not use anything else. He has won awards for design and small business and he converts Australian hardwood to a value of about $8,000 a cubic metre. That is the sort of thing we can do and that makes our forests entirely sustainable.

At present, in my own electorate, the big debate that is raging about timber concerns the old growth forests and whether we will be allowed to log them. The timber industry wants to get in there to exploit the last of that great resource. I agree with the opposition: we have to look to making our forestry industry entirely sustainable and we have to get busy on plantations. I am a great believer that people who are employed in the timber industry do not particularly care whether they are chopping trees down, milling them or planting them. The important thing is that they have a job and that they can continue to live and rear their family in the town of their choice with their family in their own environment, the place that they enjoy. That is what this bill, essentially, is all about—providing the funds so that that can happen.

The purpose of this bill is to raise sufficient funds to implement an effective research and development program under the Forest and Wood Products Research and Development Corporation. All major inquiries and reports concerning the forest industry conducted over recent years have identified the critical need for an enhanced, better coordinated and better focused research effort in the forest sector. The fact is that the forest and wood product industry has asked the government to introduce a statutory levy on the domestic production of wood. The industry, including timber importers, has also requested a charge on imports of unprocessed wood and certain classes of primary, processed forest products, including sawn timber, wood based panels, medium fibreboards and hardboards. This is a charge on domestic producers and importers of wood and forest products. It should be stressed that it is not a charge on those overseas exporters, those external exporters to Australia. So there is nothing there that contravenes our international trade agreements.

The Australian Timber Importers Federation, an affiliate of the National Association of Forest Industries, recently expressed strong support for such a charge. It recognises that importers, who stand to benefit from this research, should also contribute. Economic and marketing research will be of direct benefit to importers and this is an area which will be specifically identified in the charter for the corporation. The charter for the corporation will also be to identify national research priorities and to assess what research is being done. It will commission, administer and subsequently evaluate research into a broad range of issues relating to wood production, extraction and processing. Its charter will also include the ecological and environmental impacts of disturbance resulting from wood production, silviculture and management of native forests and plantations.

I digress by pointing out that a study is currently being carried out in my electorate to look at a completely new use of forest product, namely, the production of ethanol from forestry waste. That will be a world first. Ethanol is produced but it is not produced from such material. If this is feasible, a trial plant will be set up for which this government has already granted $2 million. If ethanol is then successfully produced, it will go a long way to reducing our dependence on imported fuels. These are the sorts of innovations, new ways of generating energy in an energy hungry world, that this country has to explore. At the same time such innovations must be sustainable—`sustainable' being the operative word that has to be present in any policy related to our forests.

Importers will benefit directly from research and development into fields such as expanding the demand for wood products in Australia, new market and product developments, fire related codes and standards and the use of timber in multiple-storey construction. Legislative amendments to the Primary Industries and Energy Research and Development Act 1989 associated with these bills provide explicitly that funds which have been raised from the charge on imports must be directed to research and development, which will be of relevance to the timber importing industry. This will ensure that importers benefit from the research activities undertaken by the corporation.

The levy and charge on domestic production will be collected when the unprocessed wood is delivered to a mill for processing or when it is exported. The charge on imports of wood and forest products will be collected from the importer at the time of importation.

To ensure that imports are treated on the same basis as domestic production, the Forest Industries Research Import Charge Bill provides that the charge on imports of logs is to be set at the same rate as the levy on equivalent domestic logs. The legislation also provides that a conversion factor between unprocessed wood and classes of processed wood which has been agreed with the industry will be applied to the levy to determine a rate of charge for primary processed wood products imported into Australia. These conversion factors will ensure that equivalent rates apply between imports and domestic production.

The introduction of a research charge is fully consistent with Australia's obligations under the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade and the closer economic relations agreement with New Zealand. It is also consistent with Australia's broader trade liberalisation objectives, as the charge will not have any protective effect and is not intended to inhibit trade.

I agree with the opposition that the importation of timber to Australia is a national disgrace. We should consider, however, that there are species that we do not grow here and species that are more suited to some uses for which we currently use timber. As long as it conforms with the free trade between our nation and other nations, we will continue to import timber.

Australia's native timbers are capable of satisfying a much greater use than they currently enjoy in our current domestic market. I sincerely hope that the levy that will be raised under this bill will go a long way towards servicing the needs and uses to which we can put our own timber and towards solving some of the problems that are certainly facing our forestry industry today. I support the principle that we must look at plantations. We must aggressively attack that particular problem because, as I indicated initially, that will create jobs in the part of Australia that needs them most. I have a great deal of pleasure in supporting the bill before the House this evening.

SPEECH.PARA: Plantation forestry must be encouraged if there is to be an expanded industry and a sustainable balance between controlled harvesting in State forests and plantations on private property.
The long delay between planting and harvesting, even if the tax treatment is the same as for other forms of agriculture, is a significant disincentive to investment.

However investors who plant trees in Australia are often subjected to inconsistent rulings by the Taxation office, particularly in regard to the definitions of "capital" and "revenue". If the plantation is deemed "capital", deductions may be allowed only over a 10-year period or even disallowed as coming under "capital gains" rather than "income" provisions.
The Coalition will:
.organise a meeting between the industry and the Taxation Office in order to reach clear definitions.
.review tax arrangements to encourage plantation forestry, including allowing five-year averaging.
.investigate whether lifting the limit on the amount of money that can be invested in IEDs will encourage plantation forestry.
.clarify the situation in relation to capital gains tax being applied to timber sold now from land owned before September 1985.
.undertake an inquiry on how to set a cost base for the purposes of capital gains tax.

Currently the establisher of a plantation can obtain deductions for the cost of the trees and must pay full tax on the value of the trees if selling the plantation before harvest. These bills form part of a package of legislation to establish the Forest and Wood Products Research and Development Corporation, which is to be developed in partnership and with the cooperation of industry. The levy and charges will be set by regulation on the basis of any relevant advice from the industry, in particular the National Association of Forest Industries.

While there is still some discussion occurring on the rate at which the levy and charges are to be introduced, industry has indicated that the different rates of levy will apply to five classes of log, namely: hardwood sawlogs; softwood sawlogs; cypress pine sawlogs; hardwood pulp logs; and softwood pulp logs. For unprocessed wood which is produced in Australia and exported, a charge at the same rate as the levies imposed on domestically processed logs will be imposed by the Forest Industries Research Export Charge Bill 1993 when the wood is exported. This bill also provides that equivalent rates will apply to imported and domestic production.

The legislation sets a maximum rate for a class of log of 0.5 per cent of its average value at the mill door to ensure that no one sector of the forest industry bears a greater responsibility for the industry's contribution than others. Indeed, it ensures that the industry overall is not levied excessively. Levies and charges will be collected in accordance with the Primary Industries Levies and Charges Collection Act 1991 and will be paid into a separate account, together with the Commonwealth contribution, under the administration of the Forest and Wood Product Research and Development Corporation.

These bills mark an important new phase in forest industry research and development which will enable existing research activities to be better focused and coordinated. The establishment of the corporation will be a sound investment in the future of the industry and should lead to significant advances in forest production and our ability to add value to our forest products. This in turn will help to build competitiveness, internationally and between other domestic materials, and will expand the productive capacity of our forest industries.

Forestry is an extremely important industry to Australia. The National Association of Forest Industries Ltd pointed out in its discussions with the caucus primary industry and resources committee that forest and forest based industries have an annual combined sales turnover of $10 billion and directly provide jobs for about 85,000 people in forest management, timber harvesting and downstream processing. The downstream processing includes sawmilling, veneers, joinery, paper and paper products.

Australian Bureau of Statistics figures as at June 1991, in respect of manufacturing industry in Australia, show that the manufacturing component of the forest sector employed 61,700 people. The forest sector employed 6.4 per cent of the total manufacturing work force, and 6.3 per cent of the total manufacturing wages bill. In comparison with other manufacturing sectors, the forest industries employed 9,700 more people than the chemical, petroleum and coal products industries. It employed 6,100 more people than the clothing and footwear industry, and only 1,700 fewer people than the motor vehicle and parts industry. It is, therefore, a very significant part of our work force.

The forest industry realises that regional growth and prosperity can be achieved only through ecologically sustainable development, and that to this end there must be improvements in all aspects of forestry. Improvement can come about only through proper research into and development of our forestry methods and wood products. The forest sector has the potential to make a larger contribution to Australian employment, our balance of trade, and our quality of life.

The research and development corporation can consider the use of new wood technologies and new wood products. It can target the development of all types of value adding processes to forest products. The industry recognises that there is an urgent need for an enhanced, better coordinated and better focused research effort.

These bills give the Australian industry a great opportunity to forge ahead. Here is the opportunity to supplement existing research efforts and to put together a cooperative effort to ensure a sound future, not only for our industries but also for the people who work in them, their families and the wider community.

Forestry is the lifeblood of many of the small towns and communities in my electorate of Lyons. I remember, as a boy, the many small sawmills scattered around the country areas that were the centre of a town's economy. These have now gone but there is potential for replacing their role by ensuring the regional development of our technically advanced industry, both in forest maintenance and the development of private land for forestry. Tasmania has much to gain from furthering research into, and development of, forests and forest products. I am heartened by this legislation and look forward to the betterment of the industry whilst it provides more jobs and more opportunities for the people of Lyons. I commend the bills to honourable members.

They cover one million hectares of public land—five per cent of Victoria. The region is remote and has a population of the order of slightly under 10,000 people, about half of whom owe their livelihoods to the forest products industry. In fact, there are about 30 mills operating in the East Gippsland area and also a range of haulage companies and associated businesses. Even more workers, especially those employed by the APM pulp and paper mill at Maryvale in central Gippsland, have their livelihoods tied to the forest resource base in this region. East Gippsland has been hit hard by constant changes in Labor government timber policies and small timber towns such as Cann River, and even larger ones such as Orbost, have suffered terribly.

Since 1988, sawlog allocations have been cut in half, down from 345,000 cubic metres to 179,000 cubic metres. Some 50 per cent of the old growth forest area is off limits to the industry owing to the expansion of national parks and other conservation reserves which have been put in place over the last decade. A further 20 per cent have been put out of reach of the industry by the Victorian code of forest practices for timber production, which has force of law. All up then, 70 per cent or so of the East Gippsland old growth forest resource is essentially placed in reserve.

The region also has a vastly underutilised resource just lying on the forest floor, some 700,000 cubic metres of residual wood which, as woodchip, is worth about $75 per tonne. That is four times the export price for an equivalent amount of iron ore or 70 per cent more per tonne than the going rate for steaming coal. Mostly, the potential woodchip supply from the region would be surplus to domestic needs and, therefore, it would be focused on the export market.

Because of the continuing uncertainty of federal government export policies and the continuing hangover of the woodchip policies of the former Cain-Kirner state governments, markets for this resource have not been developed and huge earnings have been lost over the decade. The loss of earnings has been of the order of hundreds of millions of dollars and it is all rotted away on the forest floor because of the political opportunism of federal and state Labor governments. If this has not been bad enough, the East Gippsland timber industry now faces a campaign from extreme environmental groups which are trying to suffocate it completely. These groups are arguing for a blanket embargo on native forest logging and they refuse to accept a reserve system which does not completely ban timber industry activity in all forest areas regardless of its ecological health, level of maturity, use history and so on.

As I said previously, some 70 per cent of the region's old growth forest is off limits, as it is to the industry. That is an impressive reserve system but, despite this, the Green groups keep asking for more and more concessions and, by so doing, they seek nothing less than the extinction of the timber industry in East Gippsland. This is despite the fact that they are up against good scientific evidence that the industry is able to work within a sustainable timber yield which fits comfortably with the national forest policy. It is typical of the extreme Green groups which target East Gippsland forests that they will either ignore official reports or totally distort their meaning.

Just to stress the point again, the existing reserve system, which quarantines 70 per cent of the region's old growth timber resource, is well above the threshold required by the national forest policy. There is no further need for reductions in the region's yields. The industry knows that and, as long as it separates out what it means by wilderness areas and old growth forests and adopts a sensible approach to prescribing forest values, the federal government will come to realise the same point as well. I also believe that, once the community has an opportunity to examine the forthcoming study into old growth forest values in the East Gippsland region conducted by the state Department of Conservation and Natural Resources, we will see that access to the forest base can proceed on a stable and sustainable basis and the East Gippsland region can maintain a forest system which is vigorous but which maintains a healthy regard for established forest values.

The Green crusade against the East Gippsland timber industry continues to ignore material such as this. It will continue to demand that anything less than a 100 per cent reserve system is inadequate. It constantly equates old growth forest with wilderness and confuses the public debate. It calls old growth trees ancient trees in a studied attempt to manipulate community opinion. If the East Gippsland timber industry and the whole effort to achieve a policy outcome which is based on sustainable principles is to win through, it will require a great deal more community responsibility on the part of the extreme Green groups than any of them have displayed to date, and it will require that they listen to the evidence as well. They need to understand that the national forest policy allows for the retention of only representative old growth reserve systems and does not aim to ban old growth logging. They need to appreciate that the Resource Assessment Commission's forest and timber inquiry offered a choice of timber and forest management options—not just one—which would have seen the end of old growth logging. They also need to recognise that the findings of the ecological sustainable development working groups on forests also claimed that, if a reserve system which protected ecologically mature stands could be put in place, then other mature forests could be managed for purposes including timber production.

There is, therefore, a framework that can be devised which will allow for the maintenance of biological diversity of forests but which also permits the sustainable flow of forest products. The industry recognises this. The community recognises this. All the major forest inquiries recognise this. The federal government's national forest policy even endorses the same proposition, but the Greens do not.

Despite the manner in which the East Gippsland timber industry has been undermined over the past decade, it still shows remarkable resilience. In recent weeks, East Gippslanders have seen the investment drought break in the forest products industry. Last week East Gippsland's sawmilling industry won $2 1/4 million in new investment. The investment, though far from the large amount needed to restore the vigour of the timber industry, followed approval by the state Minister for Natural Resources, the Hon. Geoff Coleman, of 15-year extensions to two existing timber processing licences.

The new investment is set to target new value added timber processing facilities—the very kind of activity the Minister for Resources (Mr Lee) and the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Mr Crean) keep harping on about but do little to sponsor. Two well-known and respected East Gippsland companies, T.J. Andrews based at Newmerella and Smith Brothers based in Orbost, are to lead the new investment push. With longer licences, the companies are confident they can capitalise on East Gippsland's forest base and add more value to local timber.

Amongst T.J. Andrews' investment plans is a scheme to rebuild its mill and boost sawn wood production from low-grade timber. This investment alone is worth $1 million. Local firm Smith Brothers will spend another $1 million on new kiln drying, reconditioning and further processing technologies. With any luck, even more investment can be expected from timber processor Monier which has also had its sawmilling licences consolidated and extended.

Sadly, because of uncertainty arising from government intervention in the industry in the past and because of the lack of confidence in wood supply, much of the investment in timber processing has bypassed East Gippsland. There has been about $60 million in new investment pumped into the forest products sector over the last five years, but next to none of this has gone into the East Gippsland region. Some companies, however, did not give up hope and continued to believe the sawmill and timber processing sector could still flourish if allowed to operate in a climate of certainty.

The coming of the Liberal and National Party state government has done much to rekindle confidence and those East Gippslanders involved in the forest products business, and who have survived the last decade, are seeing some rewards for their patience. There is now every hope that local timbers can be used for high value added products. The days when native hardwood timbers were destined solely for the commercial housing market are diminishing. Local East Gippsland timbers now have opportunities for specialist applications which command premium prices. This is an objective the federal government should heartily applaud and approve, even though it has all taken place despite it, not because of it.
