TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy Speaker, it is with a great deal of pleasure that I rise tonight to speak on the Forest Industries Research Levy Bill and cognate bills. As you would no doubt be aware, the timber industry has played a major role in the economic development of my electorate, as it has in a lot of the electorates up and down the mid-north and north coast of New South Wales. The industry has supported the economic base of the towns along the coast, but it has also been subject to a lot of external pressures from government and the environmental lobby and has suffered badly from those pressures.

PARA.TAB: It is fair to say that the introduction of this legislation is quite timely. I think it has already been said that the opposition is not going to oppose these bills. It is quite timely that something be done as far as research and development in the timber industry is concerned. Certainly, in the area of establishing inventories of what exists in some of the more contentious parcels of forest that are proposed for logging, we see, day in day out, the timber mills, the industry and the Forestry Commission in New South Wales arguing the case as far as EISs and FISs are concerned, without any statistical base as to what exists in those compartments as far as flora and fauna are concerned. I hope that, as a result of these bills which are before the House tonight, that situation may be addressed seriously so that in the future those sorts of arguments and debates can be factually based and not based more on emotion than anything else, as they have been in the past.

It is with a great deal of pleasure that I speak tonight in support of these bills which deal with the establishment and funding of a Forest and Wood Products Research and Development Corporation. I was glad to see this omnibus package come before the House this week. I was also glad to get the opportunity to speak on these bills.

The forestry industry today is one industry which has enormous untapped potential. It is an industry that is sustainable if managed properly. I do not talk of potential in terms of resources available; I talk of potential in the sense that the forestry industry is a long way from best practice techniques.

This government is a long way from recognising the value of small millers and the contribution they can make to the industry as a whole. A few of the previous speakers made reference to the resource security legislation that was debated at length in this House last year. Unfortunately, I was not here and was not able to be a part of the debate on that resource security legislation. The stumbling block it seemed was the threshold as far as who would be included and who would not. I put it to the government that, in considering future resource legislation, there should be no threshold. The government cannot say it will look after the industry that has a turnover bigger than $100 million a year to the detriment of all the small mills. That is when we will see monopoly situations exist in the timber industry right throughout Australia. If the government is fair dinkum about resource security, it will get bipartisan support.

I stress that it is vitally important that, from here, the legislation be dealt with in the proper fashion. The first step is the recognition by this government that we actually need a forestry industry in Australia. We need the government to make the commitment that we do need a forestry industry and that the forestry industry in Australia definitely has a future.

The government currently has in place a very strange policy for the forestry industry in general. In an attempt to win electoral support, the government has bowed to the environmental movement and placed incredible bureaucratic regulations on the forestry industry. Yet, at the same time, it is importing $2.4 billion worth of timber to meet the needs of an expanding and growing Australia. We have in place in Australia an embarrassingly self-righteous environmental policy with regard to the forestry industry. We do not mind ripping up the forests of South-East Asia or the forests of many other developing countries simply to meet our own timber needs, but at the same time we are kidding ourselves that we are being environmentally friendly by just about shutting down our own forestry industry.

In Australia at present we have some of the most stringent regulations that must be met and, more often than not, cannot not be met by this country's timber workers and timber millers. With these guidelines in place, we cannot meet our current needs for timber in Australia. So what do we do? We rape and pillage overseas forests where regulations are not as strict and then we kid ourselves that we have not sacrificed our principles.

I emphasise my point by referring to a sawmiller within the electorate of Lyne. A few weeks ago I contacted him specifically in regard to this legislation, having got notice that it was coming before the House. He was not out putting in place best practice management strategies for a well-balanced approach to forestry. He was not out making his company streamlined by putting in place the best approaches for cutting overhead expenses and general wastage. This sawmiller was sitting at home trying to put together not one, not two, not three, but four separate environmental impact statements, any one of which, if it had gone astray, could have shut down his whole operation and put his employees out of work.

I felt the necessity to speak on these bills tonight on one hand to support the bills but, on the other hand, to place on record my view that the forestry industry desperately needs a shake-up. I hope that this omnibus package will be the catalyst for that shake-up. There is no investment incentive in the timber industry and there is no capital input into an industry that this government is frightened to support. I must say that, while these bills are worth while, they will mean very little without some form of supporting resource security—without an entry level, without a threshold. We must have fair dinkum resource security. Unfortunately, as many in the timber industry within my electorate have told me, no amount of research and development will be beneficial unless the supporting resource security is also present.

I repeat the main thrust of my argument: it is time in Australia that the federal government made a tough decision with regard to the timber industry. Does the government really want a timber industry? Does the government really support a timber industry? Does the government really believe in the benefits of a timber industry? Without this initial recognition and support by the federal government, the bills that will pass through the House tonight will amount to nothing.

In preparing to address the House tonight on this issue, I contacted not only a number of the mills in my electorate but also a few of the organisations, such as the Forest Products Association and the National Association of Forest Industries, that have been involved in putting together submissions. It seemed to come through fairly generally—as is always the case when a government, regardless of whether it is a federal government or a state government, is setting up a body such as this corporation—that the industry wants proper representation. It does not want just hand-picked people from the National Association of Forest Industries or from the Forest Products Association, or people representing the larger sections of the industry, but fair dinkum representation right across the industry—from the people who turn over a million dollars a year, to the people who turn over $100 million a year. This legislation, and the research and development corporation that it will put into place, may be effective and have the desired result, but it will stumble on the rocks and perish if there is not proper and genuine industry representation for the supervision of the board. The Forest Products Association said:

SPEECH.PARA: Whilst it is true to say FPA opposed the concept, that opposition was based on the requirement that resource security should come first. The principles and importance of an R & D Corporation are recognised and endorsed.
It went on to say:

The only issue we have raised with NAFI is that we believe FPA, representing the majority of the indigenous industry in NSW, most of whom are not individual members of NAFI, should have a seat on the R & D Corp. Board.
I hope that the minister would be cognisant of these opinions put forward across the broad spectrum of the industry.

PARA.TAB: Because the timber industry has an important role to play in this country's future, the forestry industry has enormous potential. What we are debating tonight will, hopefully, be the first step towards a more efficient industry with more capital input from more enthusiastic shareholders. The opportunities for research and development within this industry are enormous. The buzz words in Australia at the moment are `value adding', and this is an industry that has so much potential in the value adding area within the infrastructure and the mills that are already in place.

We must recognise the importance of the smaller sawmillers. I have made this a theme throughout my address tonight and I cannot emphasise it enough. As small business is the backbone of this country, small sawmillers are the backbone of the timber industry. If we neglect them, we neglect the timber industry and its future. We must remember that currently only the big players are represented by the National Association of Forest Industries. We must not let them also dominate the interests of the R&D program.

I believe this to be an exciting rebirth of the timber industry, and we have the best climate in the world and the best forest types in the world for sustainable plantation style industry growth. The steps that take place from here on are probably more important than the steps involved in getting this bill through the House tonight. The industry, as a whole, including the small sawmiller, must be given a say in how this R&D program is established and how its ongoing performance is monitored. I wish the industry luck and every success in establishing a balanced, representative, powerful and sensible research and development organisation. I challenge the government tonight to make a decision about the timber industry, whether we need to support and streamline the industry for it to become as efficient as possible, or whether we continue being environmental hypocrites and rape and pillage forests from overseas countries to meet our growing demands for timber while placing incredible burdens on the timber industry in Australia in a superficial attempt to say that we are caring for our environment.

I will just go over a couple of key points that I think we cannot stress enough in this debate. Going hand in hand with this legislation to establish this research and development corporation there must be responsible, representative resource security legislation. We must have, in the national interest, legislation in place that not only protects the larger millers of Australia, but also protects the smaller mills—the family-owned operations that might employ half a dozen people. They deserve to have their interests looked after by this government, the same as the large organisations have their interests looked after. That sort of resource security will get bipartisan support.

The opportunity is now before the government to take a major step forward in the protection and the nurturing of the timber industry in Australia, which, with this legislation tonight, really is going to turn the corner from being an industry that has been bound by just harvesting the resource that is naturally grown in this country to one that provides a sustainable resource of plantation growth, not only softwoods but also hardwoods. The possibilities are limitless if we give the industry encouragement and scope through the moves that we are taking tonight. We must give it the guidance to go in that direction, with government support.

In closing, I reiterate the point that was made by the Forest Products Association—that the government look seriously at the representation of industry on the R&D corporation and that that representation be not just from the pinnacle of the peak bodies but from across the grassroots level of the industry so that we have all the aspirations and the genuine ideas that are founded on years of practical experience put forward to this very important organisation. As I said earlier, the opportunity is here before the government to commit itself to the future of the timber industry in Australia. It has the opportunity to make a commitment to the timber industry's future, and ensure those jobs are secure. We can secure that resource and this industry, which will remain as a major industry in regional Australia.

TALK.START.PARA: —Before I talk about the Forest Industries Research Levy Bill and cognate bills I want to reiterate something I say very often; that is, that the `p' in politics stands for people. Tonight, in talking about the Australian forest industry, I want to talk about the people concerned—because forests are very like people; they are renewable resources. Sometimes we tend to lose sight of that, particularly in terms of forests—but they are a renewable resource.

PARA.TAB: I know that, because I had the opportunity of living in a forest area for some years in a little village called Timmsvale up on the eastern Dorrigo plateau, in the hills behind Coffs Harbour. It is a forestry area with families who have been involved in forestry operations for generations. Right at the start I want to pay tribute to those people who work extremely hard in the forests, in a very dangerous industry. I could not possibly begin to count the number of my friends in the forest industry who have fingers, thumbs, hands or arms off; whether cut by saw blades or crushed by falling logs. It is a very dangerous, but important, job.

I think back to the families in the area where I lived; the Timms, the Mulhearns and the Seccombes. While I never met him, I recall the memory of old Tommy Timms who in 1906 walked, carrying the corrugated iron for his first hut on his back, all the way from Ulong to Timmsvale. This man was a pioneer and an innovator. He built the first water-powered sawmill in Australia—a very significant development. Others included Paul and Paula Lindsay. It is not only men who work in the forest industries, the sawmills, but women as well—and they make a tremendous contribution. John Rhodes and his late brother, Bill, operated a little bush sawmill and worked extremely hard.

All these people love forests and trees. Lyle Timms, the son of Tommy Timms, is a sawmiller who hates to cut down trees. This is so widespread throughout the forest industry. I think of places such as Bostobrick, Dorrigo, Megan, Cascade, Ulong, Timmsvale, Lowanna—all of the forest areas of the Nambucca Valley, the Bellinger and the Macleay. I mention Briggsvale in particular because earlier this year the mill at Briggsvale burnt down, with the subsequent loss of 40 jobs.

TALK.START.PARA: —Forty jobs.

—As the honourable member for Gippsland says, 40 jobs were lost—a very significant number in a small community. That had an impact right across the Dorrigo and eastern Dorrigo plateaus. This gets us to the nub of the forest industry argument—the loss of resource security. The Briggs family was operating the mill at Briggsvale. Juel Briggs is a very efficient woman. How can the family reinvest millions of dollars in a new mill, after one has been burnt down, without some form of resource security? No people in their right minds could possibly do that.
—The bank would not lend them the money.

—It would not. I wanted to start by paying tribute to those people, because they are extraordinarily important. It is not just those who are working in the sawmills; it is the logging contractors, the bush workers, the haulage contractors and those employed by the fuel outlets, the tyre companies, the machinery workshops and so on. Up and down the north coast—Mr Deputy Speaker, you are aware of this—we have seen a tremendous loss of jobs in the logging industry for a variety of reasons, mainly because of extreme environmental activity, but also because of the lack of resource security.

PARA.TAB: I want to dwell on that because I think it is very important. Australia should realise that if we are going to develop forestry as it should be developed—and have the investment—there must be resource security. In passing, alluding to the fire that burnt out the Briggsvale mill, the social effects are very difficult to identify. I had the privilege of attending a multidenominational memorial service held in what was left of the mill. It was a very moving experience.

The communities in that area are still under considerable stress. It is one of those things that people do not pay sufficient attention to. The coalition has always supported the need for forest and wood product research and a development corporation along the lines of other primary industries. We need to have accurate and factual information about the timber industry. There is a great dearth of factual information. There is a lot of emotion and a lot of garbage talked about the timber industry. Sadly, the fanatical, extreme preservationists have been bandying about propaganda which has been very hurtful to the timber industry.

I believe this is a time when we have to come together. We have to stop the confrontation. We have to stop those fools putting up tripods in the forests and digging holes in the roads and putting themselves down them and we have to get together and talk as rational, reasonable, sensible human beings. There is an answer. I come back to point I made first, which was that forests are a renewable resource and this is the way we should be approaching this matter. There should be a commonsense approach right around Australia so that we can see sufficient investment, so that we can go ahead and renew those forests and keep our timber industry going for a considerable time.

All the major reports on the forest industry, including those of the Resource Assessment Commission's 1992 forest and timber inquiry, the National Plantations Advisory Committee and the ESD working group on forest use have echoed the urgent need for an enhanced, better coordinated and properly focused research program. More research is essential if Australia is to increase productivity and value adding processing in forest and wood product industries and to manage forests in an ecologically sustainable way.

That is the key to it. We must manage our forests in an ecologically sustainable way. That does not mean locking them up forever. It does not mean leaving them in their so-called pristine beauty to die. It is a strange thing but trees are plants; they are living organisms, and they die. So what we need to do is to manage forests sensibly and rationally.

The timber industry has an enormous growth potential. Until now, we have largely concentrated on the domestic market. We still only provide two-thirds of Australia's needs and we import more than $2.4 billion worth of product—much of it high value pulp and paper products. We should be value adding in this area in Australia. It is absolute economic madness not to do that.

We export $775 million worth of forest products. This leaves us with a trading deficit of $1.66 billion. That is stupid. We are not using the land mass we have in Australia. What we need from the federal government is not just more research but sensible taxation policies which will enhance the possibility of people putting in more forests and making it profitable to do so. We can reduce the imports of timber products by value adding. This is absolutely essential if the industry is able to be competitive and capitalise on the resources we have.

A Forests and Wood Products Research and Development Corporation would be a body corporate with day-to-day autonomy and the flexibility to operate similarly to commercial operations. It can identify national research priorities and assess research gaps. We need to commission, administer and evaluate research into a broad range of areas relating to wood production, extraction, processing, economics and marketing. Once that corporation is established, it will have a high range of industry involvement and accountability.

There has been a very big focus on the conservation of our environment in recent years. Quite frankly I welcome this. Anybody who thinks that we can neglect and rape our environment is absolutely crazy. Everyone in this country has to be conscious of the need to look after what we have got.

Timber is a renewable resource but other things are not. It is the responsibility of every Australian—whether they be in this parliament or whether they be a schoolchild—to be conscious of the need to conserve and look after our environment. That comes back to the need for rational, reasonable and balanced management of our forest resources.

There needs to be a balance between keeping people in jobs in the forest and timber industries and keeping our environment to be enjoyed for future generations of Australians. Those two objectives are not incompatible. With goodwill and commonsense we can continue not just to log our existing forests, but enlarge our forests—as we have been doing and as we must continue to do.

As I said, those two objectives are not incompatible. We can continue to provide jobs in the forests and we can continue, as we must continue, to protect that environment for future generations. I come back to the point I made before: it is vital for the timber industry to have resource security. The government, quite frankly, has been lax on this issue and there has been very little happening in the federal sphere. The lack of resource security means that many mills will not invest in new machinery or take on new employees.

This is one of those rare occasions when people on both sides of the House support a measure which has great potential to help improve the prospects of an industry that offers this country a great deal. TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to take the opportunity of the adjournment debate to praise a community group in my electorate, the Low Isles Preservation Society, otherwise known as LIPS. Low Isles represents one large and several small coral cays off the coast near Port Douglas. They have been a tourist attraction for some time and the source of research on the Great Barrier Reef since the 1920s.

PARA.TAB: For many years the Low Isles have been managed and protected by resident lighthouse keepers. Now that lighthouses are to be demanned, the Port Douglas community has formed LIPS to lobby for the preservation and future protection of the Low Isles for all the community. Anyone who has witnessed the natural beauty of Low Isles will attest to that need.

Last Friday night I attended a public meeting at Port Douglas which celebrated the rebirth of Low Isles after the commitment of $1.5 million in the budget. This enabled the management of Low Isles to be passed to the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Authority. GBRMPA will provide at least one full-time resident ranger. Funding will also be used to improve existing buildings, sewerage and other facilities. Research, which as I said has gone on since the 1920s, will now be able to continue. LIPS involvement will continue with the community commitment to future maintenance of facilities on the Low Isles.

Special praise should go to Karl Jesienowski, the President of LIPS, and the LIPS committee, as well as the Port Douglas Tourist Association, the Mossman Boat Club and, in particular, the support that has been given by the Mossman Gorge Aboriginal community to LIPS. I have nothing but praise for this community group. This group approached me and the state member for Cook, Mr Steve Bredhauer, some time ago. LIPS impressed me with its professional expertise and hard lobbying skills as well as the fact that it represented a broad range of the Port Douglas community.

As I speak, negotiations are under way between the Australian Maritime Safety Authority and the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Authority to resolve the transfer of the lease of the isles. Now that we have the federal budget passed, funding can start to flow through. This indeed represents a rebirth for Low Isles. I commend LIPS for its leadership. I am sure that its cooperative approach could well be a model for future management of other environmentally sensitive areas throughout Australia.

TALK.START.PARA: —The matter I wish to raise for the attention of the government and the House concerns the natural disaster relief arrangements for people affected by the very serious floods that devastated north-eastern Victoria earlier this month. Just briefly to remind honourable members, the position is that virtually thousands of people have been affected by these floods which are the worst in recorded European settlement history. We have a range of people who are affected such as families; pensioners living in houses that are rented or owned; small business people in shops, particularly in Benalla, and people in factories; and farmers whose lands have been totally denuded of topsoil and who have had their crops wiped out.

PARA.TAB: Generally speaking, even though the waters have now gone, the dimension of the problem is such that we have a worse disaster than I think is really appreciated. When a misfortune such as a flood in a community is suffered which affects just a handful of people, whilst the impact on the people is substantial, the impact on the region is not as great. But when a vast number of people are affected, as has happened in Benalla for instance, we have a national and a state problem of greater dimension. I do not think the full measure of the problem has been realised yet.

I have had messages, especially from Benalla, that indicate that many small businesses may not survive and may be unable to keep staff on. Some families are under enormous pressure. People are unable to repair their homes. Some landlords are unable to afford to repair rented homes. Farmers just do not know where to turn.

Under the state-Commonwealth arrangements there is a set of guidelines for natural disaster assistance, and that is much appreciated by many people. But I have had reports, for example, that people who are entitled to cash grants of up to $700 per family to carry on following the disaster have been refused that assistance because they were too late to lodge their claims—too late because they were out helping in emergency relief, rescue and cleaning up for others. This is typical of Australians: helping others, and knowing full well that they had to clean up themselves. Yet when they have lodged their claims, they have been told that their claims were ineligible because they were out of time. That lack of flexibility between the states and the Commonwealth needs to be investigated urgently.

There are offers of concessional loans at four per cent to small businesses, but they have to prove their viability. Whilst I do not have all the personal details of applicants, I understand that most loans will not be granted because, due to the devastation, those small businesses are not viable and are therefore ineligible. Those businesses would have been able to continue to trade and employ people if they had not lost their stock and their premises could be used. But now the premises are not as effective, stock has been lost and, in many cases, the businesses have no cash and are in a precarious position. Again, the guidelines need to be reviewed so that special assistance grants can be given in appropriate cases.

Similarly, a number of farmers who would survive may not be able to cope with additional loans even at concessional rates because of their existing debt structure and the long-term nature of recovery from devastation. It may take some years before the paddocks can be restored to productivity. Generally speaking, there is a very serious situation in north-eastern Victoria. I ask all the responsible Commonwealth government ministers—of which there are several—to immediately discuss with the appropriate state ministers a review of the guidelines with a view to producing appropriate measures. There are many people in this area of Australia who would be prepared to assist both the state and Commonwealth governments in assessing and dealing with those particular problems.

TALK.START.PARA: —The residents of Geelong's southern suburbs of Belmont and Highton, as well as the surf coast and Bellarine Peninsula towns such as Torquay and Ocean Grove now find it difficult and time-consuming to obtain cash rebates for medical bills attracting a Medicare rebate. It is about time that the Health Insurance Commission ended its illogical policy of not allowing some of the most respected private health funds to offer full agency facilities.

PARA.TAB: A Medicare agency through the Geelong Medical and Hospital Benefits Association is needed in Belmont. Until March 1988, GMHBA was one of the four health funds authorised to pay Medicare claims on the spot and in cash. In a decision that owed more to centralised Canberra control than to commonsense, the then Hawke government suddenly decided that it could no longer allow private health funds to act as Medicare agents. Since that date, whilst GMHBA will take Medicare claim forms and send them into Geelong for processing in the form of a mail cheque payment, residents of these suburbs and towns are forced to travel into Geelong, where parking is difficult, if they want an instant cash refund from Medicare.

One of the reasons why Medicare ceased this agency arrangement was a suggestion that some duplicate payments were occurring as agents were unable to assess the claims against a patient's claims history. There were also suggestions that some agents were not as competent as they might be.

It is time for the Health Insurance Commission to again appoint selected health funds in regional Australia as agents for Medicare claims to provide a personal and efficient service. Mrs Norman Boyd of Belmont wanted to see a new Medicare office established in Belmont. By her own efforts she started a petition in December 1992 that had the support of 800 residents. Today there are 266 Medicare offices around Australia. Back in 1987, there were 264. Under the Medicare arrangements, the Health Insurance Commission does not have the funds to open new offices.

Geelong and its nearby towns need a convenient Medicare agency in Belmont run by an established, respected health fund such as GMHBA. The government has had an entrenched philosophical opposition to allowing private health funds to act as agents for Medicare but, given the increasing cost of running Medicare, it is time to look sensibly at the agency as an option. On the other hand, Medicare has an ideal time to implement this opening.

In November and December 1994 respectively the combined Medicare and Medibank Private offices leases expire at Corio Village and Moorabool Street in Geelong respectively. This would be an ideal chance for Medicare to move to slightly smaller premises in Geelong and save some of the $75,000 annual rent bill. There would be some fit-out costs at smaller premises, but if a three-year lease with at least a three-year option was taken, this could lead to some savings to the Health Insurance Commission.

Another reason why Medicare clients in Geelong's southern suburbs and hinterland deserve a better service is the small number of claims that are direct or bulk-billed in these suburbs compared to what occurs at Corio across the Barwon River. Going by where doctors or providers, as Medicare calls them, are located, in the June 1993 quarter nearly 76 per cent of Corio's claims were bulk-billed. Yet, for the 44,300 claims against Medicare for postcode 3216—Belmont, Highton and Grovedale—lodged in the months of April, May and June this year, only half, 50.8 per cent to be exact, were bulk-billed. A quarter of all these payments were made in cash.

So residents of these three Geelong suburbs are having to make at least 44,000 trips a year to call into Medicare's Geelong or Corio Village offices. Some of these trips may be combined with other shopping in Geelong, but many are not and cause inconvenience and extra expense to south of the river residents. The Health Insurance Commission must once again give efficient, respected health funds like GMHBA the chance to serve southern Geelong residents with one-stop shopping for health payments.

TALK.START.PARA: —On Saturday I attended the opening of a unique medical establishment, the Bundaberg Friendly Societies Hospital. I was privileged to be asked to give a keynote address before the extensions were opened by the Chairman of the Private Hospitals Association of Queensland, Mr Cahill. I say `unique' because the hospital represents a caring and unselfish contribution of nine friendly societies lodges. While acknowledging the need for modern medical care, the BAFS Medical Institute, as it is known—the administrative arm of those nine lodges—has retained the essence of the community in the project.

PARA.TAB: In the helter-skelter of so-called regionalism, the dismantling of community aspects of medical and paramedical service—no more telling example of which was the changeover from the QATB to the Queensland Ambulance Service—and the dehumanising of many public hospital practices, this friendly societies hospital stands out in stark contrast.

The $5.2 million expansion takes the hospital to a $10 million facility. It started out in 1946 as little more than a cottage hospital. It worked itself up to a fully-fledged private hospital with extensions in 1983 and is now equal to the best in country Queensland. Its bed capacity has increased from 36 to 55 beds, including an ultra modern six-bed maternity unit.

All rooms are ensuited and encompass the most modern technology. It has state of the art laminar flow theatres and a quality high dependency unit. I might add, its telephone and TV systems are the equal to, if not better than we experience here in Parliament House—and that is saying something. As a person who served for 15 years on a public hospital board, I was amazed at the vision of this hospital board led by chairman, Bob Philips; his deputy, Maureen Kimber; secretary, Peter Sawyer; and director of nursing, Kim Knoblauch.

The medical institute, which runs three successful commercial premises and a highly successful pharmacy turning over $3 1/2 million a year, makes a significant contribution to the quality of medical care in the Bundaberg community. It not only allows three hospitals—itself, the Mater Misericordiae Hospital and the Bundaberg Base Hospital—to specialise in areas of expertise but also makes a significant contribution to the economy of Bundaberg by injecting $9 3/4 million each year into the cash flow of the community. It employs 85 people, 65 of whom work in the new hospital. To cap it off, the board of the BAFS Medical Institute delivers this service—it might be worth a lot of other private hospitals listening to this—at the scheduled fee. There are no loadings; the service is delivered at the scheduled fee. The institute even offers a rebate roughly equivalent to 10 per cent to its lodge members.

I have often heard in this House honourable members—especially those from New South Wales—complaining about the quality of health care, some blaming the ALP government and some blaming the previous coalition government. I do not know who is to blame, but I found this hospital—which stands in stark contrast to the handout mentality of many hospitals—to be a refreshing difference. I am not suggesting that health care is not the

SPEECH.PARA: ultimate responsibility of government. Clearly it is. However, I question whether we have paid a high price in taking the community aspect out of the health equation. With understandable pride, I congratulate the BAFS Medical Institute and its nine constituent lodges, and I trust that they will continue to deliver quality health care in the Bundaberg district.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Health, upon notice, on 17 August 1993:

PARA.TAB: (1) How many persons have died from AIDS related causes in Australia since the disease was recognised.
(2) How many of the deaths referred to in part (1) are attributable to the use of blood products.
(3) What is the per capita funding for known sufferers of (a) AIDS, (b) heart disease, (c) cancer, (d) diabetes and (e) hepatitis B.
(4) Is a homosexual male statistically more likely to die from (a) cancer or (b) heart disease than from an HIV related disease.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Health has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

PARA.TAB: (1) Total deaths from AIDS related causes in Australia to 31 March 1993 are 2,630.
(2) Exposure category is known for 2,610 of these deaths and, of these, 77 (3%) are attributable to infection from blood products.

(3) It is not possible to supply this information with any certainty. While there are some items in the Medicare Benefits Schedule and some drugs listed on the Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme which are likely to be applicable to particular conditions, the greater part of Commonwealth expenditure cannot be readily broken down by disease state. Funding under the Medicare agreements to the States for public hospitals is also not related to disease except in so far as there is a specific amount identified ($45.587m in 1992-93) in response to the burden of AIDS. It should be said that the aim of the Government is to ensure access to appropriate health care for all Australians irrespective of the condition from which they may be suffering.

(4) Mortality statistics do not include information on sexual preferences, nor are there any other measures of how many homosexual men there are in Australia. We therefore cannot estimate the chances of homosexual men dying from one cause or another. However, the majority of deaths from AIDS occur in men between the ages of 20 and 50 whereas deaths from cancer and heart disease occur in older age groups. Men dying from AIDS die earlier than they would from other leading causes of death in males.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Treasurer, upon notice, on 17 August 1993:

PARA.TAB: Is the amount of taxation payable affected by fluctuations in the value of shares; if so, what would be the effect on a pension if the recipient bought shares at $5.00 in June 1990 and the market value fell to $3.00 on 23 September 1992 and then rose to $4.00 on 23 September 1993.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's questions is as follows:

PARA.TAB: Fluctuations in share values do not, of themselves, affect a shareholder's income tax liability. Capital gains on shares become taxable as income only when the gains are realised by disposing of the shares.
Regarding the second part of the honourable member's question, the Department of Social Security has provided the following explanation:

Whether changes in the value of shares covered in the question affect a pensioner's payments will depend on a number of factors. These include the number of shares held by the pensioner, the dividends paid on them, and the amount of any other income and assets of the pensioner. New social security rules for shares do not apply to shares purchased before 19 August 1992.

The impact of any change in pension on income tax liability depends on the total income of the pensioner for taxation purposes and the pensioner's personal circumstances. At present most pensioners do not pay income tax.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Treasurer, upon notice, on 17 August 1993:

PARA.TAB: (1) What is the maximum sum an employer may pay an employee without becoming subject to the superannuation levy under the Superannuation Guarantee (Administration) Act 1992.

(2) Do all superannuation funds approved under the Act have establishment, management or administration fees; if so, is it a fact that employees who earn just over the maximum are disadvantaged through the payment of fees which match or exceed their benefits.
(3) Will the Government introduce exemptions to remove anomalies in the imposition of the levy.
(4) Is it a fact that part-time employees who are forced to change superannuation funds when they change employment are subject to transfer fees which may eliminate their superannuation benefits.
(5) Will the Government eliminate anomalies affecting part-time employees; if not, why not.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: (1) Except where the employee or payment is otherwise exempted under the Superannuation Guarantee (Administration) Act 1992 (SGAA), an employer is required to provide the prescribed minimum level of superannuation support, or pay the Superannuation Guarantee Charge, if the employee is paid $450 or more in salary and wages in a calendar month.

(2) & (4) Yes. All approved ("complying") superannuation funds impose, to varying degrees, management and administrative fees, and many impose establishment (entry) and exit fees. It can be the case that these fees will dissipate small, irregular contributions required under the SGAA.

(3) & (5) As I indicated in my statement of 17 August 1993, "National Saving and Superannuation", the Government is aware that there are a number of difficulties associated with the operation of the SGAA. In that context, I noted that a particular concern is the fact that relatively small amounts of monies required to be contributed on behalf of many casual and itinerant employees could be eroded by fees and charges applied by recipient superannuation funds.

The Government is according a high priority to resolving this and other problems with the SGAA. In the interim, the Government intends to defer quarterly compliance with the legislation until 1994-95.

PARA.TAB: Did the Hyatt Hotel Canberra supply catering services to his Department in early 1993; if so, (a) what services were provided, (b) how much did they cost, (c) where were they provided, (d) what items were separately identified in the account, (e) what did each item cost, (f) for (i) whom and (ii) how many persons did the Hyatt cater and (g) who (i) initiated and (ii) authorised the expenditure.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: (a) The Hyatt Hotel Canberra supplied catering to the Resource Management Improvement Branch of the Department of Finance for a seminar on current issues in financial management for Senior Executive Service officers from Commonwealth departments and agencies. Quotes to provide a venue for the seminar were sought from four locations. The Hyatt Hotel was chosen on the basis that it was able to provide a venue capable of accommodating the anticipated number of participants and at the same time offering competitive rates compared with other venues in Canberra. The Hotel has the advantage of being centrally located to many departments and agencies and provides ample free car parking facilities. The services supplied were a buffet lunch, coffee, morning tea and beverages, room hire, and audio visual equipment hire. The cost of these services were recouped by charging participants a fee of $75.00.
(b) The total cost for these services was $10457.20.
(c) These services were provided in the Federation Ballroom at the Hyatt Hotel, Canberra.
(d) All items were identified separately in the account: lunch; arrival coffee; morning tea; beverages; room rental; audiovisual and PABX.
(e) The cost of each of these items is as follows;
Arrival Coffee—930.00
Morning Tea—$1240.00
Beverages—$975.00
Room rental—$500.00
Audiovisual—$608.00
PABX—$4.20
The audiovisual equipment included sound equipment used for the video taping of the proceedings for later sale and distribution.

(f) (i) The Hyatt Hotel Canberra catered for a seminar organised by the Resource Management Improvement Branch on behalf of the Commonwealth Department of Finance, to provide information on current issues in financial management. There were ten speakers at this seminar, including the Secretary and Deputy Secretary of the Commonwealth Department of Finance.
(ii) The Hyatt Hotel Canberra catered for 310 SES level participants from 49 departments and agencies across the public sector.
(g) (i) The expenditure was initiated by Garry Brooke, A/g Senior Officer Grade B, Resource Management Improvement Branch, Commonwealth Department of Finance.
(ii) The expenditure was authorised by Stephen Bartos, Assistant Secretary, Resource Management Improvement Branch, Commonwealth Department of Finance.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Family Services, upon notice, on 2 September 1993:

PARA.TAB: (1) What sum has the Government allocated in the 1993-94 Budget to the International Year of the Family.
(2) What is the broad outline of activities to be undertaken during the International Year of the Family.
(3) What will each activity cost.

(4) Will the National Council for the International Year of the Family which was established by the Government consult with existing community groups and organisations which have an interest in promoting the interests of families.
(5) What qualifications and experience does each of the Government appointees to the National Council for the International Year of the Family have which enables them to contribute to the Council.
(6) What is the accepted meaning of the term "family".

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Family Services has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

PARA.TAB: (1) The Government has allocated $4 million ($2.8 million in 1993-94 and $1.2 million in 1994-95) to the Department of Health, Housing, Local Government and Community Services to co-ordinate Federal Government involvement in the International Year of the Family (IYF).
(2) Although a detailed national time frame and program of initiatives for IYF is not yet finalised the following broad activities are anticipated:
National Council activities including meetings and community and peak body consultations;
National Communication Strategy including public relations, publications, and a national advertising campaign; and
Office of the International Year of the Family activities including co-ordination across the Federal Government and liaison with all spheres of government.
(3) The preliminary breakdown of the IYF Budget is:
National projects including major conference costs, research and one-off demonstration projects $0.55 million in 1993-94 and $0.08 million in 1994-95;
National Council activities $0.55 million in 1993-94 and $0.35 million in 1994-95;
National Communications strategy $1.1 million in 1993-94 and $0.46 million in 1994-95;
Running Costs for the Office of the International Year of the Family $0.58 million in 1993-94 and $0.29 million in 1994-95; and
Evaluation $0.02 million in each of 1993-94 and 1994-95.
(4)Yes.

(5) Council members were appointed because of their personal and professional involvement and experience on a wide range of family issues, including social policy, welfare, disability, youth, employment and industrial relations. Their backgrounds also reflect the ethnic and cultural diversity of Australian society and Australian families.
Brief biographies of the Council members are set out in my news release of 22 July 1993 announcing the National Council (Reference RC 18/93).

(6) The United Nations' guidelines for the IYF states that: "Families assume diverse forms and functions from one country to another, and within each national society. These express the diversity of individual preferences and societal conditions. Consequently the International Year of the Family encompasses and addresses the needs of all families".

Australia's response to IYF will reflect the diversity of Australian families including the diversity of cultures (in particular, Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people) and variety of religious and social norms which comprise the Australian community.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Treasurer, upon notice, on 6 September 1993:

PARA.TAB: (1) What sum was allocated to Western Australian roads in the One Nation statement.
(2) Has the entire sum been spent; if not, (a) why not and (b) when will it be spent.
(3) Was an allocation made for the redevelopment of Subiaco Oval; if so, (a) what sum and (b) has it been spent; if not, why not.
(4) Has any expenditure on the redevelopment of Subiaco Oval been derived from grants originally allocated to roads; if so, why were the funds diverted.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Dawkins The Hon J.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: (1) The One Nation statement did not contain a specific allocation to Western Australian roads. However, of the total sum of $603 million included for all roads, $55.4 was notionally allocated to Western Australian roads (see answer to (3 and 4), below).

(2) $47.4 million has been paid to the WA Government. Reports from WA indicate that all but $600 000 of that sum was spent on schedule by the end of 1992-93 and that the $600 000 was spent in July of this year.

(3) and (4) It is intended that $8 million be applied to the redevelopment of Subiaco Oval. However, it is not accurate to say that the $8 million for Subiaco has been derived from grants originally allocated to roads.

Before the One Nation statement, the then Premier of Western Australia, Carmen Lawrence, and I agreed that $8 million from the package be held over, pending further consideration of infrastructure projects that would benefit the Western Australian community. When arriving at this agreement, we had in mind that the Hatt Report on the redevelopment of Subiaco Oval was then close to completion. While we were waiting for it to be released, it was necessary, for administrative convenience, that the $8 million be notionally allocated to some part of the One Nation package: it was notionally included in the National Highway System allocation for Western Australia but the funds were never allocated to specific projects and it was always envisaged that they would be devoted to Subiaco. In the 1992-93 and 1993-94 Budgets, the funds were presented as a separate appropriation titled Urban Infrastructure in the Health, Housing, Local Government and Community Services portfolio.
To date these funds have not been paid to the WA Government because no formal proposal for

ANSWER.PARA: the project has been received from WA. Commonwealth and WA officials are meeting to progress the proposed redevelopment.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Treasurer, upon notice, on 27 September 1993:

PARA.TAB: (1) Are members of the public made aware of the wholesale sales tax they must pay on all items of goods they purchase; if not, will the Government make them aware.
(2) Will he introduce legislation to require retailers to display the wholesale sales tax level on all goods they sell.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: (1) The wholesale sales tax is collected at the final wholesale selling point, which is normally prior to the stage that the consumer would buy the goods. The sales tax law does require a person who sells goods by wholesale at a tax-inclusive price to specify the amount of the tax on an invoice given to the purchaser. The legislation does not make any requirement in relation to retail sales, as retailers are not normally the collectors of wholesale sales tax. It is a matter of commercial discretion by retailers whether or not to identify on their invoices the amount of sales tax previously paid on the goods.
(2) The Government does not intend to change the present provisions of the sales tax legislation in relation to this matter.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Medicare: Rebates for Bone Density Tests

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Health, upon notice, on 29 September 1993:

PARA.TAB: (1) Are rebates provided under Medicare for bone density tests; if not, why not.
(2) Will the Government provide Medicare rebates for bone density tests (a) generally or (b) to pensioners and low income earners; if not, in each case, why not.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Health has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

PARA.TAB: (1) No. In the 1993-94 Budget, however, the Government has committed funds to improve access to bone densitometry testing through the provision of a Medicare rebate.

The specification of a Medicare Benefits Schedule (MBS) item(s) for bone densitometry has been referred to the Medicare Benefits Advisory Committee (MBAC) for advice. MBAC is an independent statutory body of medical practitioners which advises the Government on the application of Medicare benefits to specified health services.

In providing a Medicare rebate for bone densitometry, the Government is keen to ensure that the technology is used appropriately. Consequently, MBAC advice has also been sought on the safeguards required to promote appropriate and quality use of the technology, on suitable supporting information to be provided to the medical profession and consumers and on monitoring the implementation of the MBS item(s).
Introduction of the MBS item(s) is dependent on MBAC advice. It is anticipated that this will occur in the next three months.
(2) The specific conditions and, therefore, Australians eligible for Medicare rebates for bone densitometry is dependent on MBAC advice.
